reviewText: For the most part,I think this was a great horror movie. Naturally being a huge fan of the even more terrifying games,my review may seem biased.However I truely don't understand why Roger Ebert gave such a terrible review for this movie,other than perhaps he has something against video games.While the conclusion of the plot can be a bit confusing (they made the mistake of trying to fill in the connection on SH 1&3 and then adding hollywood's take on the game) there is still much for both horror fans and SH fans to enjoy.The effects alone should have given this a thumbs up (Ebert barely gave any credit to this except to say that it was like a college art film) One of the greatest moments was when we encounter the first creature of Silent Hill.When the face was shown and that shrill was made,I truely got scared just from the anticipation alone.Then shorlty thereafter,when the "grey children" burn up,we get a dark comedy moment of Rose waking up to Johnny Cash's Ring of Fire.While the acting was average(at least for the male roles)Cybiland Rose both did a good job portraying the horror that would be felt if being immersed in such a sadistic,evil dimension.Also all SH fans will be happy to see their favorite demons make appearances in this movie adaptation.Included are patients roaches,Pyramid Head,and my personal twisted favorite,the nurses.Call me strange,but I actually find them kind of sexy.The different music from various SH games are this movie's soundtrack.With the most notable being SH3's opening title as the movies end credits.Personaly I think there will be alot more people that like this movie than hate it.The only reason that I give it a four star instead of a 5,is because 1.)I would have liked the storyline to be completely from an actual game rather than hollywood changing certain aspects 2.)the plot does kind of lose you,which is because of the first problem and 3.)more demons and special effects rather than the whole "witch!witch!" harping done in the final 45 minutes of the movie.Still,the good outweighs the bad.SH and occult gore fans will enjoy this one.Roger Ebert is just a pompous,self-absorbed dinosouar who needs to retire.
summary: Send Pyramid Head after Roger Ebert!!

reviewText: This movie is the best recreation of a game.  From the music to the environment.  The people at Konami should use this as an example to what their next gen game should look like.  Now after watching the PS3 trailer I really wanted to purchase this movie despite what others have said about the picture quality.  The movie is far from award worthy but it does really utilize the Blu-ray.  At least as far as picture.  I found the movie looked really good with a crisp picture and superb resolution.  Despite what some people have said I can only think they have less than a 1080p t.v.  Overall the movie is hardly scary and doesn't seem to have anything redeming.  I wanted to have something pull me in.  Whether it was a character's performance on the visuals.  Nothing grabbed me.  Even with some horror movies that aren't very good you still get a little comedy.  Not here.  This may be one of the best videogame adaptations but as far as watchability I would say go somewhere else.

reviewText: Silent Hill has never been one of my favorite video games due to the franchise's clumsy controls, clunky combat, and aggravating puzzles and riddles (I hate riddles dammit!). But this movie is good, really good to be exact. Which is no surprise considering that one of the film studios: Davis Films; helped make the excellent Resident Evil films. This film is a mix of stylish, morbid, gory, and disturbing horror that is wonderfully pieced together and retains the essence of the games.WHAT IT'S ABOUT: A nine-year-old girl named Sharon is having strange dreams and sleep walking while speaking of an old ghost town in West Virginia called Silent Hill, which in the 1970's had nearly the entire population of the town burned due to a coal fire and is now referred to as "The Tainted Town". Her mother Rose takes her to the town to figure out why she is having these dreams, and on the way there they get into a car accident. When Rose wakes up, Sharon is missing and she goes to search for her in Silent Hill. Then many strange things begin occurring, and she slowly discovers the horrible secrets the town's hellish history contains along with her daughter's history, while trying to evade the many horrific abominations of creatures the games are known for like Pyramid Head.STORYLINE: SCORE- 8.75 OUT OF 10- The story could use a little work, some parts of the story are things I've already seen in other horror flicks, but other parts are not which makes most of it good and more interesting than many horror movies.GORE FACTOR: SCORE- 9.25 OUT OF 10- This film can be downright disgusting when it comes to gore factor. Arterial spray, skin being ripped off, people being burned to death, and more.DISTURBING FACTOR: SCORE- 9.5 OUT OF 10- The creature designs are macabre, gross, and scary. The way the town and all of its horrible contents have been designed wonderfully and really match the eerie feel you get if you play the games, because you're afraid of what will come for you next.MUSIC: SCORE- 9.5 OUT OF 10- The people who made this movie must really love the games considering they got the guy who does the amazing music for the games to do the music for this movie and it fits to near perfection.ENTERTAINMENT: SCORE- 9.5 OUT OF 10- This movie is highly entertaining and will really keep you on the edge of your seat and wanting to know what comes next as the story is very nicely conveyed. Gore factor is wonderful, creature designs are true to the games along with the town's design, and great music really sums up this horror movie classic.OVERALL: SCORE- 9.5 OUT OF 10- If you like the games you'll probably love the movie, if you like horror movies in general, you will like this movie. What makes this horror movie all the more better, is the fact it feels much fresher than many horror movies. Can't wait for the sequel!
summary: A HORROR MOVIE CLASSIC  9.5 OUT OF 10

reviewText: It takes a lot for a video game to scare, shock, or disgust me.  The only two games that immediately come to mind are Resident Evil and Silent Hill.  These games are the only ones that I can remember actually being scared to play when I was alone.  I think I was about 12 when the first versions of these games came out, and all of my gaming systems were in the basement.  Therefore, whenever I felt like playing, I had to go all by myself down into the basement to plunge myself into the terrifying worlds that these games transport you to.  However, other than being frightening, Resident Evil and Silent Hill had very little in common as far as the focus of the game itself.  While Resident Evil was a "zombie game," Silent Hill was much more atmospheric and creepy, with less violence in general.  When the Resident Evil movie came out, I was very excited.  Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with the resulting film.  It wasn't a terrible movie, but they took way too many liberties with the storyline, and the film turned into more a creature flick than a zombie movie.  Resident Evil was one of the first movies to be based upon a game, and its failure to materialize really set the standard for future movie to be based on games.  I mean, just think of the video game movies of the past.  You've got Mortal Kombat (not horrible), Doom (horrible), Street Fighter (ridiculously bad), Final Fantasy (waste of money), Tomb Raider (at least it had Angelina Jolie), Super Mario Bros. (I don't wanna talk about it), Bloodrayne, House of the Dead, Alone in the Dark, and the list goes on...  To say that video game movies have a bad reputation is a serious understatement.All that said, for some reason, I was really excited to see Silent Hill.  Let's be honest here.  I wanted to like this movie.  No, no, I wanted to love this movie.  It had a great director (Christophe Gans) and a great screenwriter (Roger Avary) and the source material was actually better than most video games, so why wouldn't it be a good movie, right?  Those were all the ideas I had in my head when walking into the theater.  And when I want to like a movie, I find something to like about it, no matter how awful it might be.  To be frank, Silent Hill was one of the absolute weirdest movie going experiences that I have ever had.  I am completely torn on this movie.  As a video game adaptation, strictly, this is by far the best that has ever been released.  This movie is true to the game in every aspect.  Whether it is the scenery, characters, dialog, music, or camera angles, the film is basically like watching someone else playing the video game.  Granted, to write a screenplay you have to create some sort of story to give it some meaning, so the revolving story around the events that are taking place is mostly created by the screenwriter, but it is still an OK storyline, even though it strays from the games (at least the ones that I have played) in a few ways.  However, as a movie, Silent Hill just doesn't really work.  It seems jumbled, the dialog can be extremely hokey at a bunch of moments, and it does drag at some points.  For a lot of viewers, I'm sure, the movie will seem like a bunch of random, nightmarish segments all just thrown together like an episode of Saturday Night Live....but from Hell.  However, for those of us who have played the games, there is a much higher level of appreciation that is attainable here.Rose and Christopher's adopted daughter, Sharon, has a sleepwalking problem, and during her "episodes," she is constantly talking about Silent Hill, a town in West Virginia.  After a particularly intense episode, Rose decides that she needs to take Sharon to Silent Hill and get all this figured out.  Rose and Sharon head off to town while Christopher is left alone at home, fuming over everything that has been going on.  They eventually get to the abandoned town (mine fires burning underneath caused massive deaths) and a car crash separates mother from daughter, and from there the movie devolves into an insane nightmare with some images the likes of which have never even been seen by these eyes.  There are some creatures in this film that the images will stick with the viewers for a long time to come.  Pyramid Head is an amazing, unfortunately underutilized demon that plays a frustratingly small role in the film.  When he does appear, however, he does not disappoint.  The dead man in the bathroom stall (I don't know a specific name) is a truly disturbing image.  As he crawls along the bathroom floor, with his black tongue flicking out, and his legs tied all the way back above his head by barb wire, I was very uncomfortable.  Once again, however, he is only in the movie for that one scene, and not much really happens other than we get to see him, and then Rose runs away.  The nurse demons are in the film as well, and their scene easily provides the most tension-based part of the film, as Rose must navigate through their twitching, evil bodies without letting them sense that she is there.  All these random encounters with demons represent about ? of the movie.  As the last half hour approaches, the viewer is given the classic flashback sequence to explain what is going on.  And while I feel the explanation is unnecessary, I do understand why Roger Avary decided to add it to the film.  If there was no explanation, the chances of anyone liking this film who hadn't played the game would be decreased to zero.  Once the flashback is over, the climactic sequence does not disappoint in any way.  While most of the gore is CG, it is over-the-top enough to where I didn't really care.  And there are a couple of really disturbing moments (just think about a little girl dancing and skipping around in a shower of blood from one of her victims).After the credits started rolling, I decided that I didn't like Silent Hill.  It wasn't really a movie, in a lot of ways, as I said earlier.  And most of the other people in the Gateway theater didn't really like it either (there was a lot of laughing and ridiculing going on).  As the night wore on, though, and I talked about the movie a little more with the people I saw it with (who both thought it wasn't bad), I realized that I was looking at the movie in the wrong way.  I can't "rate" this movie based on how good of a film it was, I need to judge it based on the source material and how it applied the plot of a simple video game as the basis for a 2 hour movie.  Like I said, as a video game adaptation, this movie blows all other out of the water in every way.  Quality, loyalty, and visuals are all out of this world and directly comparable to the game.  Therefore, I have now decided that I did like Silent Hill, and while most people who see it probably won't enjoy it at all, it pretty much did what I expected it to do, which was disturb me.  It isn't a "scary" movie really at all.  I can't think of many moments when I was genuinely scared, but I can think of plenty of moments when I was staring at the screen saying, "Oh dear Lord, no."  And if a movie can make me do that, it has definitely succeeded.
summary: Best video game adaptation to date

reviewText: I saw the movie last night at the theater with three friends who have never played any game from the Silent Hill series. When we got out of the house we'd seen the movie at, they were all staring at each other and asking the same question: "what the f*ck was that all about!?" while I was still thinking whether I liked it or not, and remembering the first game. I was probably 12-13 when the first of the series came out, and just like 99% of the people who played it, I LOVED it. I feel like one of the reviewers before me, who said he 'wanted' to like the movie.I think this movie has a lot to do with the first game, and part of the second one, unlike most videogame-based movies, which usually come up with completely different bases. I don't wanna spoil the fun by saying which enemies or 'bad guys' they've included, I'm just gonna say they're AWESOME and perfectly adapted. The special effects are great, but in the 2000's that's nothing out of the ordinary. The storyline has the same concept as that of the first game, with several differences that were made for this adaptation.I don't wanna say much more to not spoil the fun, but my point here is: if you've played Silent Hill and Silent Hill 2, you'll like, or even love the movie. If you haven't, you'll be confused and will probably hate it.About the rating, as the movie it is, I give it 3 stars. As a Silent Hill fan, I'd give it 4 stars for the good job on the adaptation.

reviewText: Considering that this movie is not out yet, I wont go so far as giving it five stars (I will probably change my opinion when I go and see it, as I explain onward).  Thus from what I've seen, the trailers and reading summeries and all, I think that this movie does have the main character correct...the main character being Silent Hill, the city/the hell.  Yes it doesn't have Hary Mason, though it does have close to the same storyline as the first game...from what I've observed so far, it also takes a bit of the other two games (I wont go so far as adding the fourth game as I really didn't like it myself, but that's just me).  Silent Hill is the main character, and the hell that it works upon those who come into its lair is the prize for the movie watcher.  Silent Hill is filled with shadows, blood, and ancient mysteries better left hidden as the cliche goes.  Silent Hill is what you come to see the movie for, Silent Hill is what you play the game for, at least for me.  One character comes and another one goes, but the darkness that is SH is what brings me back to the game.  I am not myself so worried about having every specific character from the game, I am just hoping and praying (a strange thing to be doing toward SH anyway) that the producers/the writers/the directors/and the actors compliment the TOWN and the TOWN in turn complimenting them.  I hope and pray, again I say, that this will not be a repeat of the first House of the Dead (a really, aweful, foolish movie).  If everyone making this film makes the TOWN of Silent Hill correct, as it burns into your mind's eyes as you play the games and as you see the movie, then I will be happy!
summary: Considering this is not out yet

reviewText: First off, let me be honest--I have NEVER played any of the games. Period. All I know about the games comes from friends who HAVE played it. So this is not a comparison of how the movie stacks up against the games. I don't care about that.The story makes a lot of sense to me, and I genuinely feel for (most) of the characters. Rose's reactions are very believable when confronted by the nightmares, as are the cop Cybil Bennett's. Cybil is also one of the coolest people I have ever seen in a movie, and if I ever end up in a life-threatening situation, I want someone just like her with me. Awesome character. And I understood why Alessa did what she did, and part of me even agreed with her need for revenge. The first time I watched it, the whole movie was absolutely terrifying--subsequent viewings have cooled the reactions somewhat, but there are still some scenes that scare me every time. The first monster Cybil and Rose encounter...Colin...but the scariest scenes (and the ones I watch the movie for) are the ones with Pyramid Head and the broken nurses. As I have said, I have never seen the games, but I knew who Pyramid Head was/what he did, and I knew about the nurses, but nothing prepared me for seeing them the first time in the movie. Awesome.I am a horror movie buff, and this is one of my favorites. And it doesn't matter if you have never played any of the games.
summary: A very good horror movie in my opinion

reviewText: When I was watching "Silent Hill" in theater I wished sometimes I could rewind and watch certain scene again for it was rather hard to understand from the first time. Generally the film left a good impression but I wasn't thinking of it as of some kind of a masterpiece. But the next day I felt an urge to watch "Silent Hill" again. I have to say here that the last (and only) time I watched some movie in theater twice was when I decided to see "Die Hard" one more time in the beginning of 90s when it was one of the first big American films to hit our post-Soviet screens.So I watched "SH" again and liked it much more as well as understood better. The next day my brother said he's going to the cinema to see "SH". I said I'd go with him. So I watched it for the third time in a row. I guess I understood everything I had doubts about although some mist still remains. And now I can only say "SH" is one of the best films I've seen in life and I mean not just within a horror genre.First I thought it was some kind of a "Hellraiser + The Cell + Dark Water + Nightbreed + In the Mouth of Madness" mix, but then I realized it's quite unique in its style, manner and pacing. It's impossible to tell what "SH" is about because it has lots of meanings, lots of subplots which you can interpret whatever you like, and first you have to think a bit just to interpret it somehow. Among all recent horror films I immensely liked "The Descent" for example and that movie was pretty simple - an understandable story, no hidden agendas. But here you are given enough food for thought for I don't know how much time. "SH" is good for the second and the third and many more viewings because everytime you watch it you'll find something new and discover previously unnoticed layers.Visually "SH" is just beautiful. It's sinister, apocalyptic and picturesque like paintings of Goya and Bosch. And yet it's so enchanting. "Silent Hill" world is very tactile and substantial I can't remember any other movie that would be so real. You can really sense this town, smell the coal-burning, feel ashes on your hair, feel the darkness coming with every fibre of your skin. And its dismal and tenebrous mechanical inferno with all the hellish creatures just exists right here - around you.There are many different things to think about on "Silent Hill": it has a theme of revenge and justice. It's about personal hell and hell in a general meaning. It's even metaphorical about alienation when members of a family live close to each other and still lose connection, they almost literally don't notice the person next to them.It's even a bit embarrassing that "Silent Hill" is made out of a video game - it's so good it should've been separate, individual work. But now it's obvious to me a good film can be shot based on a game, after a deadborn "Doom" and abysmal "House of the Dead".I'm anxiously waiting for the DVD to be released, I'm sure I'm going to watch it again and again. Definately waiting for the sequel (although have my fears about it) and for the next Christophe Gans film may those two be in one.
summary: THE HORROR GENRE IS DEFINATELY NOT DEAD YET

reviewText: I played all of the Silent Hill games.  I used to say that proudly.  This movie is faithful to the videogame's original plot: it's a convoluted mess.  The movie looks fantastic, but I have no idea what it means.  Since it so faithfully recreates that element from the game, the fault is in the game, but why make a bad movie?  Because people like a videogame?  At least I assumed the game had a plot, as I'm still not sure what that is.  The main reasons I played the games were that the games were more about creepy noises.  I confess: it never made sense and neither does this movie.  The interesting part of the game was the 3-D free-roaming environment with monsters lurking around.  The games were good because they were 3-D and had a lot of odd linear perspective shots which were replicated for the movie.As much as I like the game's competition, Resident Evil has 2-dimensional backdrops which are semi-annoying, and it was cliche'd from the stories of George Romero's Night of the Living Dead trilogy.  However, the plot was at least more coherent than the muck of Silent Hill: I always knew that.  The reason for playing the Silent Hill games was not because it made sense, but because it has an original story and theme with a fantasy world like a David Lynch film, or like Terry Gilliam's Brazil, and particularly like David Cronenberg's older films, but even those films had some relevance.Perhaps Silent Hill was not supposed to have any meaning, but only be a fantasy of horrors with imaginative visuals and aurals to go with its gameplay.  Like Roger Ebert described, I wish the movie had not given me so much plot detail and story explanations because doing so gummed up the sensations of its mood.  The more it explained things, the less sense it made.  Silent Hill was meant as a purely subjective experience for videogame industry consumers of the time.  I confess that I never understood what the story meant when I played the games: I knew there was a cult organization, I knew there were characters, I knew there were horrors about ghosts and goblins, but I only accepted the creedence of these things at face value.  The movie should not have spent so much time with the secondary spouse character, and I don't remember that in the game or the connection with the real world either.  It could've just been a movie with a haunted house setting and interesting characters.Think about it if you care: the game initially started on Sony's first Playstation, and Sony was emphasizing 3-dimensional graphics, although the memory of its console was not so capable.  It was trying to compete with Nintendo who always gave videogame consumers stuffed-plush animals as protagonists.  Sony in making games with adult content, especially the first Silent Hill game, was a declaration of revolution in an industry of stuffed animals; THAT FACT GAVE SILENT HILL A LOT OF WEIGHT IN ITS IMPORTANCE AS A SUBJECTIVE EXPERIENCE.  Since the release of the first Silent Hill game ten years ago, Sony has outdone Nintendo in the videogame industry.  Sony won; this movie isn't needed.  Silent Hill was an extremely playable game even without a story coherence, and one with a lot of adult situational blood and violence, more as in paintings, and that was what it was worth.  The game was very playable because it offered a whole city, or town, with a completely free-roaming 3-dimensional environment, which also added greatly to the game.  But, contrary to the belief that this game would've made a great movie, I insist not.  Everyone who said so should admit to it as a mistake.  The movie has now hurt the game with answers and meanings it was never meant to have.  The events were curious enough to keep a videogame character moving to witness the violent and disturbing images for subjectivity, but I'm happy I know a bad movie when I see one.If the movie has one good thing going for it, it's the exceptional cinematography and that it wasn't as brainlessly superficial as the Resident Evil movies.  Perhaps not, but this one was a bore with intresting pictures.
summary: Silent Hill Movie: a Movie Without Meaning

reviewText: *  Based on the game series by Konami*  Written by Roger Avary (Pulp Fiction)*  Directed by Christophe Gans (Brotherhood of the Wolf)It's been a while since I've written my last review, and despite it being somewhat close to Silent Hill's original theatrical release date, I feel it is high time that I write a review to offset some of the rather mixed reviews I've read.  While it certainly became a hit at the box office, critics have been mixed about this horror film, based on the cult game series from Konami, and even fans have started to spread themselves thin over what to make of it.  I was no different when I heard that Christophe Gans was directing, in which I wasn't all too fond of "Brotherhood of the Wolf" to begin with, and that there were some story points that were changed; however, I still wanted to give the film its chance and in the end, I'm really glad I did.  I would go so far to say that this is the best film adaptation of a video game ever.  Seriously, when has a video game based film been THIS good?The story is changed somewhat; Instead of Harry Mason, we have Rose (Radha Mitchell), married to Christopher (the totally awesome Sean Bean), who adopt a child named Sharon (Cheryl from the Silent Hill video game).  Sharon keeps having bad dreams about Silent Hill, a town with a terrible history that has been locked away for quite some time.  Despite rumors and historical accounts, Rose decides to take her there against Chris's wishes to figure out why she's having nightmares. After an accident, Rose is knocked unconscious, only to awaken in the ash-falling Silent Hill and without Sharon.  Along the way she runs into Cybil Bennett (Laurie Holden), Dahlia Gillespie (Deborah K. Unger), and Christabella (Dahlia's sister, played by the deliciously evil Alice Krige), among others.  She also is led to many areas that have been a part of Alessa's suffering, and she encounters crazy monsters including the all-too-scary Pyramid Head lifted from Silent Hill 2 for the Playstation 2 (my favorite Silent Hill game).  We are given Alessa's horrible past, being made fun of for her powers ("Witch!") and eventually burned in a sort of witch trial; This backfires, however, sending the followers of Christabella into a state of limbo in Silent Hill, and the town has gone awry with hellish monsters lurking about at random as the result of Alessa's hatred.  Alessa had drawn Rose there, along with the light side of Alessa's soul (Sharon), in order to exact revenge upon the misguided cult worshippers.  Meanwhile, Christopher fears that something has gone wrong and sets out to discover where Rose and Sharon are, despite butting heads with a detective (Kim Coates), who has a connection to Silent Hill's past...The movie is graphic in its depiction of Silent Hill, basically a world of Hell on Earth.  They went through the trouble of making it LOOK like the games.  I commend the production designer and the art directors for successfully making this transition from video game into filmmaking.  Christophe Gans has strategically placed the cameras to make it seem as though we are playing the game through odd but creepy angles.  We view some of the most terrifying images in horror film history such as when Cybil is mercilessly beaten to hell and burned alive, or when the Pyramid Head rips the clothes clean off a cult follower (Tanya Allen) and slices her skin clean off!  And if that doesn't scar you for life, then the retribution scene (which plays almost like if Christ were pissed off, he'd kick our collective tails) with barbed wire ripping through flesh and bone surely will.I appreciated some of the story shifting, like Dahlia no longer being the villain (in the game, she led the cult to resurrect the demon Samael), and the mythology of the cult has even changed; They're misguided Christians who yearn to cleanse the world of evil, only to have created their own Purgatory in Silent Hill, and refuse to accept fault or redemption for their sins.  They are given the chance, and pay for it.The ending have left many disappointed, but it left it wide open for a sequel.  Plus the fact that each Silent Hill game has a sad ending of sorts, even the best ones.  All the actors turn in excellent performances, especially Laurie Holden and Alice Krige, and I may have found a new hero in Christophe Gans.  He has directed a film so painstakingly similar to the Silent Hill game without giving away too much or shying away from the origins of the story (the music score by Akira Yukumoura is even from the games, particularly 2 and 3!).  He also added little touches like the patient demon from Silent Hill 2, the nurse from the first game, and even getting the street names right (the last names of several horror authors).  This is a beautiful yet almost unbearably creepy film, and I totally commend the filmmakers for FINALLY creating a video game based film worth talking about.
summary: At last, a GOOD video game movie!  *SPOILERS*

reviewText: I have played the original Silent Hill for the Playstation One, and let me tell you, the main story of this movie is almost exactly the same as the video game! I'm not kidding- I knew exactly what was going to happen because the stories were so much alike that a part of me was actually worried that I might be wasting my time watching the movie when I could be playing the game.As you've probably heard, the video game Silent Hill was extremely groundbreaking in the year 1999 because the game was SO scary and SO different compared to every other game that was on the market at the time. Now, with that in mind, this movie failed to live up to the intense atmosphere of the video game.However, it doesn't matter, because the movie did a respectable job at scaring me, and you know, having the main character be a woman who has to find her daughter instead of a father who has to find his daughter (like the video game) may have actually been a better decision. If you've played the game, you'd know that Harry Mason was a REALLY bad voice actor. The woman who plays the mother in the film is really good.Also, considering this movie came out years after the video game it's based on, technology has improved which means you are guaranteed to see better visual effects in the movie than you would in 1999 playing the game. Silent Hill the game was more about remaining quiet and building an atmosphere, whereas the movie has some really unusual effects such as blood rising off the floor and walls and increasing the overall amount of action.The similarities between the movie and the game don't stop there- remember when you had to run around looking for your daughter in the beginning of the game? It's in the movie. Remember that snowy town with buildings all around it, and only a human police officer around? It's in the movie. Remember finding a note from your daughter that she's at the school? It's in the movie. A lot of things from the game are in the movie.Another complaint people have with this movie is that the story doesn't make sense. That was a popular complaint with the video game too. I don't like it when horror movies make sense, to be honest. I can't feel scared when the story begins making total sense. Silent Hill leaves you wondering what's going on. You'll know what's going on. The movie just takes a weird direction later on that may end up confusing you.Really good movie worth watching, even if you've played the video game a million times like me.

reviewText: This dark film leads to the question: What have you become?  All he could say was 'Hey, it's gonna be okay."  Who are you to judge?  No one can judge "angels."  We are judged according to our deeds.  Sounds like a religious movie.  On the contrary, that huge cathedral in Silent Hill, West Virginia, is used to burn sacrifices; a pagan symbol is atop the tower.Johnny Cash's "Ring of Fire" was used as a prelude to show how this pagan cult had taken over the ghost town.  It is symbolic of good verses evil.  Nurse Betty was there in her red sweater and red shoes (no, it's not 'The Wizard of Oz,' but symbolism and falsehoods where no one is as he appears is at the forefront in this creepy-crawly film).  It takes faith to restore innocence and purity.  Faith is the only truth.  Perhaps your faith will protect you, perhaps not?What's your definition of justice?  You didn't tell me everything.  I double-dare the viewer to learn the truth.  Don't believe their lies -- what they had created mushroomed into an inferno.  Sharon had "seen" the town and school in her tortured dreams and drew colored pictures of them.  On one of her sleep walks, we see a huge lighted cross of fire at a waterfall.  Rose, her adopted mother, couldn't take any more and drove her Jeep to take the child to the scene of these weird dreams.  There, a coal fire burned underground and ashes float like snow.  She told her "It's going to be just you and me" but when she thought all was hopeless, she wept from desperation.  They found a devil's playground where the ghost women were "desperate housewives" right out of 'Pajama Game.'Lonely and scared in this deserted place, they found a bus stop sign on which Neely Avenue took them to the orphanage and school.  Certain forms you just can't control, like the living dead.  This dream must end.  Everything (nothing) will be alright ever again.  Do you know what you've done.  They were fanatics and what they did was terrible, unethical.  She was emotionally tortured by the "human" vermin where they found a demon in the "core" of darkness.  This is crazy -- you who cast the first stone can take refuge in the church, where unbelievers are thrown into the lake of fire for their misdeeds.  A runaway elevator takes Rose into the bowels of fire, a hell on earth, beneath the church.  Deliver me from the evil demons who are deceivers and tell lies.  This can't go any farther.  All we ask for is satisfaction; only the innocents will survive.  The guilty will perish in "a ring of fire."Now, we must pray as they cast out evil with sacrifices, as in the pagan days in the Mayan mountains.  Guilt will not deny you.  I need to do this, Rose felt; she wants vengeance.  Your reward is the truth, but you'll never be the same.  Hurt, she yells, "Get off my back."  They find things tarnished and are too damaged to see anything is alright, as nothing will ever be the same, even in paradise.  This scary episode is based on a video game.  End of Story.

reviewText: I must admit that I have never played SILENT HILL, the game. Consequently, I was completely mind-f'ed by the gloriously gruesome visuals and über-nightmarish set pieces. I had to watch it a second time in order to pay closer attention to the actual storyline. I consider this movie to be like a much  darker (considering what is required of anyone wanting to enter SILENT HILL in the first place), more adult version of LABYRINTH. Rose (Pitch Black's Radha Mitchell) loses her daughter in the ghostly town of the title, and must go on a life threatening / mind altering adventure through its many mouldering halls and alleys. Along the way, Rose is joined by officer Cybil Bennett (Laurie Holden from The Mist and TV's X-Files), who is drawn into the same hideous encounters w/ the various demonic denizens of this hellish place. Together, they must not only face legions of demons, but also a crazed religious cult led by Kristabella (Alice Kriege from Ghost Story, Star Trek: First Contact, and Sleepwalkers), who is Jim Jones in a woman's skin. Rose and Cybil find themselves in the middle of a war between two dark forces bent on destroying each other. The monsters are memorable, especially the main demon (w/ his gigantic cheese-grater helmet and telephone pole sized butcher's knife!!), and those murderous, knife-wielding nurses! Highly recommended...
summary: Now, That Is One BIG Knife!...

reviewText: Fine cinematograghy and exceptional computer graphics are the highlights of this rather dark (visually) new entry to the videogame to movie genre. As usual, with this genre amd the comicbook to movie genre, we're a little short on storyline and long on nonsensical coincidence. With these obvious shortcomings you'd wonder why the filmmakers would think they could sustain your  interest for two hours. Well, the fact of the matter is, they don't really get rolling till after the the first half hour but they still could have easily wrapped-it-up in the next hour.On the plus-side, the computer grachics were some of the best I've ever seen. Much of the success of the graphics were enabled by the sound effects. The blend was very effective and almost good enough to make Silent Hill worthwhile. Time might find it to be a benchmark, something like: Tron, Starship Troopers, Silent Hill.

reviewText: "Silent Hill" is a technical masterpiece, particularly when it comes to production design.  A lot of people spent a lot of time making this movie look good.  The cinematography was interesting and attractive.  And the actors could act, a welcome change from most movies of this genre.  The little girl was very good and has a decent career ahead of her.I also have to give "Silent Hill" points for doing two things that horror movies often don't do.  First, it tells us the names of the characters early on, so we're not discovering an hour into the movie what the main character's name is.  Second, we actually get to Silent Hill within 13 minutes of the movie starting; it doesn't screw around at the beginning waiting to get started.However, this movie only gets three stars because of story/plot issues and editing.  Frankly, there isn't much story at all, just some excuses for pretty production design.  Things happen simply because they're in the script.  For example, Mom takes her sleep-disordered little girl to the creepy town in her nightmares rather than to the doctor.  And she resists arrest to do it.  I didn't buy it.  The ending comes 20-30 minutes later than it should, and leaves you wondering what the point of the whole movie was.Nevertheless, if you enjoy horror movies, you can do a lot worse.  This is at least worth a rent.

reviewText: First off, I should probably mention that I possessed absolutely no prior knowledge of the "Silent Hill" video games before sitting through this particular movie. Having said that, I must also point out that I followed the flow of the story perfectly from start to finish. So many had previously warned me that Director Christophe Gans had no feel for the narrative and that no portion of this overall amazing motion picture made any logical sense. If, however, like me, one is prone to utilizing their brain cells throughout certain cinematic fare like "Silent Hill," these claims do not hold true.Radha Mitchell assumes the starring role of a young mother who drives her daughter, Sharon, to the creepy town of Silent Hill to find answers behind the mysterious sleepwalking ailment she's been afflicted with. A violent crash precipitates Sharon's abrupt disappearance and leaves Rose, the mother, in dire need of tracking her down and ensuring her safety. She soon discovers that Silent Hill is not what it seems. A perpetual fog of smoldering ash envelops her surroundings, while freakishly twisted mutations straight out of H.P. Lovecraft's worst nightmare threaten and mill around every corner. We, the viewers, soon learn of a mass tragedy that befell the local citizenry, forcing those who were left in its wake to endure a ceaseless purgatory inside the town church. Evil, unknown to Rose and her daughter, has secretly summoned them to the borders of this formerly thriving town so that it may use their oblivious presence to infiltrate the forbidden barrier of the church and access these people who somehow escaped its cruel punishment.I was thoroughly enraptured by every last reel of this production. Gans elicits a visual style that is both grotesque and undeniably beautiful. An unrelenting sense of dread resonates throughout the entire film. And when the much-debated ending rolls around, one finds that specific dread has not yet abated.Yes, the door is left open for a second installment. But, this represents one instance where I actually find myself welcoming that notion with open arms. "Silent Hill" left me hungry for more, much more, and I can only hope that any sequel we do eventually get will carry on the rare breed of quality that this film bleeds in abundance. It may not be for everybody, in all honesty. But it is exceedingly well made and is guaranteed to spellbind you with imagery you're not likely to forget anytime soon.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In terms of graphcis alone, this is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  When I first saw it, I figured most of it was CGI, but then I watched the making -of featurettes and was startled to find that many of the creatures were actually in costume.  You don't see too much of that these days.  The atmosphere of Silent Hill was perfectly captured in the gloomy sky, falling ashes and decrepit buildings.Where I got hung up was the plot.  I've never played the Silent Hill game series, so I don't know if that would help me or not, but at the end I literally just sat there and asked myself: "What just happened here?" And found I had absolutely no idea.  Here are just  a few questions that were raised in my mind: Are all the residents of Silent Hill dead (like, is that why Rose says they're "already damned?") and just think they're some sort of super-cult that survived the apocalypse?  Is Alessa dead, and if she is, how did she give birth -- and why at the particular time she did, YEARS after she was burned, from the timeline I could gather? Is Sharon more of a "spirit-child," an entity, or some sort of copy, of her "mother?" Who is the creepy demon child and why does she look like Sharon? What's up with the barbed wire in Alessa's "revenge" sequence? Where did all the weird creatures come from and what do they have to do with anything, other than scaring the principal actors? Do Sharon and Rose die at the end of the movie?  What's Dahlia supposed to do, all alone back at Silent Hill? Also, another reviewer mentioned a disease that Sharon is dying from: How did I miss that? What is this weird disease? All I saw was a sleepwalking child...You know, I really have no clue.  I enjoyed watching the film, but I emerged more confused than I went in, which isn't exactly the cathartic feeling I normally like to experience at the end of a viewing.  I do like the soundtrack, though.
summary: Visually exciting, but hard to follow...

reviewText: Silent Hill is a confusing movie, I had to watch it twice to understand it, unfortunately I fell asleep the second time I watched it. yah, I admit I'm not a big horror fan & the fact that I fell asleep shows how not interested I was in watching it again. stupid friends, lol. anyway, it's not a bad movie, it just doesn't make alot of sense. there's not much point to the movie cause she dies like right at the beginning and the rest is all a dream after that or more likely, a nightmare but it makes it all pointless. cause it's all just a nightmare, it doesn't make it scary anymore. probably why I fell asleep the second time. it's ok for one viewing cause the acting is fine, there is a bit of a plot I guess but it's just so weird. I guess it's all about the visuals & Silent Hill did everything very well in that department! this movie at least tried, something Doom, Wrong Turn, I Know What You Did Last Summers, Screams & especially House of a Thousand Corpses didn't do. so yah, it's a decent horror film, something I would never watch again cause it's just not that interesting. but one viewing, is ok. I'd say rent it if you love horror films or if you got nothing better to rent. it's just not really my kinda film, I like Thrillers way better cause I find them scary! I find they tend to have a better plot & I love it when the build it up so we're interested to see what's going to happen from one scene to the next, like Signs. this film was kinda like that but it's just dumb. horror films I find tend to focus too much on gore & not enough actually being scary. so I tend to stay away from them cause it's just disgusting, we don't need to see people's limbs getting hacked off & this film does have it's fair share of gore but it didn't bother me too much. it's plot that's stupid. so if u don't mind a confusing midly entertaining movie based on a video game, & I have to say, it's on of the better movies based on a video game, I mean, compare it to Tomb Raider which both of them were ok or more fitting a comparison, Doom, which was an absolute disaster, but compared to any other film, it'd be toward the end of my list of films to watch.
summary: it has it's highs & lots of lows

reviewText: I'm not a complete fan of this movie-ripped-off-game version. I've played all 4 games that have released state side so far, though ripping off the games 1-3 isn't what I expected from a movie based on a game.The plot was changed incorporate a female lead, which is the biggest difference, the main game Silent Hill is based on, is the first game, from which Harry was the main character. He was removed to have some woman running around yelling `Where's my daughter?', `I'm looking for my daughter!' gag. Her name, is Rose. The daughter's name was changed from Cheryl to Sharon. But other characters from the first game were kept - all the female ones that is. Cybil the policewoman, Dahlia the old woman (who I could actually stand!) and Lisa the nurse. All of the main male characters were removed, and only 2 men were actually focused on in this movie - Rose's husband and a policeman, but they weren't main parts of the movies just background really. Other extra female characters were also added in and the plot was changed.Pyramid Head - James Sunderland's own manifestation was featured in the movie for no reason. Pyramid Head was James' nemesis and didn't fit in with why he was there but it wonderful to see my favorite character return. This was the main Silent Hill 2 game addition.And the 3rd game addition from Silent Hill 3 was Rose becoming the mother of god, this had nothing to do with Rose because Cheryl is Heather. Heather is Alessa.Don't get me wrong, this movie was a lot better then the Resident Evil trilogy, at least this movie was sticking to the basics of what the game is about.

reviewText: I have never played the video game Silent Hill, and I am seriously weary of any adaptation of said games into movies because most of the time its like watching CGI paint dry. The only movie that has ever come close to mimicking the game, to me, was Resident Evil (the first one), and even then the special effects in CGI are poorly done. The actors that sign onto these movies usually don't give Oscar caliber performances, so I don't expect much.This movie gets 6 out of ten. It was entertaining, and its visuals while a bit over the top were still good (Heavy on the CGI, but in this case it was warranted). One Complaint here was that the child actor in this was seriously horrible. She looked the part, and that might be the reason she was cast, but it was excruciating listening and watching her. Another was that Alice Krige has no range as an actress and has just one "note" that being an evil smirking slow talking pale faced woman. The ending, with the barb wire was a complete rip off from Hell Raiser, even in such that Silent Hill alternates in between realities Hell/Reality.  If you are a fan of Games than watch it, if you are a fan of horror you will be disappointed, because there were no true scares here when you take into account how hard it is to suspend disbelief when dealing with CGI. Unless you're a complete Wuss.

reviewText: Before I give my opinion of the movie, I just want to say that my wife HATES scary movies and especially horror movies. She sat down with me and watched this and was glued to the television, completely involved. More so than me. (I wanted to watch it at night when it was dark, but she won't... too scary.) About halfway through, I mentioned the cliffs, the streets that have been broken apart as if Silent Hill were cut off from the world and how it was just like the video game... cool. She said, "This was a video game?"So, before I begin, this is an excellent film and you don't have to know the video game to enjoy it. In fact, it is recommended, because you'll know less about what is coming and what to expect.Silent Hill is hands down the most successful Video game to Movie transfer to date, and I don't say that based on revenue. I say that based on quality of film and quality of entertainment.Rose (Radha Mitchell) and Chris DaSilva (Sean Bean) have adopted a beautiful and charming little girl named Sharon (Jodelle Ferland). Knowing little of her past or where she came from, they are mystified and frustrated by the elaborate sleepwalking incidents and the unconscious mentioning of a mysterious ghost town named SILENT HILL. Getting nowhere with doctors or medication, Rose, in desperation, decides to bring Sharon to SILENT HILL and get to the bottom of her dreams.SILENT HILL is a fantastic mix of movie elements. It's not just a horror movie. It is a mystery. It is a riddle. It's the story of a Mother and Father who'll do anything to save their adopted daughter from her torment. On top of that, it's a wonderful display of graphics, visual effects and creature creation.As Officer Bennett (Laurie Holden) and Rose stare in amazement at the fact that the road they came in on has seemingly destroyed by a catastrophic earthquake, the blob-like armless man lumbers their way with its legs bowed inward. A fantastic build up of what's to come and what they're in for.I won't give away the elements of the story that make this a fantastic viewing experience. Giving away the elements will destroy the fun of the mystery. I will say that the movie managed to stay true to the game, but also took it in a completely different direction. The creators of the film made some great choices with their creative liberties.From the opening moments to the closing moments, SILENT HILL is intriguing and interesting. It never rests. It is solid from top to bottom. I'm not sure why I don't give it 5 stars, because I really liked it. I've only seen it once, but it is certainly right up there in my favorite collection of horror dvds.

reviewText: "Silent Hill" is a movie that succeeds in creating the right mood for a horror film: most of the scenes make use of a washed out color scheme, making every shot seem like a something surrounded by a fairly thick blanket of fog (or in this case, smoke). There are also a fair number of dark settings, which, as you may have guessed, are the ones where the scariest moments occur. It harkens back to the classic storytelling method of hiding something mysterious and possibly deadly within the shadows. It's good to see that even modern day horror filmmakers will sometimes rely on well-established formulas to effectively frighten the audience.But creating a mood is the only way in which "Silent Hill" is successful. Everything else--I'm sorry to say--misses the mark by a staggering degree. This is especially true of the story, something so full of holes that it could easily put Swiss cheese to shame. It isn't helped by numerous moments of unimpressive dialogue that don't border on cliche so much as they cross it and head for the horizon. That could be why many of the key scenes rely heavily on special effects and makeup tricks; Hollywood seems to think that when a plot loses cohesion, they have to give the audience eye candy to make up for it. Occasionally that methodology works, but in this case it was all just wasted effort, amounting to something that uses horror aesthetically instead of as a way to help the story progress.It's no secret that every horror movie requires some suspension of disbelief; otherwise, the whole genre would be debunked. The problems come when certain things are simply too unbelievable, even for an exaggerated concept. Herein lies one of the biggest issues I had with this movie, especially when it came to the character of Rose Da Silva (Radha Mitchell); she's a mother searching for her nine-year-old adopted daughter, Sharon (Jodelle Ferland), in the abandoned town of Silent Hill. For a woman who has lost her daughter in an unknown area, she still seems calm enough to stop every five minutes and examine a strange phenomenon.But I'm getting ahead of myself. Apparently, Sharon has been prone to bouts of sleepwalking, as shown during the opening scene in which her parents try to save her from unintentionally jumping over a rather large waterfall (a geographic feature not normally located within walking distance of a suburban area). All of her nightly excursions are frightening ordeals, especially since they end with her ranting and raving about Silent Hill, a place she's never visited or even heard of. Rose decides to take her daughter there against her husband's wishes (Sean Bean as Christopher Da Silva); since she screams the town's name in her sleep, and since her childlike drawings point to some strange clues, maybe going there will finally bring some answers to light. I guess it didn't matter to her that the very fabric of the town's social and economic structure unraveled after a devastating fire (which, according to local information, still burns deep beneath the city).Rose is almost pulled over by Cybil Bennett (Laurie Holden), a cop who is suspicious of anyone taking a child to Silent Hill (apparently she had arrested a man for throwing his son into one of the town's coal pits). But instead of obeying the law, Rose decides to speed way. She probably would have made it had she not swerved off the road to avoid hitting a child standing in the middle of the street.The incident causes her to hit her head on the steering wheel. When she awakens, Sharon is gone and everything outside is smoky and coated in ash. The frantic search for her daughter immediately lands her and Officer Bennett in the perpetually ashy Silent Hill; a place the audience already knows will be the start and the end of the whole mess.And here's where the scares start popping out. Not long after Rose's arrival, the wailing of a siren alert system is heard, after which the screen fades to black. When Rose ignites her lighter, everything around her--including the walls, floors, and ceilings--melts into a grotesque, undulating organic mass. This is immediately followed by the arrival of faceless, deformed beings that amble along like zombies. At a certain point, they burn away into ash and the walls and ceilings turn back to normal. This happens continuously throughout the film, and eventually other beings make their presence known, including a helmeted warrior-type equipped with a twenty-foot blade and an army of mutant insects.This marks the point when the already weak emphases on plot and character development collapse. Initially, the tense moments of creature encounters are effective; they certainly left me in anticipation of what their role in the story was. But as the crucial details were gradually revealed, I realized that the creatures added nothing to the film other than providing a few minutes of digital wizardry. Their scenes come off as unnecessary interludes in an already complex sequence of events. This includes encounters with some very enigmatic characters, such as Dahlia Gillespie (Deborah Kara Unger), a woman dressed in tattered black robes who babbles in seemingly incoherent religious terms. While virtually nothing about her is learned, we do know that she feels connected with Sharon, at times frighteningly so.Eventually Rose and Cybil meet a group of religious fanatics led by Christabelle (Alice Krige). This congregation has been able to avoid the periodic resurgence of creatures and melting architecture within the confines of a church. How they go about this is never explained; maybe they've somehow been able to bless the church. However, we do learn that they have previously used their faith as an excuse to conduct witch-hunts. We also learn that they don't care very much for Dahlia. This is mostly due to her daughter, Alessa (an important character who, as fate would have it, bears a striking resemblance to Sharon). I won't go into much detail; let's just say that something bad happened to someone a long time ago and now they want revenge.Of course, this movie also features Christopher as he goes on his own quest for the truth. He desperately searches for his wife and daughter amid some pretty tough obstacles, especially Officer Thomas Gucci (Kim Coates), who knows more about the town's dark past than he lets on. Or at least, that's the impression I got; ultimately, he says little if anything that hadn't already been established earlier in the story. He does do one helpful thing, though: he brings Christopher to Silent Hill so that they can both perform a quick search. (And here's the interesting thing: from their point of view, all traces of ash and smoke are gone. Now that's creepy.)So what exactly do we have here? Basically, we have a pretty bad mess of a film: the idea behind it was good, but the way it was told leaves a lot to be desired. It doesn't help that the ending is a nonsensical, confusing pasting of shots; I'm convinced the director tacked it on at the last minute because of growing studio pressure. Still, I suppose fans of the video game series will like this movie. I ran into one just as I was leaving the theater, and according to him, this film adaptation of "Silent Hill" is perfect in every way. To each his own, I guess.
summary: Something Terrible Must Have Happened Here....
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film isn't the usual blade-to-the-eye gorefest that's been coming out of Hollywood for the last couple years--which, I think, is a good thing. Instead, Silent Hill goes for mood more than gore and succeeds in creating a creepy, disturbing atmosphere full of menace and dread. Also, there are precious few "gotcha" moments in the film. Rather than force you to turn away, the film wants you to stare, kind of attracted to what you see and kind of repulsed at the same time. I liked Radha Mitchell as the main heroine because she held my attention. Laurie Holden as the motorcycle cop with the heart of gold was equally captivating.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A young girl begins sleepwalking and saying the words "silent hill" before she awakens. The girl was adopted and originally lived in West Virginia. The mother does some research and finds out there is a town called Silent Hill in West Virginia and decides to take her daughter there to find a reason for the girl's problems. Silent Hill, it turns out is a dead town, consumed by an underground mine fire, and is fenced off from civilization. The mother is pulled over by a motorcycle cop who thinks she looks suspicious. The mother thinks the cop is suspicious herself and takes off. She blows through the fence and into Silent Hill, eventually crashing to a stop. When she comes to, her daughter is gone and she searches the ominous town for her. She eventually meets up with the cop again who also crashed her motorcycle and they find that Silent Hill is a very strange and haunted place. They are attacked by creatures made of fire and ash, they watch another creature kill a woman and end up in a church with a cult that follows the whims of one paranoid, deranged woman. The mother eventually faces the creature in the darkness and learns the secrets of the town and her adopted daughter.Silent Hill is a bad movie, mainly because it has no soul. The story, while odd, is not all together original and the movie depends too heavily on effects. Some of the effects are very cool, but meaningless as far as advancing the story. Also the story does not entirely make sense. Things happen that are never explained and the ending was confusing. The movie is too long for this type of film and the middle section gets pretty boring. A good actor, Sean Bean, is wasted with virtually nothing to do as the girl's father. I wasn't surprised to find out that this was adapted from a video game because with all the effects taking center stage you never get a real connection to the story.
summary: Cool effects, but no soul and doesn't make much sense
Title: N/A

reviewText: Silent Hill is a movie inspired by the video game of the same name.  The game came out on the original Sony Playstation console.  It was one of the first of the so-called "survival-horror" genre of games, which included Resident Evil and Parasite Eve.  The genres popularity, as well as the dominance of the Sony Playstation console, ensured that the movie already had a large fan base even before it opened.Chris and Rose DaSilva are concerned with their adopted daughter's sleepwalking habits.  During these episodes, Sharon keeps referring to "Slient Hill", a town in nearby West Virginia.  Rose then takes it upon herself to drive to Silent Hill, with Sharon in tow.  Miles outside of Silent Hill, she stops at a gas station.  While there, the attendant warns her not to proceed to the town.  Evidently, the town was evacuated many years before.  This is coal mine country.  Fire got started in the coal mines, deep beneath the town.  The fires continue to burn to this day, making Silent Hill a danger zone.Rose drives through the barricades and proceeds to the ghost town.  Meanwhile, a mysterious motorcycle police officer is in pursuit.  Rose swerves to avoid hitting a child, and runs off the road.  When she wakes up, Sharon is missing.  Rose starts to walk down the empty streets.  She meets up Dahlia, who informs her that she believe Sharon is actually Alessa.  With fog blanketing the town and ashes falling from the sky, Rose runs back to the car.  There, she meets up with Officer Cybil Bennett.  Together, they continue the search for Sharon.They learned that the town is not empty.  Silent Hill is populated by the members of a cult.  As darkness descends, they follow the members to the safety of a church.  While there, they are captured by the cult, led by the insane Christabella.  Slowly, the story of Silent Hill and Alessa begin to unfold.  Dahlia had a daughter out of wedlock.  Condemned by the town as an abomination, Alessa grew up without friends.  Other children tormented her, while the adults did not do anything to stop the bullying.  Christabella convinces Dahlia that the cult can help.  She proposes a ritual that would "cleanse" Alessa.  Dahlia agrees.  The cult takes Alessa into their church and straps her to an iron wheel.  Dahlia realizes too late that the cult intends to burn Alessa to death.  The cult proceeds with the ritual and sets Alessa aflame.  During the ritual, an explosion rocks the town.  The fire gets out of control.  Dahlia and the police arrive to stop the ritual.  Alessa, horribly burned but still alive, is taken to the hospital by Officer Gucci.  Alessa's anger and rage pulls the entire town into an alternate reality, created by her mind.  Her powers, fueled by anger and hate traps the town and the cult members into her dreamworld, filled with horrors.  Meanwhile, Alessa takes that part of her soul which is still good and manifests it into another child, Sharon.  Sharon is the "good" half of Alessa.Meanwhile, Chris arrives at the outskirts of town to look for his wife and daughter.  Stopped by the same Officer Gucci, Chris learns the tragic story of the town.  Unable to proceed into town, he then returns home.This is a very good horror movie.  Sean Bean, Radha Mitchell, Laurie Holden, Alice Kriege, Kim Coates, and Deborah Kara Unger make up the all-star cast.  Laurie Holden probably gave the best performance out of the group, playing the role of a dedicated police officer.  She plays the tough but very beautiful policewoman, Cybil Bennett.  Laurie Holden, with her short blonde hair and slender figure, looked sexy in her motorcycle policewoman's outfit.  Kim Coates was also very good as the compassionate Officer Gucci.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would never have guessed that this film was based on a video game--I certainly couldn't tell from the plot.  Then again I grew up with Pac-Man and Donkey Kong.  I loved this movie!!  I generally like more traditional horror flicks ("The Shining", "Jeepers Creepers") and have a tough time with some of the more recent films that jump all over the place with no explanation and nary a hint.  At first I had my doubts...but watching past the first 15 minutes revealed that this is one movie that didn't have to add in a bunch of unnecessary junk to make up for what it didn't have."Silent Hill" was a perfect balance for me, an unusual concept (a coal mining town sitting on top of a slow-burning fire, deserted--or is it?), and logical but not easy-to-guess conclusions to events.  Excellent unexpected effects!  Things done in new ways!  Creepy and wierd!  If you enjoy scaring yourself now and again to remind yourself how lucky we are that we aren't going through something spooky and unexplainable like this, here is a film just right for a night alone when you want to curl up on the couch with your trusty milkduds 'n' a beer and scare yourself silly :oClose the drapes ahead of time just in case there's something under the couch...and turn out the lights!
summary: This was Based on a Video Game? Excellent for Scaring yourself Silly!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have to say I was very impressed with how well this movie was executed at the start.  There are times when the visuals are so amazing that I actually got very excited and wished more movies could be like Silent Hill.  It generally has a decent pace working for it until about the last third.  Then it seems to become a tangle of plot explanation, dragging it slowly down and un-doing all that came before it.  The ending of the game version was far better I thought, but I suppose because this is a movie aimed at fitting the criteria of a film, the director, screenwriter and producers would have been broke if they had attempted to re-create the game entirely.  Honestly though, they hit all the deeply disturbing spots from anything and everything Silent Hill.  I was glad to see that this wasn't another sell-out to make it a PG-13 movie and simply reap the finances.  It is disturbing, very gory and should please any horror fan.  I wouldn't reccomend taking the little ones to this one.  There are some very dark, nightmarish sequences that would seriously scar them for a long time.For gamers who love this game, you'll like it I think.  Like I said, the ending is the only let down and it seemed like getting there was a bit painful.  The Pyraimd -Head was absolutely amazing.  Forget all of the garabge that both Resident Evil films were.  This one smokes them both.  It hits the atmosphere on the ball, it usese the music from the first three games and pulls you straight into Silent Hill, the nighmare world where two separate planes keep switching.Overall, I'd say 3.5 stars, just because for the writer and director to have pulled off the first 2/3 with such proficiency and effectiveness made me think they didn't put in their full effort to end it more effectively.  Plenty of people at the theater voiced their negative opinions quite loudly as the credits began to roll, but I knew better.  Most Americans expect the in-your-face-horror-movies like Saw or Hostel.  Silent Hill is more subtle, yet far more disturbing and much better done than any horror movie I have seen in a long time.  It's sad that people who saw this discarded the first two-thirds of the movie simply because they hated the ending.  I am able to appreciate, forgive and forget.  Hopefully the sequel will be a little better meditated on.If you like horror flicks, you'll be impressed by the music, gore and overall creepiness.  If you like the game, I'm sure you'll be as equally impressed.  If you don't like either, or you only have a very shallow understanding of horror, you will be disappointed and upset.  It's great on the big screen, but I don't see Silent Hill winning any awards.  If only Resident Evil could have been this good.
summary: First 2/3 well executed, last 1/3 could have been better

reviewText: Funnily enough, the one film people say is the best videogame adaptation is Mortal Kombat, directed by much-maligned(but not really by me) director Paul W.S Anderson, with the Resident Evil ones at least being "decent". The Tomb Raiders, Doom, and so on were just absolutely horrible. Well Christophe Gans, the one behind the Brotherhood of the Wolf, probably gives us the next best adaptation but ultimately fails in the same area the others have.Chris and Rose are dealing with the fact that their daughter Sharon sleepwalks. In her dazes, she mentions a place called Silent Hill, an old town in West Virginia. Wanting to get answers, Rose takes Sharon to Silent Hill. However, they find very disturbing and strange things that do more than bump in the night, and a cult of religious fanatics who are, for lack of a better phrase, hellbent on ridding the town of evil.Since it is a videogame adaptation, certain things in the story such as explanations are sacrificed for character and creep-out scenes. For example, besides a nasty looking janitor, what are the other creatures and how did they become to be that way? We have nurses, armless men, and soon-to-be everyone's favorite, Pyramid Head. Then there's just weirdness such as why would Chris and Rose live next to a cliff if Sharon sleepwalks? And why do the air-raid siren scenes happen at certain times then disappear.Then there's the banality in some of the dialogue. Characters come across a room that is visibly burned. "This looks like there was a fire here" says one of them. Ashes fall and leave a mark on a character's finger: "ashes" she says. Well gee, obviously! There was a bit too much references to the game that seemed kinda odd. A character finds clues or "puzzle pieces" let's say, which for some reason I started to say "you found the flashlight. Will you take the flashlight? You took the flashlight." There's even platform jumping and I thought "wrong genre guys".The film does however succeed on its atmosphere and sound design. Unlike Resident Evil, which went from a dark horror game to a well-lit combat movie, Silent Hill maintains the look and feel of the games which you haven't seen a lot in these adaptations. Then there's the sound design and music which perfectly matches what the games had, with weird atonal ambience mixed with light melancholy piano. While it's one of the few times a film matched its source material, the story still feels off like the others had.I think we can expect a double-dip soon. There's no commentary and we only have 6 featurettes which run roughly 10 minutes each. Not to mention there's behind the scenes stuff that you never saw in the movie such as the character's run-in with another armless men before going to a hotel. If you absolutely want Silent Hill then buy it but if you're one of those extras freaks like I am, then wait around a bit.It's not really a film for everyone. Best way to describe it is that if Resident Evil, Mortal Kombat and maybe the first Tomb Raider were at least passable to you then check this film out. But since this is better than something like Doom, Wing Commander or Super Mario Bros, you should also try it.
summary: Well at least we're getting somewhere...

reviewText: I'll be the first to admit, based on a video game or not, the plot of this film isnt very deep, and the ending is seen from a mile off, but the truth of the matter is, the visuals make up for all the failings. This film is visually stunning. I havent played the video game, so I dont know how it compares visually or storywise, but the camera movements, visual transitions and characters add enough of a creep factor to propel you past the thin storyline.Radha Mitchell puts in a great perfromance as the mother searching for her missing daughter, and Alice Krige is at her creepy best. The only drop in the acting is the woman who plays the cop, who's wooden perfromance reminded me of the crappy actress from "House of The Dead" everytime she was onscreen. I dont think she was actually AS bad, but, I felt biased.Overall, a very good film.

reviewText: I for one have let off many video games movies like ( Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat 1&2, Tomb Raider 1& 2, Resident Evil 1&2, and Doom. Exluding the work of Uwe Boll.) off with a warning for the longest time.  But now they should have figured something out by the time they got to Silent Hill, about what they been doing wrong with video game movies.  Though there are few moment here and there in the film, where you think the movie is about to get good but I just falls back on its ass once again. The final with the barb wire was pretty cool, but the rest of the end just sucked. The dialogue is just terrible. The performane are terrible. You don't care about none of the characters, because they don't develop at all in the movie ( with the exception of the girl Sharon). Now video game movies are here to stay, but they should put alot more effort into  how they make these kinds of movies now. Or perhaps they should just this kind of genre  a five year rest, and come back to it with a refreshed sense of thinking.
summary: Silent Hill Sucked!! And don't give me the acuse of you got to play the game to understand the movie, Neither.
