reviewText: Entirely forgettable film. Saw it last night and I left the theater completely indifferent towards the movie. 'Silent Hill' fails at nearly every single level except for style, sounds and visuals. Beyond that there's really no story to speak of, virtually non-existent or pointless dialogue, nonsensical actions by the main characters that contradicts otherwise logical behavior and there was a severe over reliance on CGI and special effects.Perhaps the biggest problem was the directing of the film.  I honestly don't think Gans is a bad director, but I do think he was wrong for this particular film. His style isn't suited for the 'Silent Hill' storyline, since any film based on those games call for probing into the human psyche, reaching the innermost, dark corners of the mind and leaving a haunting imprint that will genuinely scare the audience. The frantic pace and the action sequences worked perfectly for his best movie to date, 'Brotherhood of the Wolf', since its theme required it, but that was a completely wrong approach for 'Silent Hill' which needs to be slower paced, more emphasis on the scariness of silence, and a focus on what is not seen rather than the metaphorical big blunt object in plain sight.'Silent Hill' needed the type of psychological horror that masters like Hitchcock and M. Night Shyamalan can create, the quiet, subtle direction in which they take their films for maximum effect. Shyamalan would have been perfect for this film because he understands the concept of less is more and how to delve into our internal fears and exploit them on the big screen.  Gans on the other hand went for a by the numbers approach, throwing visuals and quantities of CGI at us, but all that was necessary was substance and quality and unfortunately that was sorely lacking.We should expect nothing less than much better than this and I do not buy into the mentality of "this is good enough" or "don't expect an Oscar worthy production".  A film does not have to be an Oscar contender in order to be entertaining or great, but there is no excuse for mediocrity.  It was a good try I'll admit but it overshoots way above par. Gans lacked focus, a sense of direction, he was all over the golf course with 'Silent Hill'. He needed to focus on shooting the ball into one hole at a time, not all 18.I mean honestly what is so difficult with sticking to the original material, sans a few minor liberal interpretations?  I honestly do not see why he would have to change it one bit, except for a detail or two. A Hitchcockian approach with the material from the games would have been perfect. Just imagine the director stringing the audience along with a few minor hints of horrors to come, rather than with the in your face approach that Gans used what seemed like every couple of minutes. Subtlety is the key, the movie acting as a puppet master with the audience, toying with what they see and think as opposed to blatantly telling what the audience should see and think. The shock and awe factor does zilch for me, it has been done too many times and there is no immediate nor lasting psychological effect. It screamed CGI, big whoop. Where is the genuine fear that the games gave people? That's what this movie was supposed to accomplish.Aren't the 'Silent Hill' games fun because the players are never sure exactly what is going on, and part of the fun is delving deeper into it to find out exactly what lies behind the curtain? What I have read about the games and what the movie should have been was not an amusement park house of horrors, instead it should have been good ol' fashioned mystery with horrors beyond imagination. I've seen 'Saw', it's cliche', I wanted something cerebral. I really do not think that is expecting too much.  It has been done before and could be done again with someone who understands the material and how to conceptualize it.Sean Bean's character might as well have phoned in his performance, which ironically wouldn't be all that different from what he accomplished. His part could have been effective but as it stands it was pointless.  Sean Bean is an excellent actor and perfect for this type of film, so why not fully utilize his talent and give him something solid to work with? His contributions went nowhere, quickly. They could easily have cut his part out and the film wouldn't have sufferend one iota.The female cop, who I liked initially, was unfortunately stricken with the stupidity syndrome.  For example, why oh why did she not follow the girl's mother down the elevator? What possible sense did it make for her to stand her ground against the cultists, with an empty gun no less? What did she hope to achieve by her sacrifice? I saw no reason why she shouldn't have followed the mother down the shaft.  The reason seemed that she wanted to sacrifice herself to save the mother, but they would have been better off working together as they did for a while, there was no logic behind it.  The mother had her idiotic moments as well. The car chase in which she escapes the police offer was ridiculous, and the arrest scene makes one wonder about her intelligence, as if she did not realize why she was being arrested.I have not played the games, but I should not have to in order to understand the plot or relate to the characters. Going into this film, I was expecting at the very least to be scared or shocked somewhat, but I was never frightened nor all that shocked. Once the writer and director decided to get rid of character development, the movie should compensate with scariness, but any genuinely scary moments were nonexistent.The film's job is to translate the concept into something that's palatable and relevant for the average movie goer, just as much as it is trying to stay true to its roots. 'Silent Hill' should stand on its own merits, video game background or not, that shouldn't really matter, but as it is, the film lacks the backbone of a classic horror film. It's quick, easy and entirely disposable.Who are these people? What do we know about them? Why should we care what happens to any of them? There is nothing revealed at any point that would make anyone care one way or the other as to what happens to a single character, other than simply on principle of the universal concept of a mother ferociously defending her child at all costs, but even that idea seemed like days old chinese food with too much MSG, given the manner in which it was presented.There were a few positive elements as I mentioned, such as the look of the monsters, the town, and the CGI was impressive albeit ineffective and anticlimactic. The sound and music was eerie and jarring, but after awhile it became passe' and without an effective plot and action sequences its use became redundant. The graphics were gratuitous however and way over the top, despite the realism of the computer graphics. I am not impressed by the shock factor of modern horror films since I've been there, done that, bought the t-shirt and taken the roller coaster ride far too many times.  This movie copies the same formula as 99% of other Hollywood horror films, with little to no originality.I sat through the whole movie waiting for something to engage me in the story, to pull me in and make me care for what happens to the parents and their child, but the film was too busy with too many things happening at once, so much so that any buildup that was started at some point was lost 5 seconds later with something inconsequential and irrelevant in terms of plot importance. The monsters were window dressing, little more than mannequins or wax dolls. Where was the exposition of the characters and the town itself?Just because the film is based on a video game that does not mean that the standard rules for film making goes out the window. Simplicity and authenticity are the two keys to a successful film based on video games. Less is more. It does not get any easier than that.An example that I have used in the past is 'Mortal Kombat' which captures the essence of the video games. It doesn't try too hard to do anything spectactular, it stays true to its source material and does not deviate and uses enough elements from the games with enough of the story to make the audience care about what happens, and it's simple enough for both fans and newcomers to appreciate, understand and be entertained by what happens on screen. Is it a great film, no, but it is a good film and it accomplishes what it sought to do, which was make an entertaining, fun film based on a series of popular video games, and hopefully translate that concept into a universal medium that is approachable to all audiences without straying too far from its root.'Silent Hill' is an overachiever that tried too hard to do too much in too little time and as a result it failed. It is better than many video game based films, but that is not really a compliment considering the genre.  The creators of 'Silent Hill' would have been better off focusing the film on the first game, rather than trying to put all games into one film.  I give the film 1 star for style and 1 for the soundtrack, but it loses out on substance and depth.

reviewText: FIRST AND FOREMOST...i've played and LOVE the games (and i prefer them IN ORDER from 1 to 4). ALSO,...i think the soundtracks by Akira Yamaoka are brilliant (i own them all).THAT BEING SAID...........this film IS somewhat disappointing (which is a shame because the opportunity for greatness really WAS there). IT IS "miles" better than those Resident Evil jokes (in fact...it really is THE BEST video-game-to-film adapation to date),...but it just never quite materializes as being consistently good from start to finish.this movie DOES have atmosphere.....and it has it NAILED. the sets are brilliant and VERY detailed. Radha Mitchell is superb (as she always is) and really seems to sink her teeth into this role.....but everything else is just VERY average. the story is convoluted and really seems to contradict the pyschological prisons that are SO prevelant in the games. the feeling of isolation that makes Silent Hill so unique is spoiled by an "Adams Family" type cult that preoccupies too much of the story. Rose's departures into the "alternate" Silent Hill aren't nearly dramatic enough (nor very well explained). Sean Bean's character is almost meaningless. ALSO,....(and i must reiterate that i am a HUGE fan of Akira Yamaoka and the Silent Hill game soundtracks) I MUST SAY that the music editing/arrangement for this film was absolutely horrible. it's almost as if someone deliberatly tried to superimpose a "best of Akira Yamaoka" mix over the entire film. many queues were completely inappropriate or poorly timed. i'd like to see the music score redone....perhaps focusing on ONE central theme and reproducing it very subtly. the "Akira's Greatest Hits" approach really ruined the atmosphere and lacked imagination.On the POSITIVE side,..there were plenty of interesting uses of lighting and camera angles (many of these will be familiar to players of the games). Most of the special effects were pretty good (particularly the physical transformation of the environment from real to "alternate"). HOWEVER,..things just seem a bit too "GRATUITOUS" at times,..as if too many elements from all the games were attempted to be squeezed into one film. I found myself shifting from my own "real-to-alternate" worlds as i was quite interested (and entertained) for 20 minutes and then bored-to-tears the next 20. ALL IN ALL it was a good try (it was certainly quite an undertaking) and while it DOES have it's moments,...Silent Hill just isn't quite the complete package.I'd have to rate this as a somewhat (at least for me) disappointing experience. maybe i should have just rented this dvd,....but,...well,...i already own all 4 games and all 4 soundtracks (plus a few bootlegs),..so i was BOUND to buy it anyway. watch it if you are a SERIOUS fan (but you are likely to be a bit annoyed). it ain't horrible but it ain't THAT good.p.s. Sean Bean,....you deserve better than this.p.s.s. Radha Mitchell,...you MADE this watchable...thanks.p.s.s.s. if you really want a good scare,...go see THE DESCENT.EDIT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!UPDATE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!i have watched the movie through for a SECOND time now. i must say that i liked it a bit better this time around. maybe it's because it IS a nice change of pace from the usual horror "fodder" we monster movie fans have to sift through on a weekly basis in order to find a good flick. Silent Hill attempts to adapt the video games (which are purely horrific psychological acid trips) into a film of similar complexity. it ulitmately falls a little bit short,..but the attempt is admirable. the first 45 minutes (or so) succeed pretty well. THEN the film bogs down in an overcomplicated script and fairly crappy dialogue. the music editing STILL bugged me in MANY places (not the fault of Yamaoka's work,..but of poorly timed/chosen queues). the dialogue was embarrassing in a few spots. "Pyramid Head" (for all the EMOTIONAL GRAVITY that he embellished in SH2) makes an uneccessarily gratuitous and completely unexplained appearance in the film. the nurses in Brookhaven Hospital are comical (looking more like extras in Robert Palmer's "Addicted To Love" video than the murderous carnivores in SH1). BUT......despite it's faults....it is still a "keeper" in my DVD collection. overall the "atmosphere" CARRIES this film home. i really would like to see a "re-edited" version of the film (both music AND footage).....but,...i guess we'll have to wait for Silent Hill 2 (NOW,..if Gans followed the story of THAT game "to the letter",..we might REALLY have something).i OFFICIALLY bump up my review to THREE AND THREE QUARTER STARS (3.75***).
summary: Atmosphere and Radha Mitchell....and not much else.........
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: Plain and simple `Silent Hill' is a beautiful horror film, beautiful in sense that the effects are top notch, the imagery is effective and the set pieces are out of this world.  That aside, `Silent Hill' tries a little to hard to make a drama out of a horror film.  I'm not against the idea of a horror film being a dramatic staple, but `Silent Hill' could never be that movie.  I saw an interview with Radha Mitchell before the film was released (Mitchell by the way does a wonderful acting job here even if it was unnecessary) and she was going on about how this is more than a horror movie, how it's about the maternal instincts of love and devotion to child and how the woman will do anything to save her child.  What really shocked me was that she looked sincere.I just want to make this very clear, this movie is about demons and satanic rituals and sacrifice and revenge...not about mother daughter time.  Yes, Rose (Mitchell) is struggling to find her lost daughter Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) but that's not our main concern while watching.  The story, as you may not be privy to, is about a young girl Sharon, adopted by her loving parents Rose and Christian (Sean Bean).  This young girl suffers from sleep walking, and in her dreams she utters the words "Silent Hill" so in an attempt to cure her daughter Rose drives her to the ghost town to confront the nightmare.Big mistake.  What happens next is a montage of disturbing scenes and the unraveling of a horrifying back story that explains (somewhat) what's going on.  A friend of mine whose played all of the games said they need to make a few sequels to really make more sense of it...I have only played the games sporadically and didn't really know much about it at all so I was left a little confused, yet not enough to where I was dumbfounded, I mean, you can figure it all out if you try hard enough.So anyone who's played the game will enjoy he masterpiece brought to life, and it's wonderfully done.  The demons are all scary and realistic, and there are plenty of jump sequences and eerie, creepy moments to salivate over, but it's not what it tries to be.

reviewText: Back in the late 90's we had been playing Resident Evil and Alone in the Dark for a while, and the horror fans of the world were already complaining that the game play had began to turn stale. We're always crying for innovation (especially in films, but I'll spare you that complaint.) Konami answered our cries for innovation by presenting us with a very different kind of horror in Silent Hill.Most horror games relied heavily on zombies, and quick "Boo... Ahh!" scare to get it's job done. Silent Hill didn't do that very often, but what it did do was expose you to extremely disturbing images, and monsters that defy any conventional explanation. Are they Demons? Are they undead? Or more disturbing, Silent Hill 3's "They look like monsters to you?"The best thing about Silent Hill was it's amazing story which revolved around a young woman named Alessa Gillespie who had extraordinary powers, powers, her mother Dahlia wanted to use to benefit the Cult of Samael. Everything that happened to Alessa was at the hands of her abusive mother, including being lit on fire. Dahlia even went so far as to misguide and trick Harry into working against Alessa who was trying to prevent the coming of Samael when Harry had to break a seal at a certain place and time where Alessa would be doing some sort of incantation, thus halting Alessa's progress... what I'm getting at is that it's true that in the Bad and Bad+ ending of Silent Hill Alessa was the end boss, however, and it is true that she was the root cause of the twisted world of Silent Hill. But, the witches, Dahlia, and the Order (AKA Cult of Samael) were indeed the bad guys, and in the ending I got Samael herself was the end boss. (I say her because of Silent Hill 3's revelations.)Silent Hill the movie starts off similarly enough to the game that for the first hour or so a fan of the game will indeed be at the edge of their seat waiting, and waiting, and waiting for the scares to come. People who haven't played the game may enjoy the story, and the visuals, but aren't likely going to be getting scared by this film either. Non-fans will say that they never got the impression that Rose was ever in any real danger. The moment death was at hand the enemies (Whether they be skinless demon children who now have eyes and mouths making them less creepy) or the infamous Pyramid Head (Originally a delusion by James Sunderland in Silent Hill 2) just dissolve the moment Rose is about to be killed, thus eliminating any real feeling of danger.Fans of the series can simply complain that Christophe Gans strayed too far from the original story. While he nailed most of the visuals dead on the plot doesn't seem Silent Hill like at all. For a while this film was code-named Centralia. I left this film wondering if the original story was going to be Centralia, but that Konami, who was seeking to do a Silent Hill film felt that the two were similar enough that they could both save some time and money by combining their efforts. This, if true, hurt the production. Silent Hill's original story could have saved this production, and or Centralia could have been saved by not limiting itself to the Silent Hill universe. If Gans wanted to do his own thing, he should have, instead I now have no way to present the original story that I love to my family members who don't play games, and I had talked this one up quite a bit.The first half of the movie, as I stated, is not scary, but is pretty cool nonetheless. Pyramid Head doesn't do anything uber-disturbing like his video game counterpart, but he does cause a really awesome fatality to one of the unimportant characters. Later on when the towns folks start screaming " a witch! A witch!" I found myself feeling nostalgic for Monty Python rather than the original Silent Hill. These movie folks need to stop straying for the original material.The story also starts out following the original plot closely enough but looses critical things like the hallucinogen that the Order was using, Dr. Huffman was nixed,  and although Nurse Garland makes a brief cameo her character is changed dramatically. As I stated earlier, the original plot didn't deal with Alessa being nearly killed by witch hunters, rather being subjected to abuse at the hands of the Order, and eventually suffering from being burnt alive by Dahlia, which is why in her room you see messages like "Mom... mom kill..." and "help me..." It's true that Alessa's soul was split up like in the movie, but Alessa lured Harry to Silent Hill to help her to defeat the cult of Samael, not for revenge against a bunch of witch hunters.Perhaps the biggest complaint I have about Silent Hill the movie is the ending. I know that Silent Hill spreads. It chooses who it wants, and when it will let people go. It's possible that Rose and Sharon were simply not yet allowed to leave, but many people felt that the ending meant that they had died in the car crash, similar to one of the bad endings in the original game. If this is the case, however, I do wonder how on earth Gans will follow this film up, especially since Alessa is the lead in Silent Hill 3. That's right, you play as Alessa. The bigger problem is that since the 6th Sense too many writers and directors think that the "Oh and at the end they're revealed to be dead" ending is still unique. If indeed that is the case here then, no Christophe, this is not a unique ending. It's another "me too" 6th Sense rip off. If there's more too it than that then it simply was not clear enough for the uninitiated.For Silent Hill fans it should be noted that although it nails most of the visuals dead on, the creepy feel of Silent Hill is lost, largely in part for Gan's silly "A Witch! A Witch!" replacement of the original story. Fans will likely feel, as I did, that the movie is very cool, especially visually, but will be disappointed that Gans strayed so far from the original plot, and that the monsters are under whelming, and even misused.One such example is the demon nurse sequence. The demon nurses work well in the game. One or two at a time the way they move is extremely creepy, but in a large group like this it looked to me like they would break out into the Thriller dance routine. It was silly, not scary. And Pyramid Head should have had a lot more to do with in this film.Non-fans will likely walk away with no clue what just happened or what made the game so great.Books and game adaptations do have to undergo some changes to make them work on film, and I understand that. However, pretty much every video game to film adaptation except Mortal Kombat has been absolutely terrible because they stray too far from the source material. Hollywood does their own thing, and then slaps a well-known label on it.But I have to ask, if the story from the game is good enough to make one want to do an adaptation, then why change the original premise? Silent Hill and Resident Evil have both nixed the original protagonists in favor of less interesting female leads. I felt more for Sean Bean's Christopher than I did for Rose. Rose was never in any real danger, Christopher was fighting loosing his entire family. That element of the film worked well on an emotional level. There is no good reason that Harry Mason needed to be replaced with a woman. None. Whatever excuses Gans throws out there the only reason this was done is because recent horror films have this idea that women should be the lead protagonists in all horror films, likely because they scream better than men. Fans of Lord of the Rings would have screamed bloody murder for this had Frodo been made a woman. I have nothing against women in lead roles. In fact, in original stories like the Ring or the Grudge I encourage it. But if the lead in the original story the film is based on is a weakly thirty-something male writer who is a widower with a sickly 7 year old girl it aught to stay that way. It is not okay to change the lead protagonist when adapting a book, the same reverence for source material that Hollywood has for novels needs to be extended toward video games as well.Simply put this movie would have been infinitely better had it stayed true to the original story, but like Resident Evil before it, it falls apart when it begins to stray. That said, unlike Resident Evil, this movie is still pretty cool based on its visual merits.With that said this movie is not un-enjoyable, and is the best video game adaptation since Mortal Kombat. Just don't expect anything super special, let alone scary.
summary: Cool but not scary, and not exactly true to the game

reviewText: In a word, "Frustrating"; as a film, it looks fantastic and in places it matches the surreal horror of the game perfectly (the introduction of the bile spewing walkers and the apocalyptic vistas of the ash enshrouded town on the edge of hell are highpoints) but it falls down due to a hackneyed script from Tarantino alumnus, Roger Avary, which eschews the ambiguity of the games in favour of your standard, over-the-top Hollywood histrionics. For instance, where the motivations of the protagonists that you guide in the games are often nebulous and opaque, here we're saddled with a stock 'loving mother who must *yawn* traverse the gates of hell in order to rescue her terminally ill daughter' character motivation from the outset, as well as plot points and themes that are not so much insinuated as sledge-hammered home to the point where you get the impression that the script may actually have been written by Phil Hartman's Frankenstein (Religion BAD! Mummy GOOD!). As a film, it also needed to be about 45 minutes shorter and not so obviously set up for a sequel. That said, Akira Yamaoka's atonal electronic soundtrack sounds splendid in a digital mix, Laurie Holden in a tight motorcycle cop uniform does wonders for the ardour and at least we should be grateful that Uwe Boll didn't get his hands on this one.  All in all, a missed opportunity.
summary: The Script Was Lost In The Mist...

reviewText: Well, it had nice cinematography. 'Silent Hill' started with some promise, and it had a good, creepy plot. However, all of that was squandered after the first ten minutes. I can understand how, since this movie is based off a popular series of video games, that the movie may have to be mostly action, since very few video games are story-driven. But, what we get here is a nice start with a tight, concise plot, and some creepy scenes, but once the movie moves itself to the town of Silent Hill, it becomes a stupid action movie, and the main plot dissapears. I have no problem with action movies, but my problem with this movie is that it's not scary, it's action is boring, the acting is bad, for the most part, and the set design is ugly. However, the cinematography was nice.The movie would have benefited from being cut by about a half hour, and most of that could have been action that was cut. On top of the bloated running time, the movie made no friggin' sense. It was basically a version of 'The Village' with elders that like to burn people. I came out of the movie not knowing what happened, and not really caring, since the movie was like a slap in the face and just as enjoyable. I can't begin to describe how poorly made this movie is. Strung together with pieces of film stock or something cheap, the movie looks like a college student made it. The camerawork was nice, and the town of Silent Hill was captured nicely, especially with the constant fog.While there are some creepy moments in the movie, they mostly involves sirens or flashlights. The movie came alive twice in the third act, and it was a saving grace...but not enough to make the movie good. In an extended sequence, barbed wire rips around a church, causing damage and eventually ripping people to pieces. In another scene, a flashback, we hear about a girl who was thought to be a witch, then burned. The scene is shot in a way that makes it look like a 1970's horror movie. But then the movie goes back to its extreme lack of just about everything.The plot has Rose (Radha Mitchell) taking her adopted daughter Sharon to the town of Silent Hill. Sharon has been screaming the name of the town in her sleep, and Rose thinks that taking her there will help her. Silent Hill was set ablaze several years ago by a coal fire that still burns underground. At times, the fire knocks out all electricity, and featurless zombies pop out. At least I think it was the fires causing this. This is about the amount of clarity in this film. The zombies that come out from said fires are naked and can hardly walk, possibly because they drip acid blood (in a more interesting moment in my viewing experience, some girl in the very back of the theater remarked "Look! It's on its period!") But later, it is revealed that, no, the monsters are not having their time of the month, but simply are just deformed miners caught in the blasts underground. I think.If you do see 'Silent Hill', which I do not endorse in any way whatsoever, then take head in my warning: DO NOT PAY FOR IT! Whether you have a free ticket to something like 'Ice Age' that you could care less about seeing, then use it to see this. But it would probably be better to do what I do whenever I am dissatisfied with a movie: sneak into another one and say it was that one that you payed for. This had a good plot and good actors that it could have put to good use, and the direction is flawless, but as it stands, 'Silent Hill' is an incomprehensible, poor, irresponsibly violent movie.Running Time: 126 MinutesMPAA Rating: R for strong horror violence/gore, disturbing images, and some language.
summary: Trek To 'Silent Hill': A Vacation You're Sure To Regret Paying For

reviewText: From the very beginning, there is a problem with the film -- we are never shown a "normal" world so we never really have the shock of the new -- or abnormal. A little girl sleep walks to the edge of a cliff -- very close to her home. She murmers "Silent Hill" so of course any good parent would drive off to the town --- but WHY? We're never told.After the child disappears in the town, you spent the next 45 minutes with the mother calling for her daughter. Yep. 45 minutes. "Sharon!" "Sharon!" "Sharon!"Some "real" and computer monsters chase her (for no reason, no explanation). It gets dark for some reason every 10 minutes. Lots of yelling and running around,Then the horrible and silly ending -- more screaming, barbed wire, "Burn the child! Keep the innocence!"Worst thing is we never care about any of the characters -- the mark of a lame film, horror or otherwise.If they would have made this a QUIET horror film -- like the game -- and cut out all the running around (that's in the game, but this is a movie) it could have been a terrific and scary horror/mystery.Stick with the game -- or rent SESSION 9!
summary: Too long, poor script, horrible & silly ending--stick with game

reviewText: Okay so some adopted girl sleep walks and says Silent Hill so the mother finds Silent Hill and decides to take her daughter there without the husband knowing about it. On her way there she gets pulled over but then for some odd reason she starts to speed away to Silent Hill with the cop chasing her. Once she gets there her daughter is missing so she teams up with the cop to try to find her. While there they run into monsters and a crazy cult of people who live in a church that keeps out the monsters. While all that is going on the husband tries to find his wife and daughter and he tries to uncover the mystery of Silent Hill.The good things about this film are that it has some good atmospheric moments through the film and the effects are also pretty cool to say the least. However I found there to be too may problems with this film like it goes on way too long. A film like this should only be 80 minutes long but this is 2 hours long, so it just drags out in some parts. I felt that like I had to force myself to watch it, which isn't something you should be doing with a horror film. Also the ending is kindda weird, I get it but I don't understand why it happens the way it does. It got out of control with the killings and effects towards the end when the girl gets her revenge on the cult.This movie does have some good parts to it but they don't make up for the rest of the movie so I would suggest that you see this movie without buying it if you feel the need to see this movie so bad. reviewText: This movie is kind of like a fart that won't come all the way out. You're left feeling like something more should have been accomplished. It's actually fun to watch (mostly) but they explain nothing, so it isn't worth the price of a purchase.This is a Supernatural Revenge film. I thought it would turn out to be more Mad Scientist (Monsanto labs, maybe). I was wrong.The beginning of the movie was rushed, so that everybody could get to Silent Hill. Should have been more focus on Sharon's dreams and pictures. Still, it did it's job.Stupid characters that have no point or are never explained: Exploding Acid Creature. Guy With Triangle Metal Head. Bugs. All the deformed creatures.Actually, the only characters (other than the main ones) who make any sense at all are the religious cult members. Thinking they were survivors of the Apocolypse, they live in Silent Hill.Well, after 30 years, why haven't any of them gone beyond the walls? Not one goes exploring? Hunting? Looking for food? One is shown scavenging, but there must be another food source. Cans on the hotel floor don't just appear Deus ex Machina after three decades.And since they mention that a boy is found in a mine shaft, and a cop finds him, there must be some contact from the outside. This is West Virginia coal-mining. I'm telling you, bored teenagers would have been all over that place. There would have been EPA involvement, something.The end was a big disappointment. Why aren't they home? Mission was accomplished, so what happened? Why are they in a miserable alternate dimension?Annoying.

reviewText: I have never played the game so I approached this film with a completely neutral mindset. I had not read any reviews of it, prior to seeing it either. For me this was a film from Cristopher Gans, the director of the remarkable and original 'Brotherhood Of The Wolf.' As such his most recent outing deserved my attention. And in a nutshell, I was not disappointed either.Silent Hill is taken from the game of the same title. The scenario is an abandoned town which sits in mountainous terrain and has been abandoned by its inhabitants because of the massive underground fires which are burning all around, perpetually fed by the subterranean coal seams. The sky is grey due to the smoke from these fires. In an eerie and stunning visual (which is disturbingly like scenes from Auschwitz) ash continuously falls from the sky like snow. The inhabitants of this town are a congregation of religious fanatics, totally in thrall to their maniacal leader (another superb performance from Alice Krige). These denizens have to contend with a darkness that falls intermittently across the town. The advent of this darkness falling is the eerie sound of a huge warning siren (another piece of WW2 imagery) that beckons anyone in the town, to race for the sanctuary of the town's church, the only place that can withstand the darkness. This darkness is home to all sorts of Lovecraftian monstrousities. These move slowly but with terrible purpose, and the fate of anyone caught by them is not a pleasant one...Into this hellish world come Rose and her daughter Sharon, the latter having been tormented by dreams of Silent Hill, a place that she has seemingly never visited. Rose is played by Radha Mitchell (the pilot in Pitch Black) who turns in another strong performance. Accompanying Rose is a female motorcycle cop whose initial suspicions regarding Rose and her daughter are quickly displaced by the desperate struggle for survival that both she and Rose have to undertake in Silent hill, all the while searching for the now missing Sharon. Rose learns that her daughter is the 'good' part of another girl - Alessa who was horribly burnt by Krige's bunch of fanatics for being 'evil'. The 'evil' part of Alessa has remained in te town and has become the demonic entity behind the darkness, all the time looking for revenge on her tormentors - Krige and her fanatical following.This is a film of stunningly surreal imagery and horror images that in my opinion are very Lovecraftian, in fact superbly so. The viewer is left with two possible scenarios for the Silent Hill existence:Firstly, Rose, Sharon, and Officer Bennett died when their vehicles crashed and that Silent Hill is some purgatorial plane between Heaven and Hell which also houses the spirits of Krige and her followers.Secondly that the town is another plane of existence and that Sharon, Rose, and Officer Bennet have all been summoned to by Alessa to be part of her final confontation with Krige and her cohorts.The otherwordly scenarios of both possibilties are underlined by the desperate and increasingly futile attempts of Rose's husband (played by Sean Bean)as he wanders round an empty Silent Hill with another policeman in tow, sensing his wife is near but never able to communicate with her. The film's final sequence only serves to underline this.Silent Hill is a film of imagination and stunning surreal imagery. Whether you are a fan of the games or like me just wish to see a very original horror film, then Cristopher Gans delivers in spades, superbly moving on from 'the Brotherhood Of The Wolf.'Highly recommended.
summary: Deserves more credit than it has been given

reviewText: When a young girl named Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) suffers from dangerous bouts of sleepwalking, her adopted mother Rose (Radha Mitchell) brings her to Silent Hill against the wishes of her husband Chris (Sean Bean). Drawn to the mysterious town by Sharon's dreams, they arrive to find that Silent Hill has been abandoned for many years due to an underground mine fire. Ignoring the warnings, they enter the town anyway, but Rose crashes her car and is knocked unconscious. She awakes to find that Sharon has disappeared, and Rose must venture through a town that seems to shift between alternate dimensions of ash-covered wasteland and rusted-metal nightmare, avoiding bizarre creatures along the way to find her daughter and uncover the truth behind the strange town.One thing has to be said about Silent Hill - it looks incredible. It perfectly captures the visual aesthetic of the video games that the film is based upon. Unfortunately, the story isn't as impressive. Like most movies made from a video game, the film's story seems to share passing similaririties with the game, but that's usually where the similarities end. The filmmakers typically decide to tell a different story, an approach that is understandable yet disappointing. Here, the film's plot seems weakly strung together, making it hard to follow for long stretches and leaving you wondering what is really going on. And to make matters worse, a huge chunk of exposition that finally explains everything is dropped like a bomb late in the film, leaving the storytelling feeling unbalanced.Another element that felt odd was the subplot of Chris' search for Rose and Sharon. He follows them to Silent Hill, but he never enters the town's alternate ash and rust dimensions, remaining in reality while finding hints and clues to Sharon's past and the town's dark history. Perhaps if the unraveling of the film's backstory was addressed in the main plot instead of the subplot, the film would feel more cohesive.One aspect of note is that the film's cast is largely female, from Rose, Sharon, police officer Cybil (Laurie Holden), and cult leader Christabella (Alice Krige). The male characters seem to be relegated to the subplot and feel unimportant. Not that there's anything wrong with a largely female cast, it just seems abnormal for a film based on a video game, where the target audience is comprised mostly by the young males who play the games. The lead characters in video games are typically male, since that makes it easier for the male players to identify with. There are the exceptions like Tomb Raider's Lara Croft, but those characters usually had the allure of sex appeal to go along with the role as the lead character. At no point are the characters in Silent Hill presented in a sexual manner, so its cast of largely female lead characters is rather unusual.In all, Silent Hill is a film that looks beautiful and tries to take its source material seriously though not strictly adhering to it, and for those reasons alone make it one of the better video game movies out there. But unfortunately, its loosely-weaved plot makes it difficult to follow and prevents the film from being one of the better horror films in recent memory.

reviewText: I am a HUGE fan of Christophe Gans ( he is not only from the same town in France as me, but I have been following his career since Crying Freeman and le pacte des loups), and am an even bigger addict of the Silent Hill games. I own all of them, as well as their soundtracks. I play them over and over again, and will continue to be a die hard fan for the rest of my life.With this beinmg said, there were certain elements of the movie that I did not like.For example, I LOVE how they did Pyramid head, but did not like the ( SPOILER) scene where he ripped the chick's skin off; Pyramid Head in the game is much more about presence than him actually being a slasher ( though he carries a mean sword). In the movie, it seemed like they just wanted some shock value and so put that seen in ( and the chick that plays the girl isn't that good).Also, the plot really does vary from the original game, and I did not like how Alyssa's mother was not the bad person, but was sort of 'gray' and not 'black'. Christabella was the villain ( and was well acted, and so was Deborah Ungar, but still). This was irritating, and on top of that the cult Christabella was a part of differs from the cult at the root of Silent Hill.Look, Radha mitchell was great, and the rest of the cast as well. But something was missing, and I think that it was because of how the script differed from the game.The scenary was fantastic, but they didn't visit many of the Silent Hill's many stores, historical points, etc.I just wish that the director would have encompassed all that I mentioned!
summary: GREAT director, GREAT cast, sort of shabby ending and change from the game

reviewText: Silent Hill has got to be the best video game movie yet.  It has what all video game movies should have.  Detail, atmosphere, story and characters from the game.  Every detail from the Silent Hill games have been taken into consideration.  The lighting, direction, cinematography and creature effects.  From the very beginning of the movie, references from the Silent Hill games are very noticeable.  The car journey, the crash, the missing daughter and the wondering into the haunted town to find clues.  The story is very basic and takes the plot directly from the first Silent Hill game.  The CGI and special effects I found were very good, with weird and horrible creatures looking very impressive.  Throughout, this movie is very entertaining and violent but far from scary.  The movie's soundtrack is very good as it sits perfectly with the tone and atmosphere of the movie.Overall, I would have liked this movie to be more frightening and eerie but its entertaining value still holds my attention with a good story and impressive laugh-out-loud climax.The critics have under rated this movie way too much, as they don't understand what Silent Hill is all about.  Thats because they have probably never heard or played the Silent Hill games before and judge this movie with confusion.  This is a good movie (not a great horror) and I enjoyed it.If your not a fan of Silent Hill games, you'll probably hate this but if you are a fan of Silent Hill, you'll love it.

reviewText: I liked this movie a lot. That may result from the fact that I am a big fan of the Silent Hill videogames. I also love this type of horror: weird monsters, bizarre nightmarish settings, and no logic to be found anywhere. The game was inspired by this type of horror: the works of H.P. Lovecraft, Clive Barker and Stephen King, Barker's Hellraiser, Wes Craven's Nightmare on Elm Street, Adrian Lyne's Jacob's Ladder and probably Italian goremasters such as Dario Argento and Lucio Fulci. So that's what you're in for with Silent Hill. You're either a fan of this type of stuff, or you're not. Personally, I love it. Give me monsters and creatures over serial killers and slashers any day. Surreal horror (or fantasy horror) is by far the most interesting horror subgenre to me.We have a very atmospheric, creepy, story-driven, very cinematic game which would seemingly be perfect for a movie adaptation. We have a director, Christophe Gans, who is a big fan of the game and downright passionate about making the movie. It would seem that the movie is in the right hands. However, the results are unfortunately very uneven. While unable to break the long-running videogame movie curse, Silent Hill stills ends up being a very worthwhile movie for certain viewers. That would be fans of the videogame and/or fans of surreal Clive Barker-esque horror. Director Gans has done a remarkable job. The movie looks amazing. The production design and cinematography are top-notch, recreating the look and feel of the game perfectly. The ash snowfall, the deserted streets, the ubiquitous fog, even the wild camera angles. In fact, the first half of Silent Hill is so good that the second half is immensely disappointing in comparison. I think the filmmakers got too concerned with faithfully adapting the game that they gave little consideration to plot and dialogue. As in the games, the story is oblique and often incomprehensible. However, what makes the movie worthwhile are the strong points: creepy atmosphere, awesome bizarre monsters and lots of blood and gore.However, as I said before the movie is far from perfect. Some of the dialogue is downright horrible, some of the acting is pretty bad, some of the CG effects are less than stellar, and of course the story makes very little sense. For me, those flaws did not detract from the viewing experience. I still enjoyed the movie immensely because of what it gets right. Some will be able to overlook the many flaws and enjoy the good stuff, others won't and will probably hate the movie. A lot of viewers will probably leave the movie saying "What the @#$*?" But at most, Silent Hill should (like the game) find a devoted cult following. I really want to see a sequel, because there is so much potential here that the movie didn't quite live up to and I would love to see more monsters, more Pyramid Head and more Darkness. Hopefully the sequel will correct the first movie's flaws. I do hope that Christophe Gans will return for the second film and hopefully, with a better script, it will live up to the enormous potential of the game's concept. But until then I will just enjoy the movie. I am very much looking forward to the DVD release.So for fans of the game, do check out the movie. For fans of surreal fantasy-horror, check it out. Anyone else may want to proceed with caution.
summary: Creepy, bizarre, and twisted... yet very flawed

reviewText: Being a big fan of video games and horror/thriller movies in general I was looking forward to seeing this. Just from the trailer and set shots I had seen it looked like it was turning out to be a great film.After seeing it last night I can say I was not dissapointed. It's been awhile since I played the games but it was amazing just how many little details, camera angles and such I remember from the game that were translated into the movie.The performers they hired to do the nurses and those other creatures (the ones that look like they are trying to break out of their own skin, its been awhile can't remember their names) did a great job in mimicking the movements of their videogame counterparts. Pyramid Head was also extremely cool and well done.The only thing I would have changed would be to lessen the amount of screen time for Sean Bean's character and devote more to Silent Hill/Darkness scenes. But I understand that is character was a good way to help viewers who were not fans of the video game understant a bit about the 'Multiple' Silent Hills.All in all great film and definately the best video game adaption yet. Those who have not played the video games may feel a bit confused about things in the movie, but those who have played the games will likely come out very satisfied.Silent Hill opened in nearly 3,000 theatres. Let's hope it does well enough for a sequel, this moving is definately deserving of one.

reviewText: First of all, I would like to say that I love bad horror movies. After seeing the second movie I was expecting this movie to be just as bad, but it wasn't. This movie actually had some things going for it.The Good:The camera work is superb, I never really felt like it was awkward or bad in any way.The acting is, for the most part, very good. I felt like the main actors really got into their roles and played them to the best of their abilities.The CGI is very good. When the town falls under darkness I really enjoyed seeing the walls flake away.The monsters, especially Pyramid Head, are very nicely done and help withthe atmosphere, which was also very nice for the first half of the movie. Even though this is a short movie I was (at first) able to believe that there was more to Silent Hill than I was seeing onscreen.The Bad:The writing is...well...if you've seen it you'll get what I mean even though it might not have occurred you. The writing consistently plays the victim of plot convenience. The first time our main character encounters monsters, she has the opportunity to run away but gets confused and runs the wrong way. She then stumbles as the monsters converge on her, but wait! It just so happens that the monsters just disappear! This happens every single time the main characters get into a major situation in this movie. The monsters trap them, but then they disappear because that's what happens. They never fully explain this either. All we know by the end of the movie is that some form of praying to an unidentified god by some random cult happens and then the bad stuff just disappears, though even this isn't fully put together for us. This doesn't help the atmosphere later in the movie either, since once we know that the darkness doesn't have a very good explanation it just feels random and un-scary. More on the plot conveniences below.I'm not sure if I could classify this one as monsters or camera work, so I'm just going to call it catering to fanboys in the wrong way. Anyone who knows anything about Silent Hill knows that Silent Hill was scary because of that "I wonder if something is behind me" sort of feeling it gives you at all times. This movie seems to take this approach at first, but then just leaves it in the dust. The only genuinely scary part of the film is a part where our protagonist, Rose, locks herself in a bathroom and finds a dead guy in a bathroom stall. I won't say what happens, but the atmosphere is tremendous. It then screws this great atmosphere over only a minute later! A monster appears, and while this in itself is great, the camera stays focused on the monster repeatedly. The camera angles themselves were fantastic, but the protagonist just stands there and looks at it so that the writers can cater to Silent Hill fanboys by keeping a "scary" monster on screen. Rose then just runs out the door (that was just locked?) and leaves. It's not that hard guys! Just quickly show the monster (not showing us what it looks like in detail so that we are even more scared of what it might be), give us a sense that she is being chased by it, and make us really scared with those great camera angles that you keep using! Simple!This movie also sports the most useless character in any movie I have ever seen: the cop. Notice that I did not say she was a forgettable character, but that she was just completely useless. She is literally forced into the plot on many occasions and near the end does some of the most stupid things imaginable. She notices Rose's car at a gas station and sees her daughter inside of it. She asks Rose is everything is okay. Then she doesn't just follow Rose to Silent Hill, she tries to pull her over on the way there! WHY? This is never explained and all we know from this point is that the cop doesn't like Rose, until she does like Rose, and then she conveniently likes Rose. Even if Rose had just met her, and then the cop just found her suspicious and followed her to Silent Hill that would be better. But there was literally no reason to forced her into the plot the way the writers did. The only thing she does in the whole movie that is worth anything is when she pulls Rose out of the way of the darkness when Rose was (conveniently) to stupid to move out of the way. She crashes her police motorcycle and receives only a small scratch above the eye (this might sound silly, but if you watch the movie you'll see how stupid this is based on the MASSIVE headgear she is wearing on her head) and she isn't hurt otherwise. She also gets acid sprayed all over her front, and even though she takes off her headgear and nice leather jacket (just because it's a leather jacket doesn't mean that a motorcycle crash wouldn't damage it...) but her face just lucky avoided the acid (that was everywhere around her face...).  She later easily fights off three cultists, before (conveniently) not being able to fight well anymore. I'm not even joking. She doesn't just take a hit to the face and get disorientated or something, she just pulls the most USELESS "I'll stay behind" move I've ever seen, and then (conveniently) loses both the desire and ability to fight. WHY? She doesn't even slow the cultists down because THEY WEREN'T EVEN ABLE TO CHASE ROSE!I think I've said enough. This movie suffers from an extreme case of plot convenience and really doesn't make sense in a lot of places. It really kills the atmosphere later in the movie and it's a shame that the writers decided to continue the same story line in the newer one.

reviewText: For someone that hadn't even heard of Silent Hill (GASP!) until after the movie, I found it to be very impressive; both in its setup and in the execution.Since this review is based off just seeing the movie and not knowing which characters, lines, plot points, et al were part of the original game or the sequels; fanboys and gamers alike-please bear with me.The story starts off as most horror movies of today start..a strange raven haired child scares the bejeezus out of their parents as they wonder just what is going on.  Mumbling about "Silent Hill" near a very treacherous waterfall certainly is enough to bring Radha Mitchell and an extremely miscast (and underused) Sean Bean at ends with each other in how their adopted daughter is to be treated.After a few internet searches (does anyone still use Yahoo! or MSN for their internet scouring anymore?) Radha comes to a story describing the tragedy in Silent Hill, WV.  Going there, she hopes, will bring her daughter out of the "New Millenium Creepy Child character trait" funk.It doesn't.  We start, then further treading down the same "New Millenium Creepy Child character" path...chasing a girl that doesn't talk, but darts in and out of dilapidated, rundown rooms and condemned buildings.  All the while, the exasperated parent vainly looks for them.The female police officer is wearing the tightest leather outfit I've ever seen without having to pay a cover charge and listening to Emo or KMFDM all night.  My first thought?  Whoa..Joan Jett is in here!  :)  Alas, it wasn't.  Unfortunately, she's tied to a stake and made to feel like the other side of a human pig roast.Silent Hill is creepy.  Intensely creepy.  The sirens are fantastically eerie...Definitely something you don't want to hear in real life. The monsters-especially Triangle Head-are straight out of a Lovecraft/Dali dream montage; or at least from a Wes Carpenter movie.**SPOILERS AHEAD**By the time Alice Krige (the busiest plain jane in movies) hits the screen, the plot starts sliding to a videogame plot (memorize the floorplan, defeat the monster in his lair), which pretty much means all hell is going to break loose.  It had me until the time the cop was accused of being a witch.  After that, the reveal (done as a very effective set of flashbacks) is little more than a revenge story; which tends to lose it's credibility to some extent.  Again, as someone that wasn't familiar with the games, it was fun to know that a lot of the beasties and clues were taken directly from the games.Not many movies adapted from other media (books, videogames, Podcasts) are going to be as faithful as fanboys would like.  Think if George Lucas had published the Star Wars episodes as books prior to 1977.  Remember..Han Solo was supposed to be a cross between Greedo and Chewy, if I remember right."Silent Hill" certainly has my attention and I will definitely be placing the DVD on my Christma...er, sorry, Winter Solstice Holiday Wish List...  It's worth a money for a rental and perhaps a purchase as maybe (I hope) an audio reference disc.

reviewText: I never thought I'd be one to give this movie a bad review, because I usually love everything. But it is true, the movie just boring. From the trailers, the movie looks to be a really creepy and a very good game movie, but it just turns out to be slow and some what confusing.Indeed, they did a good job at having the right mosters and special effects, but the story itself is just so dull. Everyone I was with, including myself, was ready to leave after the first hour. It has a bad problem of dragging, the movie just seems to go on and on and on. It felt like it went on about 30 minutes too long.The acting is great for the script that they have, and some actors that I really enjoy. Sean Bean was great as the husband, but his role could have been played by anyone. They just didn't take him to his full advantage, but for as long as he was on, he was great. Being a Trek fan, I was happy to see the villain was played by actrees Alice Krige, who is the Borg Queen on Star Trek First Contact and Voyager.But like I said, the special effects are good. Not really great, some parts could have been better but it was enjoyable. For those who have never played the games may be confused by some of the things going on. Even I found myself confused in some places. Overall, the movie has good special effects and great actors/actresses, but it really lacks in story and is nothing but dull and confusing.

reviewText: I am wary to purchase this film. Why? Because it has "Unrated Version" written all over it (it's invisible but I swear I see it) and I would hate to purchase this edition only to have an alternate version soon available.That said...This is a scary movie. There is no way around that fact. The film does deliver on the heebie-jeebies. For proof of this look no further than the burning babies in the dark alley. They had a eerie shriek and their relentless chase after the heroine was just down right creepy. Even knowing that she was the central character of the story did not take away from the overall "frightfest" those demonic infants had.But... there is more. Even for his short amount of screen time... Pyramid Head ruled when it came to delivering the dread. Seeing that deformity carrying around the sword bigger than my mamma and surrounded by all those bugs was nothing short of heart stopping. In reality, if something like that was after me... I'd be a wreck for sure.Then there were the faceless nurses. They were evil, creepy, and sexy to boot. Some guys wouldn't mind being trapped in a room with nurses like that... though, once the lights go on and they go all "violent" I'm sure a different tune would be sung.Of course, there were some downer moments as well. The little girl, when in evil mode, was just unconvincing. The "other people" in Silent Hill were too dirty and dark to not give the lead doubts about their mental status. She became too trusting of them too fast... as where I would have been more wary; afterall, everyhting else in Silent Hill had proven to be evil. Add to that the ending which left me saying "Huh?" instead of "Oh..." Although the climatic showdown was something you would see in a hellraiser movie... (now that was entertaining)So... I would wait just a little bit to see if there is indeed an unrated version on its way before spending the bucks on this one. Part of me expects it to happen (afterall they did not make much money from it in theaters) so I'm going to hold out and see what happens.

reviewText: I'll mention up front that I've not actually played any of the 'Silent Hill' games.  This will doubtless make many of you think my opinions is irrelevant.  I understand your concern:  Seeing this film w/o playing the games I'm all too likely to judge it on it's own merits rather than just fawning over the fact that a game I like has been made into a movie.  And, contrary to what you may have heard, this film is plenty easy to understand w/o having played any of the games.  I suppose it could be said that the film doesn't entirely make sense, meaning that the explanations don't necessarily jibe logically with what we've been shown, but the connection we are supposed to make is generally obvious.  More to the point, I don't really give much of a damn if my horror movies make sense as long as it's got the individual horror scenes down well enough that I don't bother to look at the big picture.  Sadly, 'Silent Hill' fails in this respect, and wastes a lot of time and effort on a dull, hopelessly muddled script.I should also say that whoever put together the trailer for this movie totally deserves to win the Golden Trailer award, or whatever it is.  Nowadays the trailer making industry is in dire straits, with even good films usually having lame, distasteful trailers.  Conversely, the trailer for 'Silent Hill' actually made the film look like it had potential, and that it might actually be *gasp* good.  The 'Silent Hill' trailer is helped by the fact that it doesn't insist on showing us everything in the movie, focusing on the introductory parts of the film.  This points to how the trailer was able to trick me into thinking the movie might be good:  The introduction to the film is actually well done.  The set design is brilliant, the cinematography  quite gorgeous and the basic premise, while not utterly original, is intriguing enough.  It's the old mysterious, abandoned town premise, but that's always been one of my favorite horror setups, and this one is particularly well done, with some extra nice touches.  (Such as how the fog-thick abandoned town is near an ever-burning fire, which makes ash continually fall from the sky like snow.)Anyway, the film primarily involves Rose and her adopted daughter Sharon.  Now Sharon is a bit of a loon as far as little kids go, constantly sleepwalking and muttering about a town called Silent Hill.  Oddly enough, Rose decides to cure her of her ailment by finding this town, and, I dunno, wandering around there for a while.  Needless to say, there is a dark history behind the ghost  town (HA!), and bad stuff goes down when they arrive there.Basically, Rose and Sharon arrive there along with a lady cop who has been on their trail, and Sharon disappears, leaving Rose to wander around for the next hour or so.  Again, the opening scenes in the town are powerfully atmospheric, and the early encounters with the strange, humanoid creatures that live there are fairly good, but at about the 45 minute mark things start to fall apart.  It's really quite remarkable, how from that point on the film gets almost continually worse, until we arrive at the tediously overlong expository flashback stuffed late in the film and finally the tragically weak climax.Again, the film is severely hampered by the lame script.  The dialogue is nothing but cliches and banalities.  (I might as well cite the two particular lines that always get mentioned:  "Something terrible happened here", and "There must've been a fire" [said upon entering a burnt-out husk of a building].  Those may not be the exact lines, but you get the gist of it.  Rest assured, the movie is packed with junk like that.  More significantly, the script has got no sense of pace to it and the various explanations to the horror prove far too mundane considering the setup.  The pacing problems come from the general lack of occurrence between the midpoint of the film and the climax.  We just have things explained to us, uninteresting things, many of which are already known by the audience.  Furthermore, there is a subplot involving Rose's husbands attempt to track her down which is unnecessarily drawn out and poorly intergrated into the central narrative.Alright, now just a few random gripes:  Pyramid Head = Lame.  No other way to put it.  Crazy Lady played by Alice Krige = Way silly and over the top.  Also, this film works on the whole evil/scary child angle, and it just can't pull it off, and if you mess that up you look really silly.  And, ooh, don't get me started about the horrible CGI gore.  I never much care for CGI gore, but this is easily the worst I've seen in a film that actually got a theatrical release.  This is particularly prominent in the terrible, overblown finale.  It's just stupid, formless CGI spectacle, further weakened by the fact that the main characters of the film are generally on the sideline of the situation, so it barely even matters to us what is going on.  (Well, this would matter if we actually cared about these characters, anyway.)  Finally, most of the horror scenes are curiously unaffecting.  I don't even mean that they aren't scary, though they aren't, but they don't even really connect with the viewer on any level, and lack any intensity at all.  They're just a mild curiosity.  (Again, this less true of the earlier horror scenes, but it's never more than mildly unnerving.)Anyway, I can't say I wasn't more or less entertained by the film, but I'm just easily entertained.  It's got its moments, yeah, but it all comes together as a whole lotta nothin'.Grade: C-(P.S.  One last note, I did like how at one point Rose basically collapses on the ground and cries for a while.  People don't do that nearly enough in horror movies.)

reviewText: This movie feels sloppy, the pacing the editing. It's like the director filmed way more than what made it into the final cut and lots of scenes were trimmed, or the editor was given bad direction from the director, or the editor just sucks. The movie is choppy, goes from being slow and drawn out to crammed with content. It seems like a three hour movie or couple of episodes of a show smashed into a two hour slot. Some of the visuals are really good, some not so much. The acting is not great, the story is convoluted and only makes sense in about the last 20 minutes of the movie at which point I felt unmoved since I didn't care about any of the characters. There is no beginning to this movie, it just starts and not much is explained like you are starting the second episode of a tv show having missed the first episode. Just not a very good movie, and yet it's still better than most video game movies. On Blu-Ray it looks really good. Since a lot of the film is dark, the black levels are deep and never murky, most shots are crisp in detail and when color is used, its vibrant and looks really good. The movie looks better than it is, the sequel does look better but I just can't imagine doing more with this series. Christophe Gans did an amazing job with  Brotherhood Of The Wolf and his upcoming Beauty And The Beast should be really good as well. Unfortunately his attempt at a Hollywood film is a bit flaccid and I can only assume those Hollywood Dougs had a big influence on the script and final cut of the film. For a horror film, the only thing that is scary is the terrible story this movie tells and is rivaled only by the flat acting.
summary: Sloppy, but better than most video game movies

reviewText: Very rare is the case when game adaptations become good movie but so is the case with "Silent Hill".  A plot that revolves around an estranged couple Rose Christopher Da Silva (Sean Bean) both at different ends in how to care their sick daughter.  Ask for the comments that males were an afterthougth well there is a lot of testosterone in "Silent Hill" Cybil Bennett, the cop , is very a tomboy figure.  Rose herself often acts irrationally without thinking and breaking the rules.  Contrary to the belief of a few minority Silent Hill is a combination of male and female characters.Now as for the differences in the game, I've played the whole series from beginning to end including the first game and while there are differences the movie does remain pretty faithful  to the game. In the game Harry Mason was the lead, in the movie Rose was in the lead and looking for her missing daughter. The setup is also the same, Silent Hill has been abandoned for years but a portal of reality is now inhibited by monsters , evil spirits and other abominations. Equally the setup of atmosphere will be very familiar to game fans. The town is depicted as cold, gritty, snowy,  mysterious and evil.  There are  a lot of dark and grainy scenes that serve as a good hint that something horrible is about to come on screen followed by a lot of shrieks and high pitch squeals to add to the mayhem!!! There are classic horror gags as well like when Cybil being approached by the limbless zombies of Silent Hill is still laughing barking out orders hoping they'll stop coming after her.Acting wise everyone was pretty solid here. I would have loved to see more of Sean Bean whose a  great actor but Radha does a good job especially for the fact that she mainly plays unmemorable supporting roles in movies led by leading actors.  Jodelle Ferland is great as Sharon Silva and her alter ego Alessa.Of course you don't have to be familiar with the game to love the movie, the movie has classic horror elements and angles that will make everything pretty familiar but of course you gain a great appreciation if knowing the game you'd see that French Director Christopher Christophe Gans did not let fans of the game down. That's the biggest bottom line after all the hype a lot of fans expected this to be another catastrophic piece of garbage like all of Uwe Boll's movie but thank God it did not. All in all "Silent Hill" is a welcome surprise to some of the poor game adaptations out there.
summary: The Konami hit becomes a movie with great results

reviewText: First with regard to Blu-Ray, I suspect the above reviewer was using an inferior television.  The picture was sharp and superb almost to the point of distraction sometimes, but I suppose that's the point of using Blu-Ray.As for the movie, when I saw it had Radha Mitchell (from Pitch Black) and Sean Bean I knew that this would not be a standard shocker, and I was not disappointed.The movie throws subtle clues about what's going on to accumulate and fall together at the end for a touching and rewarding 'wow'.  This movie stuck with me through the night after I watched it and put all the pieces together neatly with appreciation for the writing as well as the directing and acting.I'm extremely pleased I waited for this movie to come out on blu-ray before I saw it, too.

reviewText: Silent Hill has a lot of great special effects - which saves it from being a total waste of time. The story centers around a woman searching for clues to her adopted daughter's origins in an abandoned mining town called "Silent Hill".The movie takes the viewer on a tour of the wraith - filled town, that periodically morphs into a Hellish nightmare. The special effects are very interesting but the film does not have a cohesive ending and sputters to an confusing conclusion.Silent Hill is not an awful film, but it is not a great film either.

reviewText: I got to say this is one of the best movie of 2006 and my personal favorite.  It has been a bland year for movies, except for what happen in Silent Hill.  I won't give away any plots/ spoilers in this review, that for the viewers to enjoy.  How to describe this movie without giving away too much favors or details?  How about the bizarre and creepy feeling when you first watched the "the Ring".  The survive horror of "28 days".  The "what is going on factor" of Mulhlland Dr.  An independence directing style of an Indies type movie with a touch of "12 Monkeys."The mood of the movie starts slowly and keep you wondering throughout the film.  I though the acting was perfect, maybe the motorcycle policewoman character is questionable.  I glad there were no superstar actors/actresses that stood out.  Silent Hill would not work with overacting actors, which would take away from the mood of the storyline.  The background music and scenes were great; it felt like being in a dream or some parallel universe.  The actions really balance out with the mood of the story.  There are no cheesy or Hollywood's cool styles directing here.  I could see why some conservative movies goers and religious fanatics might give this a low ranking.For gamers-This is the best game to movie adaptation so far.  A 6 out of 5 for this standard.  More like movie to game adaptation.  Jolie did great for Tomb Raider, but that was really simple minded more base on a lead character.  Resident Evil's movies should have been more like Silent Hill with more actions, but those were way too cheesy.  Mario, Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat, D&D;, Doom were all really silly, but not Silent Hill.  They really did a great job of pulling scenes and enemies from all the Silent Hill games in the series and mixing them in so well.  Watching this movie was like playing the game over again.  The "what?" and "what next?" factors were prevalent throughout this flick.This is a very enjoyable movie and the best I have seen this year.  The next Silent Hill movie would have a tough act to follow, if there is any.
