reviewText: Silent Hill, what can I say. I was waiting for this movie to come out and blow my mind just like the games did, but instead, I stumbled upon that euphoria in another movie entitled "Containment." That's a different story, however. I was under the impression that Silent Hill was going to be a classic, but once I saw it, I see where it falls short. Yet, it strives to make up for what it lacks with a crisp world and a true-to-game representation of this abandoned little town with a ghastly secret.The game left a lot of the plot up to the imagination, but being a game, each player has his/her own player story anyhow. The movie tried to do the same, but failed in this area, because in a movie you follow the character, in a game, you are the character. We need sustenance! The movie would've been much more enticing had it teased my brain, and then tricked it, but gave me something solid to hold onto after it's over. That's what will make it memorable. Twist the ending, but explain it at some point during the film. Otherwise you'll leave the audience to wonder what happened, rather then revel in what could've been.But, overall, it wasn't a bad movie. There were lots of cinematic elements at work that covered up any misshapen plot holes and poor dialogue. In my opinion it's still worthy of a classic title, just not in the way I had originally imagined. So what all worked to the films benefit, and what brought it down?Atmosphere and camera work- Obviously as you've well heard by now, the visual representation of Silent Hill is ecstatic. It is probably the most accurate and most thrilling game to film atmosphere to date. If you simply wanted to experience Silent Hill in all of its creepy visual glory, then this film would be a must see. The visuals alone and the excellent camera work almost make this film a classic as is, and certainly make it one of the most intensely artistic horror films of all time. I do wish more producers would devote this kind of time and funding to their atmospheres.Blood and violence- I think that Silent Hill did extremely well with this aspect of the film. Although the game listed some severe horror-scapes that didn't seem to be present in the film, I was generally satisfied with the proper amount of blood and gore. I will admit that I missed the scenes from the game, dripping with mutilated dead bodies strung up between wire mesh and other metal objects. The film included a few of these scenes, but probably chose to remove much of it for rating purposes.Plot- Now I know the game surfaced on a simple plot where you wreck your car and loose your daughter in this strange town, only to find out that it's overrun by a strange cult, which has the town under a grotesque plague...But the film barely managed to expand on this. Simple plots are great for games, but not movies. In-fact, you know it was either too complex, or too simple when you run through a door and enter into a bright light only to be greeted by the voice of a child, who blatantly explains the entire surface plot, and that was about all the further it went. The main character didn't even really discover anything. It was really a 2D plot, with no deep grounds for something 3 dimensional, something that allowed the audience to dig deeper into the film for meaning beyond the basic plot. You could try to dig in deeper, but at the same time, you wouldn't get much further than the surface, even with that mysterious ending.The characters- The game had characters of complex and different archetypes, which helped lead the main character through this strange little town. The movie had a slew of insignificant supporting roles compiled to simply set up the film and further the plot in any stage of events. The characters, excluding the mother and daughter, never seem to grow and change within the film. None of them, except Cybil and the mother even seems to complete a full character arch. This in turn makes them seem a little less human, more like zombies. However, they managed to include most of the key characters in the game, and at least provide them with some placement and importance with regard to the plotline. And in relation to the creatures.....(expletive deleted) I wanted more! They should've run to the police station, loaded up on mythical weapons, and rode the "action genre" wave for at least a mile. The game was all about killing those awesome creatures; the film was all about the atmosphere. I think we can all agree that it would've been much more exhilarating with the static from the cell phone resonating around every corner with enough creatures to build a small third-world country, and enough fire-power to take it down.Acting and dialog- Of course in a film with this type of budget, and a well-established director attached to it, we know the acting is going to be superb. I think it flew in a lot of ways, but there were a few instances where the characters crashed and burned. I'm not sure if it was just scripted poorly, or the actors were at fault, but the roles were tough-enough as-is. However, it should be mentioned again, although every review had the same note; the dialog is lacking. There are some attempts to make it philosophical and other-worldly, but in the end, it's basic. It doesn't bring you into the same type of deep thought and conversation that the Matrix slapped you with and made you question your own existence. Maybe it just wasn't supposed to be that kind of film, but again, we go back to the surface plot, and the dialog never strays from the basics of human interaction.In the end, I feel that Silent Hill was a good movie. It was definitely worth seeing in the theatre if you got the chance, and I am sure going to buy the DVD at some point. Being a fan of the game (I own the entire series), it definitely excels in some areas and falls short in others. With the addition of a few changes, it would've been an instant classic, but I feel it might just fall short. In any case, it's worth seeing, and you won't be disappointed by the set-work.
summary: Silent Hill is your worst fear....

reviewText: "Silent Hill" is about a woman, Rose, who loses her adopted child in an alternate reality of a town called "Silent Hill".  The audience moves along with Rose in her search for her daughter and experiences with her the supposedly hellish remains of Silent Hill.  Big on special effects and small on plot, "Silent Hill" is an over the top mess that is so far-fetched and lacking in discipline that the experienced horror movie fan loses interest by movie's end.  At first, it seems like "Silent Hill" is a nice concept, but the movie does not know what to do with itself.  The result is a maze of barbed wire, cages, and silly special effects which drown the movie in its own vomit.  Stylish movies like Dario Argento's "Suspiria" and "Inferno" are able to pull off the style over substance technique attempted in "Silent Hill", but "Silent Hill" ultimately has no style and completely fails in this regard.  Moreover, the manifestations used in "Silent Hill" are overdone, overused and essentially comical, indicative of an expressive yet sloppy and heartless attempt at a horror movie which mistakenly and ironically banks on its incoherentness to save the day.  One-half of a star for the concept and the special effects, and while special effects really aren't my thing, I find them especially annoying when the movie has nothing to hang its hat on at the end of the day, and is executed as badly as "Silent Hill" was.  Stream of consciousness is one thing...stream of rubbish is another.

reviewText: Yes this is one of those movies based on a video game, so what?.. Almost all the movies are based on books, which is basically someone imagination. I would classify this as a horror movie, and boy is there horror. I judge a movie by more than just a plot, I cannot stand people who tell me about a movie, or make an online review, and talk about how great the plot is and historical significance and bla, bla.. and then when I watch it I cannot get over the fact that either makeup of the actors is overdone, not good enough, or when they put the Wrong looking actor for the role. i.e. Steven Seagal as Superman.. get it?... totally screws up the movie for me..Now, this movie may not have the greatest most interesting plot (its very short) but, IMO, EVERYTHING else is pretty much spot on. One of the other reasons why I just dont go to the movies anymore, is cause all of the movie these days, whether its horror,thriller,comedy, are ALL predictable, which just screws up my interest in the movie itself. Also I could say the same thing for the MUSIC, I freaking hate it when the movie is interesting but the music just messes everything up, or the special effects, or acting,..One of other things that keeps me watching thru the whole thing (talking about any movie) is the imagination of the writers. Especially these days with the CG animations, the producers have just about used up all the moves,sets,,etc... possible, which IMO makes it boring for me.. ie. another bank robbery movie, another horror movie in a cave,... THIS movie is nothing like that..It has been a while since I have seen such EPIC imagination of writers/producers. The Music was pretty much PERFECT the whole movie. The Acting was great(at least for the main characters) One thing that sort of pisses me off, is when the extras?. background people, suck at acting, or they laugh when there is a horror scene going on, just screws the feel of the scene for me.Special effects were good, but more than the special effects the Bad guys were freaking AWESOME, they scared the crap out of me. I think I would have been even more scared if I was drunk.Bottom line, if you like movies like Lincoln,Titanic,etc... you will probably consider this movie crap. If you like movies that expand your imagination, not so predictable, horror movies that actually scare the living daylight out of you, resident Evil type survival movie, this thing is EPIC. Also the climax of this movie was by far the best hand down I've seen in a long time, hands down, the imagination is superb.p.s. If this producer actually produced the Resident Evil series they could have been some of the most EPIC movies in existence, at least for their genre, and or target audience, instead of the BUll that came out, especially the RE2,3,4.... such a shame..IMO

reviewText: Everyone told me not to see this movie. Friends told me it was the worst movie ever made. I played the video games on Playstation though, and when I saw the previews I really wanted to see it. Unfortunately it was out of theatres before I could. I don't really understand why everyone hated it. Everyone has their own taste, but I happened to really enjoy this movie.The basic plot is a mother who goes to investigate a town called Silent Hill, after her daughter who suffers from sleep trauma keeps repeating it in her sleep. Soon mother and daughter find themselves in the strange town of Silent Hill, which is fairly desolate, and where creatures come out at night. She loses her daughter, and the movie essentially is her trying to find clues where she can find her daughter. Ultimtely though she ends up uncovering a mystery about this town.I found the acting to be nice, but the real treat was the direction and special effects in the movie. More than that, the plot was really interesting. It's a complicated movie, I'm still not sure if I totally get it. The good news for me is that I liked it enough, to watch it again and again until I truly figure it out.
summary: Not as bad as people would like you to think

reviewText: Possibly the most incoherent and plot-less movie I've ever watched. Actually, in my opinion, worse than Plan Nine from Outer Space. From beginning to end, it makes little or no sense and for that reason I simply can't give it more than one star. The acting is fair, but the script is so poor that it can't compensate. The special effects are good, but again, without a sensible plot and set up, they're pointless, they're just an exhibition of effects. There are so many superior ghost/horror stories out there, don't spend your money or time on this one. I wish I could get my two hours back.
summary: Silent Hill, shouldn't be seen or heard

reviewText: 3 1/2 Stars = Very GoodOk, yes, "Silent Hill" the movie is nowhere as great as the video games, but you know what, they did a pretty damn good job of turning this supremely eeriest of video games, into a pretty good eerie film. No small part due to the fantastic CGI effects, atmospheric cinematography, & what may be the most unnerving soundtrack in horror movies, or I should say, video games, the original "Silent Hill" video game music.But for all this going for the films benefit, the direction was surprisingly weak, especially considering director Christophe Gans amazing effort, "Brotherhood of the Wolf!" Even so, a mediocre effort by this superior director is many directors "A" game, & the film does have it's surrealistic creepy, "Hellraiser" like charms. Other problems include a uninspiring execution of the plot, some weak acting, & an overwrought climax, to much of a good thing makes a mockery of the whole point of the film. Yet, it does get under the skin, & that is not a easy thing to do. Compared to the "Resident Evil" films, I'll take "Silent Hill" as my nightmare any night or day!For horror lovers of both cinematic & video game!
summary: Despite it's Many Faults, A Good Video Game to Big Screen Adaptation!

reviewText: I beg to differ with Amazon.com's review. While far from a perfect film, the imaginative visuals and the atmosphere of Silent Hill make it a thoroughly terrifying viewing experience. Though the plot is abstract the premise is simple enough, and some indiscretions in narrative are forgivable since this is a film dealing with the supernatural. My only complaint with the story was the utterly superfluous subplot involving Rose's husband, which did nothing for the film but break up the momentum and suspense of the main storyline.I would venture that most horror buffs aren't looking for literary excellence but rather a good scare and an original idea in a genre that's become quite saturated with mediocre films. Silent Hill offers enough frightening visuals, a gentle foray into social commentary on the dangers of organized religion, and above average dialog, which earns it a respectable place in the horror catalog.
summary: So close to a perfect horror film.

reviewText: Usually I agree with the overall Amazon reviews--but not on this one! I found that there is plenty of plot in Silent Hill. C'mon now, the people giving this movie bad reviews must not be watching much of the rubbish that Hollywood has been sending down the pipe in the way of spooky movies. reviewText: This movie was amazing. Beginning to end it had me drawn in. This movie breaks the rules and thinks outside the box...and gets away with it. I think they finally got a movie that actually seems to stretch the limits of the R rating when it comes to gore. This movie drips and splatters blood.The use of CG is surprisingly low. Most creatures are really people in costumes, but it's so realistic yet strange that you almost think its CG. The movie is well-casted. Instead of, say Sarah Michelle Gellar they went on a limb and casted Radha Mitchell, whose biggest role so far has been in a minor Woody Allen movie. She carries the movie and does a fantastic job. They casted someone named Laurie Holden for the role of Cybil the cop, and she impressed me. Sean Bean as the husband is pretty much the only well-known actor in the movie, and he's basically a secondary character (though he does fine for his role).For everyone who has seen or is going to see or is thinking of seeing Silent Hill, do not go into it thinking ohhh its going to be a scary movie,,, because its not suppose to be. It's for intelligent drama based crowds who like good visuals, story line, acting, and mystery. This isn't Doom and this isn't Resident Evil, this is a well written drama/mystery that happens to be very disturbing in its visual and story. People who have not played the game go see it with an open mind and not look at it as a video game movie because even without the game it could stand on its own as a great movie.To Other Reviewers: Please, do a little research before you cut the movie off at the knees. 1st off they're not Christian fanatics, they're another cult. Secondly, not everything is movies are based on real things. Certain things can be completely fictional. The movie was made to have that dream/nightmare feel.  As for the part where they tell you the back-story, it had nothing to do with anyone not knowing what was going on. Konami as well as Sony loved it so much they didn't cut anything. That is why the movie is so long. Not to mention this is a European FILM!!!! Japanese horror, European writers and actors with few Americans (yeah some of the actors were but they don't write the film). The movie is supposed to make you sit back and go "What the ......" when things randomly happen...that's what Silent Hill is all about. This isn't your run-of-the-mill horror "horny teen" slasher film (which unfortunately is what's most popular in America).

reviewText: I can't believe all the positive reviews of this movie that I'm reading here at Amazon.As Ellen Ripley said in the second Alien film, "Did IQs just drop sharply while I was away?"This movie is utterly and hopelessly incomprehensible.It's gross to look at, but not the slightest bit scary, basically because there is zero -- ZERO -- character development.  We don't give a fig about the mother here, her bewildered husband, or their adopted daughter.Producers, just because you CAN make a movie based on a survival horror game, it doesn't mean you SHOULD.Lovers of classic horror movies should stay as far away from this stinking pile of poo as the protagonists here should have stayed away from the town of Silent Hill.If your curiosity overwhelms you, Crackle is currently showing the film, interrupted by idiotic candy commercials.Still, taking in a single free commercial-riddled viewing is far preferable to laying out money for this blood-spurting turkey.Or try playing the original video game, which at least was legitimately scary and creepy.What is our world coming to?
summary: Dreadful -- and Not in a Good Way

reviewText: Silent Hill is simply great looking and creepy and probably the best movie based on a video game. But still I can't really recommend it. I don't know the game that well and I hear you had to have played the game to understand the movie. But I did watch my brother play the first game once and the film is very faithful to the game.The foggy look is well done. I don't really know much about the creatures from the game though but here they're more clunky and stupid looking than they are scary. Plus I'm not really sure what the point of them really are.  Radha Mitchell is a good actress but the script baically has it that she sees these creatures...gets scared and when they are gone she just acts casual. Some horror video games tend to be like that though lol. I think she had more to work with in Pitch Black though. She does well in horror films but I'm still not even sure why her or Sean Bean (The Fellowship of the Ring) "who plays her husband" are this film. Eventhough both are pretty good in it.She plays a worried mother who's worried about her adopted daughter who has nightmares about a place called Slient Hill. She thinks that bringing her there will help her daughter stop having the nightmares. She gets in an accident after a women police officer trys to make her pull over for like no reason at all. She wakes up in Silent Hill with fog all around her and her daughter nowhere to be seen. She soon realizes that she's in no ordinary place. She has to fight through weird and kinda stupid looking creatures and a crazy cult to try and find her daughter.I like Alice in Wonderland type stories where people suddenly find themselves in a strange place. I wanted to like this movie for that but it would've been better if it didn't rely on thinking that everyone played the video game. The film is still kinda well made though. I mean I played my share of video games like this and when you reach a certain part towards the end you get a sequence that explains important plot twists. This movie does that when Radha Mitchell gets further to fiding the truth about Silent Hill and I can't really say that part wasn't well done. This is probably the best of the video game movies since it is faithful to the video games. The TombRaider movies would be 4 star caliber if they were faithful to the games. But saying this is the best video game movie is still sad since it's still not a great movie. It's just lightyears better than movies like Doom though.
summary: The Most Faithful of the Video Game Based Movies...But Still Not Fantastic
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't play video games and knew nothing about the game, Silent Hill. So I watched this film with very few expectations other than what I saw in the commercials. I'm a sucker for mysteries and horror films so when Silent Hill became available on DVD, I rented it.There are elements of the plot that make this film interesting and intriguing. A mining town abandoned for 30-years because of a coal fire still burning underground sounds like an excellent setting for creepy things to occur. Plus it takes place in West Virginia in the US of A. There aren't a lot of haunted locations in the U.S.--too much money to be made by sanitizing and developing them--so this interested me.For the first 40-minutes or so, I really wanted to understand what was going on. What had happended to the town? What was so horrible. Was Rose really experiencing these things and why.Then there was about 30 minutes too long basically showing us Rose and the leather motorcycle lady cop running away from various demons. Creepy, grotesque demons to be sure. But after awhile, it got old, at least for me. It was like, "Oh here's another scary, mutant creature making Rose scream. Whatever."Finally, FINALLY, we find out what's going on and it's really unsatisfying. Another Japanese-style ghost/demon taking revenge on those that wronged her. In the Ring, the vengeful spirit was interesting and cool. But it's been done way too many times, not particularly well, and the novelty has worn off. It's not a bad plot device but it doesn't make up for an unoriginal story.The film gets 3-stars for kick-butt creepy atmosphere and effects. They did an amazing job making Silent Hill the setting of your worst nightmares. But the slow pacing, redundant scenes, and dirivative story line keep the movie from truly satisfying.
summary: Awesome and atmospheric but lacks strong story & too long

reviewText: Let me start by saying, I'm a big horror buff, both fiction and movies, and I assume Had I played the video game, I might have liked the movie more. "silent hill" is moody, atmospheric, and surreal. at least the first 40-50 minutes or so, but it's a muddled mess from that point on. a young mother [rose] witnesses her adopted daughter [sharon] sleepwalk and repeat the words, "silent hill", while exhibiting odd, suicidal behavior. drugs haven't worked so rose decides to trek off to the town of silent hill to find some answers, and begins her descent into hell. a police officer becomes curious about the mother and daughter, while they are stopped at a gas station. after leaving the service station, the officer stops them to investigate further, but rose decides to flee, with the motorcycle officer in pursuit.both the suv and the motorcycle are involved in an accident, where both women apparently lose consciousness. when rose awakens, sharon has disappeared so she sets off for silent hill on foot, along with the officer, who remains suspicious.  before reaching her destination she is told that silent hill is a an abandoned town due to an underground coal fire that still burns today. it's obvious that silent hill suffered a horrible, tragic end, but where does her daughter fit in? her husband learns that his wife has gone in search of silent hill and takes off to find her, but his role is pretty minor.I've seen many a movie and I am familiar with just about every plot device, and this one begins with a predictable scenario that should be obvious to any horror fan, reminiscent of the movie "jacob's ladder". but no spoilers here. rose encounters various bizarre creatures and a barely coherent woman who warns them of the town's evil. during this time, the movie is genuinely creepy and frightening, however the final half of the movie provides an explanation that is convoluted at best. many horror movies promise big things and often don't deliver. "silent hill" is no exception. I didn't find the end of "silent hill" to be ambigious at all, there are many "clues" throughout to explain the final scene. "silent hill" certainly has it's moments and is very gory and graphic, but ultimately is somewhat of a disappointment. it is  still better than many horror movies I've seen in the last few years, so "silent hill" should be recommended.

reviewText: 30 years ago a mysterious disaster has destroyed the once peaceful and glamorous town of Silent Hill, a young girl named Sharon has been sleepwalking and babbling about the town Silent Hill for her mother Rose (Radha Mitchell) takes her there only to wake up from an accident to find Sharon missing. Rose looks for her in the isolated and lonely ghost town of Silent Hill where weird things go on! strange creatures and spirits along with evil villagers are hellbent on destroying Sharon, however Rose along with a police officer (Laurie Holden) seek out to find her daughter.Spectacular and riviting supernatural horror thriller faithfully adapts the cult video game series to the big screen in a successful way thanks to a screenplay by Pulp Fiction's Roger Avary and French director Christophe Gans ("Brotherhood of the Wolf"). The film's plotline may confuse some viewers but this movie is a gruesome feast for the eyes with disturbing atmosphere, sharp editing and creepy-as-hell creatures that goes into the darkest corners of our nightmares in a H.P. Lovecraft, Clive Barker or Stephen King style. The film also co-stars Sean Bean ("Lord of the Rings"), this lovely yet disturbing shocker is one movie that does the games justice kudos to Christophe Gans and Roger Avery for putting effort into this movie, a must see movie! can't wait for the sequel next year.The DVD has superb sound and picture quality with the only extras being previews to other movies especially this movie and 6 behind the scene featurettes.

reviewText: Towards the beginning of this film, the main character, a mom looking for her (adopted, sleepwalking) child is in the abandoned town and is confronted by a maggot-man: an upright armless, faceless hopping creature that looks like a big maggot that also spews toxic junk out of his head.I wonder if this scene is not a secret homage to the screenwriters who seemed to be blindly hopping around trying to decide whether this movie should be more like a Hellraiser flick, Amityville flick, some Bruce Willis I'm dead/no I'm not flick or just a gore-fest.  What came out of their heads was a confused toxic mess of all of the above.Aside from making the obvious point that some fundamental religous groups (no specific religion slur intended) sometimes get led into madness by nutty leader, it's just one "oooooh, did that scare you?  How about THIS!" after another.Best viewed on DVD so you can play it at at least 2x speed when dialog is not being spoken.

reviewText: It's definitely not CITIZEN KANE, but as far as videogame-to-movie adaptation goes, SILENT HILL is actually not too bad.  That is to say, it's not a particularly great film by any means, but compared to the likes of SUPER MARIO BROS, DOUBLE DRAGON, STREET FIGHTER and even the MORTAL KOMBAT movies, this is far more watchable.  About a woman who searches for her missing daughter in the titular city, SILENT HILL's strongest asset is its cinematography.  From the start, director Christophe Gans, who makes a solid effort to stay close to the creepy atmosphere of the game, recreates the titular villa with appropriately dark, gloomy colors.  The performances, too, are better than one might expect, with Radha Mitchell making a believable turn as the mother dedicated to finding her daughter.  Alice Kruge also gets to have another villainous role as a corrupt priestess who claims to "purify" the corrupt town.  But the film's strongest asset is the use of Akira Yamaoka's music from the games themselves.  That said, there are a couple of faults to be found; there are pacing issues and at least one subplot that really doesn't do much to advance the story (Sean Bean's character searching in the rain for his missing wife and child), and some scenes may be too gory for one's taste (particularly the finale).  Even so, this is still a very commendable effort for a videogame based movie, even if its appeal may be limited to gamers instead of general audiences.  On that level, SILENT HILL is arguably one of the better films of its kind.
summary: Uneven but still solid (if not great) effort at creating a good videogame-based movie.

reviewText: I've never played a Silent Hill videogame in my life; therefore I'm not familiar with its plot or characters. So I viewed Silent Hill just as a normal film watcher. I'm comfortable to say that I enjoyed what I saw. I mean that literally. The visuals in this film are amazing from the beginning scene to the town of Silent Hill to its subtle ending. The dark and dreary aura that the film gave off is in major part due to the visuals. Although the first creature attack is obvious CGI, anything other than that is a great sight.That being said, the plotline became a little confusing to me. Little girl sleepwalks, adopted mother of little girl thinks it deals with the town little girl was born in, mother escapes husband with little girl to visit town, gets sucked into a world of horror, screwed up religion, monsters, and confusion. Got that part. We're told why the little girl was drawn there. Got that part. What I didn't get was the results of it all (and the end sequence that takes place in the church? Awesome and very reminiscent of Hellraiser 2). No spoilers given, but why did the lives of the mother and daughter continue the way that they were? I guess these questions really didn't matter as I was too busy enveloped into the visuals and crazyness going on.Radha Mitchell is beautiful. Her presence as the determined mother was evident, and the woman can play fear (also seen well in Pitch Black). JoDelle Ferland, who is the little girl, didn't really strike me as endearing. She was a little more than annoying. That's just me. It has to take a LOT for a kid actor in a horror film to affect me. I hear she's much better in Tideland. Sean Bean was Sean Bean: tough guy, caring character, very stern face.Silent Hill could have satisfied a little more with a little bit of editing and more of a well-told story. But I enjoyed it.
summary: Gave Me Spectacle, Entertainment, and Confusion

reviewText: Four years since its release in theaters and I still find this movie captivating.  I am not the type of person to buy or watch horror movies very often.  It's probably debatable to even call this horror; it's more suspense.Irregardless, Christophe Gans couldn't have done a better job.  The movie is artistically done in the style and substance of the video game it was derived from; they say that Gans had the video game on set and referred to it constantly.  This is the kind of director one wants to do all video game adaptions--the faithful fan that wants to pay homage to something he loves and admires.The casting of Jodelle Ferland was superb.  I had to pause the movie on multiple occasions in awe and mystery and remind myself that she was a child actor; she has such profound performances to solidify the viewers' suspension of disbelief when experiencing this movie.The story itself has enigmatic qualities; for those that aren't immediately sucked in, it may cause disinterest--but it also allows those remaining to leave with a feeling of ownership.  The sense that you experienced a kind of art that was specifically for you allows a 'replay value' that will bring you back years later to purchase this movie, as I have.

reviewerName: Keith A. Jones "Sonic Jones... I'm Kind Of A ...
reviewText: Silent Hill sure is a surprise and it certainly gets the job done by freaking you out in every way possible. The movie starts off really quick, it doesn't run around anything and it gets right to the point. Rose (Radha Mitchell) is frantically looking for her daughter Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) who hasn't been kidnapped but somehow sleepwalked all the way across a hectic highway to the edge of a canyon. You soon find out that this is a regular thing for Sharon and she is always saying things about Silent Hill while sleeping. After saving Sharon from attempting to throw herself off the edge Rose is fed up and takes a trip to Silent Hill against her husbands will and the real crazy stuff starts happening. After about 10 or 20 minutes into the movie when Rose has an accident entering Silent Hill and Sharon goes missing you start to doubt that anything more can be done with the story. It's actually a good feeling because you're unable to predict the next events and that's one of this films strengths.The acting is great and right on target, especially Radha Mitchell who goes above and beyond to save a child that seems so demented. I have never played the game Silent Hill but I was told there were changes made. The first change seems to be the biggest and that is Sharons mom takes the lead role and not her father. If you ask me the change was effective and positive because you can feel more emotion from the story and Radha Mitchell. The change even puts more to the story and actually allows Rose, Sharon, and Sharons past to have more in common. Another change is that in the game the town is covered in fog and snow but in this movie it's smoke and ash which actually make more sense because the back-story is the city is abandoned because of a coal mine fire that's still burning. That part actually freaked me out because it is said that the coal mine fire is modeled after one that actually exist in Pennsylvania, somewhere not too far from where I live.The most amazing thing about Silent hill is the sick creatures living deep within the town. I have never seen anything like these and they're perfectly nasty to give you that extra chill. Actually I should probably warn anyone with a weak stomach cause some of these guys remind you of the guy in the bed from the film Seven. Everything is perfectly paced and set so when it is time to creep you out your mind goes crazy. Silent Hill has a nice story that you wouldn't expect it to have since some scary flicks are lacking a good story these days. The question now is why did I give Silent Hill 4 stars if I talk about it like a 5 star movie? Well the problem is the ending. Silent Hill ends like a game would or a movie that is sure to have a sequel and since the viewer doesn't have the pleasure of playing this movie a different way to get an alternate ending like the game nobody will know what the heck was going on until a part 2. The movie is good and very entertaining, now all I'm waiting for is a sequel to clear a few things.
Title: N/A

reviewText: At first when I heard that a Silent Hill movie is being released I had some worries for it. As you know, most of the video game adaptations so far have failed miserably. Mario Brothers, Street Fighter, House of the Dead, Final Fantasy: the Spirits Within and The Resident Evils-even though I would consider the first resident evil not to be the worst, it just doesnt give us what the Resident Evil video games are made of. Instead it piles in a bunch of zombies into a movie that seems so rushed and pretty pointless. But I still had to see what Silent Hill was like.As I was watching Silent Hill at the cinema I was thinking, can this be true? Did the movie makers actually develop the true meaning of a video game adaptation? The answer is Yes, absolutely. Ok, so it may not be your best horror film or scariest at that, but we werent exactly expecting it to be either. It does however deliver a big package in relation to the Silent Hill video games. Other than the other attempts of video game adaptations, here they really seemed to have taken the Silent Hill series into consideration. You will notice how the video game features are really brought into perspective. The atmosphere of the game is certainly held deeply within the movie, alongside the soundtrack taken directly from the game, brings you to the whole Silent Hill environment, with creatures and characters that seem incredibly accurate to the video game.But even though the CGI was done decent but not spectacular, I couldnt help think that maybe the CGI wasnt needed. As we know CGI can destroy a horror film, not help it. Yet it didnt destroy this film. I suppose they just could have laid a little low on it near the end. There are some scenes in the film I have noticed that was done extremely well without the CGI.(the creepy guy, in the bathroom, crawling along the floor with his feet by his head). Overall, Silent Hill isnt a masterpiece, nor will it have you shiver, but Silent Hill does, finally, deliver a 'great successfully accurate video game adaptation', with atmosphere and eerieness and a whole lot of fun for the Silent Hill fans.
summary: A successfully Accurate Video Game adaptation.

reviewText: I received a call from my brother about this film. He was not quite sure what he had just seen. He thought it may have been great, but did not really trust his own judgement and asked me to see it with him again.I am not a horror fan, nor have I ever played the games, but I must agree that this was one of the best psychological thrill rides into the depths of horror archetypes ever created.It seems to be using the basics of dream interpretation of jungian psychology and creating disturbing and relentless images that will disorient and keep one thinking about the movie for weeks after.Even though it is not altogether without flaws, there are some unnecessary explanations, stock dialog and over the top climatic gore - but what this movie excels at is bringing the viewer to a place of wonder and horror, where the demons that populate silent hill are our own.It is the inner journey of overcoming fear and choosing sides when the division between good and evil are blurred that makes this movie unlike any other of the genre and worthy of 5 stars.

reviewText: Okay guys, first of all, I know you can't help but compare this flick (I hate to call it a film) to the video game, but that's a flawed view. This here is a movie, kids, and for a movie review, I have to judge this stinker on it's cinematic merits - not on how close the cast & crew were able to come to duplicating the gaming experience.So, two stars, 'cause this baby stank like rotten, year-old Cheez-Whiz, but I'll give it ten stars for the cheesiness factor. The best part of watching Silent Hill is tearing the crappy thing up while trying to figure out all the other movies it cheerfully rips off during the process. While the production design is initially kinda groovy, watch enough movies and you'll see the filmmakers stealing pieces from everything that's come down the pike the over last thirty years or so, including using the evil cult motiff from Robin Hardy and Anthony Shaffer'a eerily atmospheric thriller, The Wicker Man; the creepy, faceless, fast-frame jerky angel/demons from Adrian Lyne's mysterious Jacob's Ladder and bits from Clive Barker's macabre and operatic bloody vision, Hellraiser; all the way to the new fright-movie cliche, the spectral, evil, often lank-haired child (typically a little girl) introduced with the new wave of Asian horror cinema, a-la Hideo Nakata's Ringu (The Ring), Hideo Nakata's Dark Water, and Takashi Shimizu's Ju-On (The Grudge).The, uh, plot has already been outlined here extensively: Husband and wife Christoper and Rose Da Silva (Sean Bean and Radha Mitchell) adopt a beautiful, waif-ish girl named Sharon who's a cronic sleepwalker. At the beginning of the film we find Rose, panicked, racing to rescue sleepwalking Sharon from the edge of their backyard cliff. Okay. Sharon mumbles the name of a town, Silent Hill, over and over, and Rose decides to ditch hubby Christopher and take Sharon to this Silent Hill ghost town, because, heck, that'll help cure her of these whacky episodes, right? On the way, the pair becomes the subject of interest for a hot, tight-leather wearing female cop with an instinct for helping kids in trouble. Rose bolts after the cop decides to pull her over, and suddenly, there's a high-speed chase through the hills and into the off-limits town (turns out there's a coal fire still burning under the town after 30 plus years, and the town's deserted). There's a crash, and when Rose comes to, Sharon's gone. Not easily dissuaded by the creepy town, Rose heads out in search of her daughter, with the sexy cop and eventually, hubby Christopher in hot pursuit.Along the way Rose encounters a rogues gallery of ghoulishly evil characters; a crazy woman spouting fire and brimstone warnings; a flitting, waifish entity named Alessa that's the spitting image of her daughter Sharon; and finally, a crazy cult holed up in a church the size of Notre Dame, led by a woman who looks an awful lot like Sigourny Weaver impersonating a maniacal school-marm.To steal a segment from another Amazon reviewer, I did learn a few things watching Silent Hill, that I thought I'd pass on:1. A house right on the edge of a cliff is the perfect living environment for an adopted child with a sleep walking condition.2. When thinking of adoption, stay the hell away from waif-ish, doe-eyed little girls with long, stringy brown hair and insanely creepy split personalities. They always seem have some unknown problems you just don't want to deal with (see #1, above, for example...)3. Note to all hot, sexy, tight black leather wearing cop-babes: shouting 'Stop!' before shooting a shambling, burning acid-spitting, humanoid thingy that looks like it's got another nine or ten people rolling around in its torso, fighting to get out, will only provoke getting said acid-spit directed your way.4. Note to all aspiring horror film-makers: directing a shambling monster thingy's burning acid-spit toward a hot, sexy cop is the perfect way to get said cop to remove her burdensome leather clothing.5. Muscle bound demon-guys with pyramids instead of heads are really scary and carry really, really big knives.6. And I quote: Dahlia Gillespie: "Why didn't she take me? Like the others?" Rose: "Because you're her mother. Mother is God in the eyes of a child." Whooo - That's deep.7. You can only enter Silent Hill if you're dead. Um, I think. And if so, even dead people can still be burnt to death by crazed cult members. I think.8. Crazed cult members bent on killing you will calm down easily if you just casually push them away.9. Stiv carrying zombie-demon nurses are really hot; especially when they're lined up wearing skimpy demon-nurse uniforms, stumbling around like the chorus for a creepy version of Silent Hill, the musical.10. When you finally find and confront the little devil-girl Alessa and discover 'The Truth', it turns out to be holiday footage of the Crazy Cult's special Little Witch Burning Day, preserved on badly deteriorating, overdeveloped film stock shot sometime circa 1973.That about covers it, I think, beyond getting into the extras included in the DVD, which is the increasingly standard making of documentary broken into a whopping six parts covering everything from the origins of the game to the creature development. Frankly, I found the extras more fun - definitely more interesting - than the finished movie.I love bad horror movies as much as the next guy, but except for coming away slightly nauseated, I've got to say that there's really not anything particularly scary in Silent Hill - other than the gawd-awful dialogue and crummy acting - it's just grisly. I really hate to think about anyone wanting to watch this stinker more than once. While video games have become more and more cinematic in their storytelling, Silent Hill is a perfect example of the ineptitude of incorporating corny, choppy plotlines - which work fine in a game format - into the film medium; and also, how low Hollywood has sunk in its continuing attempt to flush more and more cash from an increasingly growing market (all of us gamers out here, me included), who are too often willing to shell out our hard earned money - often up to $50 bucks a pop for most video games - for tripe like this.
summary: Abandon hope all who enter here...

reviewText: The trailers for this film made it look really, really creepy.  Unfortunately, all of those creepy moments in the trailers are the only creepy moments in this film.  "Silent Hill," based on a videogame series I've never played before, tells us the story of Rose, a mother who is trying to come to terms with the sleepwalking and nightmarish fits of her daughter, Sharon.  Sharon constantly speaks of Silent Hill in her fits, so Rose tracks the actual place down and takes her there against the will of her husband, Chris.Pursued by a policewoman while trying to get to Silent Hill, Rose and Sharon are involved in a car accident.  When Rose awakes, Sharon has vanished and the cop is attempting to arrest her.  When Rose and the policewoman encounter a "thing" outside of Silent Hill, Rose uses the distraction to escape from the officer and seek out her daughter in the creepy, fallout-looking town of Silent Hill.  We are slowly lead around the town for what seems like an eternity.  We are intentionally denied specifics in an attempt to build both suspense and confusion.  Rose begins chasing another young girl in the town who she believes can lead her to her daughter.  Along the way, Rose and the cop befriend each other and they join together in a battle against supernatural forces and mutant-like creatures in order to save Sharon.Meanwhile, Rose's husband is desperately trying to find his wife and daughter.  He, along with a suspicious cop, scourge the same Silent Hill looking for his family, but instead of the gray, misty version of the town that Rose is trapped in, Chris is simply in a deserted town.  This is the first tip-off that Silent Hill might be operating on two separate planes of reality.Confusing, dull, lacking in any real interesting characters, "Silent Hill" is obviously meant for the game kids to sit back and enjoy the inside jokes.  I'm disappointed in Sean Bean for agreeing to be in this drivel, he's much better in "Equilibrium," "Lord of the Rings," and the "Sharpe's" films.  Radha Mitchell also brings little to the table in this bummer.  Director Christophe Gans remembered to bring the atmosphere from his wonderful "Brotherhood of the Wolf," but he forgot character development, good action sequences, a credible plot, and some decent scares.  Instead, he got graphic-happy with more CGI blood and guts than you can shake a stick at.If you love the games, I'm guessing you'll enjoy this flick.  However, if you want a legitimate scary flick, look elsewhere.  Also, a better video-game based movie is either of the "Resident Evil" films.  They have better plots, faster action, and much better baddies.  Oh, and before I'm accused of being a lover of "Resident Evil" the game, I've never played that either and I still managed to keep up with the storyline.Rent at your own risk.

reviewerName: Kirk McKenna Jr. "I love falling asleep to Au...
reviewText: The word running through my head during this entire film was, "Atrocious". After we sat through this monstronsity, my brother looked at me and said, "Well, the popcorn was good." There are so many things wrong with this film, it's hard to choose even where to begin.First of all, nobody acts like these characters in real life...hell, nobody acts like these characters in a video game! The acting was terrible -- everybody overacts. Sean Bean would've gone into an utter rage if the restaurant would've said they were out of complimentary toothpicks or mints.The special effects were incredibly good, but there simply was no script. I got the feeling they created all of these creepy effects shots and then just told the actors to improvise. In the beginning, there was an actual place that was a gas station, restaurant and tattoo parlor rolled into one. I said to my brother, "It has everything you'll ever need!" At times, the scenes were so absurd, that I started busting up laughing -- so hard I was in tears.The first hour, in spite of the absurdity of the story, does have several creepy scenes that weren't all that bad, but during the second hour, the film completely changed with a whole new plot even more insane than the first! I got the impression they could've finished the film after the first hour, but since it needed to be longer, they just threw some even more crappy plotline together. Not even the presence of Alice Krige (Borg Queen, ST:First Contact and VOY), or Laurie Holden (Marita Covarrubias, The X-Files) could save this trainwreck. I wasn't even scared once!Save your money and wait for this when it goes on the cheap shelf at the video store, and it's only worth that for the effects.  Thank god I used a pass to get in to see this, because if I would've paid to see this stinkbomb, I'm sure I would've asked for a refund.

reviewText: First off, this movie looked awesome.  For anyone who has ever played any of the games, the filmmakers really did their homework.  It looks EXACTLY like the game come to life with every minor detail.  I can honestly say that this is the Best adaptation of a video game into a movie that I have ever seen.  In the beginning, you will groan with censure at the opening sequence of the child actor screaming "Silent Hill!  Silent Hill!" and you think, "Oh man, this movie is going to suck."  But stay in your seats because surprisingly, the actor they chose for the role of Sharon (not Cheryl) does a spectacular job. The story was changed around slightly so that it would be easier to understand for non-gamers, but there were still some story holes.  The husband character's purpose was to fill in plot points and show the audience that Silent Hill is no ordinary town, though he doesn't seem to serve much purpose.  If you're watching it and you have no idea what's going on, sit tight because there will be a long narration at the end for those who don't get it.  I still stick by my standards that a good filmmaker doesn't need a narrator to explain the story if they've done their job right, but I can't really complain about this one.  They threw in as much from the games that would fit, including Pyramid Head from Silent Hill 2.  If you've played the game, you'll love this movie.  If you haven't, it still makes a good horror flick, but you probably won't love it.  If you're unsatisfied with the ending, you should know that this wasn't so much a typical horror movie as the start of a franchise.  You can expect more than one sequel to follow and more of Pyramid Head.

reviewerName: Konrei "Everything I need is right here"
reviewText: SILENT HILL is based on a series of "survival" video games, and anyone familiar with SILENT HILL the game will probably appreciate SILENT HILL the movie, but for the rest of us SILENT HILL becomes a wearying, unvarying, plotless stumble through a world of atmospheric horror.Rose Da Silva and her daughter Sharon visit the town of Silent Hill to find out the Why of Sharon's recurrent nightmares about the town, which at first appears deserted but is densely populated by wraiths, giant arachnids, faceless zombies, eyeless walking corpses, and other grotesques, all trapped in some congruent dimension into which Rose and Sharon are drawn. When Sharon vanishes, Rose is forced to search Silent Hill for her daughter. Rose's search finally leads her to Sharon's kidnappers, a bizarre religious cult that is dedicated to burning demons alive---of course, Rose and Sharon qualify as demons. And although the cult are the bad guys of the film, there seems to be no connection between them and the various monsters Rose has to fight to find Sharon, meaning that three quarters of SILENT HILL has nothing to do with itself.The major problem with SILENT HILL is that it simply isn't frightening, its just gross. Rating a 25 on the 1-10 gross-out meter, SILENT HILL even loses its effectiveness as a nausea-inducing, "Ewwww!"-producing movie because the grossness becomes predictable. Nothing shocks because the last scene was so yucky it becomes a safe assumption that the next scene is going to be even yuckier, and it always is.A film largely geared to fans of the video game who will give it five by five, SILENT HILL gets one star for its atmospherics, which are appropriately dark, and another star for actress Radha Mitchell (Rose) who carries most of this film on her slender shoulders alone, seems convincing in the midst of this pointless chaos, and looks good doing it.
summary: This Town Ain't Big Enough For The Two Of Us

reviewText: This movie was a major dissapointment to Silent Hill fans all over. If you have never heard of Silent Hill before you've seen this, you are lucky. I'm not saying that the movie was really bad or anything, it's just...come on! I'm one of the hugest silent Hill fans to ever grace this earth! I was expecting it to be like the movie. I understand that most movies are never exactly like the game or book, but I wasn't expecting this. In the videogameSilent Hill, there is a man, Harry Manson, searching for his daughter Cheryl in the town of Silent Hill after he swerved on the road trying to avoid a girl in the road, after he woke up in the car to find her missing. There's the first problem. In this movie, there is a married couple. The lady, Rose, takes her daughter to silent hill because this girl has been having nightmares and doing weird things all drawn in by this abandoned town. The plot, and alot of things in the movie don't even exist in the game.This movie was produced by an english company. They called the infamous Pyramid Head, "red pyramid" which disapointed me greatly.All in all the movie was okay. It wasn't what I expected, but It still keeps the eerie silent hill feeling. Title: N/A

reviewText: Let me first off start by saying that I'm obsessed with the Silent Hill game series.  And I'm going to try to write this review as unbiased as I can get for the benefit of those that haven't played the game series.Silent Hill is a game about atmosphere and art direction.  The plot is there, but no where near as strong as the production.  Which makes it a good film, instead of a great film.For the game fans, I feel that Christophe Gans has captured Silent Hill to a T.  His vision, is my vision of the town and monsters.  And I hope he's onboard for the visual direction of the sequel if there is one.Acting, was done as best as it could be.  I feel that all the main characters, Rose, Sharon, Cybil, Cristabella, and Dahlia, were done wonderfully.  The script wasn't the best, and they did what they could with it.  Rhada played Rose splendidly in my opinion, her fear leaking out of the screen.  Laurie did a great job with cybil, helping the audience feel compassion for her.  Jodelle was a little weak with Sharon, however did a splendid job with Alessa.  For a little girl, I was throughly impressed.The creature effects really stand out.  Instead of being purely CG, they took the time and effort to get dancers to do the monsters, and put them in costume.  If you watch the behind the scenes, its really impressive.  And I think a lot of horror movies could learn from this decision.  CGI is not the right choice all the time.  Green screens were used as well, however I feel that Silent Hill is one of the few  movies that pulls off CGI effects and costume effects really well.  Perhaps because its meant to be such a surreal movie, one in which you're supposed to suspend reality, that its not as noticeable.The plot, as I said, is lacking, but for what its worth I think it generally worked okay.  As an adaption they did what they could.  Anyone who knows the storyline of the first game, knows how complex it is.  And personally, if so  many people were confused with this current plot line, then I suppose they made the best choice in simplifying it.  I feel that its fairly easy to follow, and I think they did a good job of trying to show the different realities and such of the world of Silent Hill.  It sets up what the town's about, which is what Gans was aiming for, since he originally wanted to adapt the second game.  I think he made a good choice of trying to explain the town first, and why it is the way it is.As for the special features, there aren't any, really.  Which is dissapointing.  The behind the scenes special is fun, and a great feature, however its the only feature.  During the behind the scenes we can see that there are many scenes that weren't used, and it would've been nice to see these deleted scenes.  It would've also been nice to have some trailers to the movie, some trailers for the video games, and maybe a few fun extras to do with the games.But that's what the infamous "double dipping" is for, right?In short, if you're a fan of horror, and if you can let the atmosphere and movie wash over you, it should be an enjoyable romp.  Don't sit there, and try to figure things out as the movie's going on.  You really just have to let the movie lead you through, and wrap you up in its world.  Its a gorgeous film, and can be entertaining if you let it.
summary: Beginning to break the Video Game Movie curse
Title: N/A

reviewText: After emerging from the theatre, my friends and I were soo creeped out that we had to come up with something positive and friendly and the only thing we could come up with was fly a kite (hence the title).So, like many gamers, I was afraid like the video game/movie predecessors Silent Hill would follow the legacy of sucking.  I am proud to report that my expectations were mostly wrong.  Silent Hill was much better than I expected and with that are the pros and cons.Pros.Actually followed the details of the game to a degree that it's good for gamers, but not annoying for the general audience.  The scenes of Silent Hill were well done and didn't look fake at all down to the last details.  However, the producers did deviate some with the endings (which led to much discussion amongst my friends and I) and what they represented.Silent Hill is not your typical horror film at all.  For once, it made my friends (also avid gamers and film buffs) actually think about the movie in philisophical terms... something we've never done with a horror film.  Also, the movie does not incorporate the usual suspense and surprise themes.  Instead, Silent Hill has a constant state of fear with stuff that fades in and out such as pyramid head (the wacky villian with a head that looks like a piece of road construction for you non-gamers).As for the horror aspect, the movie was just creepy from literally start to finish.  The climax at the end just made my skin crawl as it did with my friends in the audience.  Throughout the film it is just one creepy concept after another with bugs, pyramid head and the other monsters seen in the game.  I was not on the edge of my seat the whole time, but my skin did crawl once or twice.The story was nice, falling almost completely in line with the original Silent Hill game for the playstation and even explains how Silent Hill became the way it was in a comprehensive manner.  Again, my friends and I had to sit down after the movie and discuss the ending because it was soo... thought provoking, which is unheard of in horror films that like to wing the ending in hopes of making a sequel.The music was done by the original composer of the Silent Hill games, which confused the audience with it's Japanese-style suspense (which is very similar to the music in the anime Patlabor) but made the gamer fans just nod and smile.  Some parts had the typical game beats, which probably was not a good idea so it wasn't perfect, but good nonetheless.Now for the cons.  The acting was a bit off by some, particularly the 'scavengers' in Silent Hill.  I think the woman in the church was the same one who played the queen Borg in Star Trek: First Contact... which made it a little weird.  Sean Bean does his usual excellent performance and plays a role people can actually like for a change.Again, the climax scene seemed a bit... odd and downright cheesy at points.  It was also a bit gross and excessive in some perspectives and could've been done a lot better.  This also makes me agree with my peers that there needed to be more pyramid head... he just wasn't in there enough and he played a major role in the games and was bad*ss enough as is as a villain.Many parts seemed a bit cheesy such as the 'survivors.'  Some of the lines just seemed soo... captain obvious.  At one point, the cop turns to rose and says, "I think something bad happened here," or took a look around a burned building and said, "I think there was a fire here."  It was almost like the dialogue in the first Resident Evil game, only these people were smart enough to stick together rather than split up.All in all, a sold C+.  It was good, but could've been much better.  It'll creep you out, I can assure you of that... just please do not talk during the movie, it really ruins it for everyone else.
summary: I Had to Fly a Kite After Seeing Silent Hill

reviewText: I have seen several of these movies that are based on video games, but "Silent Hill" is the first one where I have been motivated to order one of the games and try it out. This was not just because of the bizarre world that I saw on screen, but also because of the testimonial provided by director Christophe Gans in the special features on this DVD, who started playing the original "Silent Hill" game and apparently got three or four hours into it when it hit him it would work as a movie. But there is something to be said for the bizarre world and if style overwhelms substance in this 2006 horror film that is more because the style is so omnipresent than the problematic elements of the substance.So I know nothing about the "Silent Hill" videogame and have no idea where the movie is being faithful and where it is grossly offending game players. Rose DaSilva (Radha Mitchell) has an adopted daughter, Sharon (Jodelle Ferland), who sleepwalks across the interstate in the middle of the night to stand on the precipice screaming "Silent Hill!" It turns out that this is the name of a ghost town in West Virginia that was abandoned because of uncontrollable fires in the coal minds underneath the town. Rose decides to take Sharon there because that is the sort of thing you do in videogames (or movies) when somebody in a heightened state of awareness starts screaming clues. Besides, Sharon keeps drawing pictures of the place. Rose's husband, Christopher (Sean Bean), does not think this is a good idea so she starts off without telling him and he spends the rest of the film playing catchup.According to everybody Rose asks, you cannot get to Silent Hill from here, except that there is a road sign that still indicates the turn off. However, when Rose takes the fateful road up to Silent Hill she does so by driving away from the female highway patrol cop on a motorcycle who pulled her over. The next thing we know there is a car accident and when Rose comes to again, Sharon is gone. We now have the basic situation of the movie: Sharon is lost in Silent Hill, and Rose is going to have to go find her.Beyond that I really do not want to say more about the plot of the film because what matters is not the specifics of how Rose tracks down Sharon, but that she does it in a world aptly described at one point on the DVD as "Alice in Wonderland" meets "Dante's Inferno." The latter reference point is obvious because I was thinking early on that Gustave Dore's etchings for "The Inferno" were an artistic inspiration for what is going on here (along with Nine Inch Nails music videos) with Carol Spier's production design and Dan Laustsen's cinematography, but I can see where Rose and Sharon have gone down a hell of a rabbit hole as well. Rarely have I seen a film where what is happening is taking a back seat to the locale, but "Silent Hill" really is that sort of a film. I want to see what happens next for the visual dimensions rather than for what it means for the narrative.However, I will speak to the apparent confusion that exists over what is going on, without explaining what is happening (and with one hand tied behind my back). At issue is whether Silent Hill is a town gone wrong because of an unnatural disaster, like in "The Hills Have Eyes" (think of bituminous coal as the early 19th century equivalent of rampant nuclear energy), or whether it is an alternative reality, like in "Army of Darkness." This is a key question, and the answer is that the film is both. That is not obvious, at least not until you catch the key visual difference between the two, but it is important to understanding what is happening in the film. Even at the end I am not totally sure what has just happened, but I saw the final twist coming and I liked it, and I have not liked the final twist in a horror film since "Honogurai mizu no soko kara." Now I have to go see about playing that video game.
summary: Throwing characters and viewers into a world of distrubing images

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: The beginning of this movie confused me, which I suppose was the intent of the director and the producer.  Throughout the movie you get bits and pieces of what is happening until near the end of the movie, when most, but not all, of the details are explained.Plot Spoilers Avoided to the Extent Possible!Rose Da Silva (Radha Mitchell) is taking her adopted daughter Sharon to the town of Silent Hill to understand why her daughter is having nightmares and sleep walking.  Husband Christopher opposes Rose's trip and does everything in his power to stop the trip.  Of course, Rose and Sharon arrive in Silent Hill with a motorcycle officer close behind.Once in Silent Hill, all confusion and horror breaks out.  Sharon immediately disappears.  The imagery is bizarre and surreal, alternating with sinister figures and creatures that can only be some kind of ghosts.  What is going on?  Why is the sky around Silent Hill always overcast with ash falling?A few minor details about the story of "Silent Hill."  We learn that a little girl was molested, and a self-righteous woman decided the little girl had to be "purified."  The girl's injuries were horrific, but she also acquired an incredible, largely evil power driven by her need for revenge.  Eventually the little girl caused a fire deep within the earth to erupt into the town of Silent Hill, killing many of the citizens.  We learn that citizens of the town have imposed their own peculiar and strict brand of faith on the town for centuries.  The town has mostly been abandoned, but the abandonment does not necessarily extend to every dimension...This movie shares some similarities to Japanese horror films.  The movie is loosely based on the Silent Hill series of video games, and a couple of artifacts of the video games were imported that appear to make little sense in the movie.  Fortunately, the distractions from the video game that fail to advance the plot are minimal, though they do enhance the confusion felt by Rose.This movie falls well shy of being a great horror movie, but it is fun to watch and the cinematography is outstanding.  The director used overhead shots a lot to reinforce our aloofness from certain scenes, but in other scenes we were extremely close to the action.  The director also alternated dramatic scenes with detailed scenes.  The director's intent seemed to be to contrast our desire to know, but our desire to keep from being affected by our observations.  The director refuses to let us escape from being part of the action, and by the end of the movie we are all too up close and personal with the events of the film.Horror movie fans will want to watch this movie for its brilliant cinematography and imaginative special effects.  However, be prepared to think and watch the movie more than once to figure out what is going on.  Splatter film fans will likely be bored by the carefully constructed story line that requires the entire movie to evolve.  Action movie fans will be bored because this movie has only intermittent action.Enjoy!

reviewText: I give this movie 3.5 stars. Intriguing, but not very original story draws you in. The imagery and cinematography are fantastic and create an ominous atmosphere and a sense of doom.I found Rose to be a horror movie cliche, with her string of moronic decisions. ***SPOILER*** High tailing it to Silent Hill like she is an escaped con. Oh yeah, and I'll drag my young and obviously traumatized daughter with me, but not my husband. What could go wrong?! The way she flees from the police officer for no apparent reason. Smart move mommy. And while she is on a roll, why not drive like a maniac and crash through a fence. You see, then her vehicle gets damaged and she and her child are stranded in Silent Hill, which looks a lot like a war zone and a little like the gates of hell. Sleepwalking daughter does her thing. Now we've got a plot. Shes got to find her daughter! The most believable character was the female police officer.The movie took a silly turn with all the religious zealots and their actions. And from there, it sort of dragged on for me. Ending was good. All in all it was okay. Not that scary.

reviewText: When this movie was released back in April 2006, I was more than thrilled to go see it. Although I'm a huge fan of the series at that time I didn't care if the movie would be bad or not, and when I say bad I mean on par with the Street Fighter movie bad. But thank goodness it turned out to be great. I even dragged my cousin, who is somewhat familiar with the game from watching me play during sleepovers, to the theater to see this with me.  She was grossed out, horrified, and stunned by the film, as was I.  It was pretty scary for me even for a movie adaption of the game.Video-game fans are somewhat a hard crowd to please for the most part. The word 'adaption' means just that, it's not going to be the Silent Hill game rehashed bit by bit.  Why pay money for a movie when you already know what's going to happen?  I'm a fan of the series, but some just take their 'fandom' waaay too seriously.  It's a video-game movie, just be happy that sad sack director Uwe Boll(House of the Dead, Alone in the Dark, BloodRayne, Doom) didn't get his disgsting mitts on this project, then you'd really have something to bitch about.Instead of the male protagonist we had in SH1, we're introduced to Rose(Radha Mitchell) who takes her adoptive daughter Sharon to the town of Silent Hill, against the wishes of her husband, believing that somehow it will help flesh out the mystery of why Sharon is plagued by nightmares of the town.  It follows the main storyline of the first game and includes many canon characters from the game with the inclusion of many non-canon charcters.  I was not upset or perturbed by this by no means.  I thought it was an excellent idea on the director's part to mix and blend his ideas with what the series has already established.Similar to the game, Rose and Sharon are involved in a car crash after racing to the town by taking a closed road, which alerts the concern of patrolling officer Cybil Bennet(canon) who attempts to stop her.  After an undetermined amount of time after the crash, Rose awakes in the fog laden town with ash falling from the sky...Sharon is no where in sight.  Thus, the movie really begins.The film includes many key elements and characters from the series, but it isn't all copied from the game. The movie takes a life of its own, but it keeps the plot grounded to what the fans were familiar with from the game with the main goal of finding the missing daughter of the protagonist and hopefully escaping from the town.  There is some interesting back story about the origin of Sharon nostalgic to the Alessa/Cheryl/Heather element also.I love how the director portrayed the town as like an alternate dimension/world disconnected yet still apart of the real world. We see this in the scenes involving Rose's husband and a detective who are in the real deserted town(due to the hazard of the coal fire burning underground) compared to Rose and Cybil who are trapped in 'alternate' Silent Hill.I also love how this film, unlike the Resident Evil films(which I also like), has a lot of familiarity of the game such as locations like Midwich Elementary, Grand Hotel, and Alchemelia Hospital.  There are familiar characters and villians, along with the music from Akira Yamaoka. I don't care if the movie wasn't an exact replica of the game or not, because that's not what I wanted, I just wanted a movie with solid acting, good scares, and an engaging plot.  This movie delivered that to me and I have no complaints, save for a few...Christopers Gans took some risks by including the fan favorite Pyramid Head in the film.  The movie follows the plotline of SH1, PH is from SH2 and many fans debate that this villian is somehow manifested in the main character's mind from SH2, and I agree, but I believe PH was added to the film for fanservice.There are many memorable and great scenes from the movie and I was surprised at how great the monsters looked without looking overly cheesy or unrealistic.  There is a fair amount of blood and gore scenes in the movie that are just as disturbing as the content from the game.  It's a great 'adaption' for the series and I belive many people who are not familiar with the video games will enjoy this film if they are fans of horror.The ending is a bit of a mystery and it may leave many viewers confused or open up more doors of theorizing about what really happened...
summary: A Brilliant Movie Adaption of the Silent Hill Series!

reviewText: I have never even seen the video game, so I went into watching this with the advantage of being totally unbiased. That said, this is a wonderfully shot film. Very atmospheric, at times it reminded me of Tim Burton's "Sleepy Hollow" but minus the charm. In many scenes it rivalled Tarsem's Jennifer Lopez starrer "The Cell" for visual excellence (thats another movie you should definitely watch for 'real' horror).The story Im sure you know about. However, I wasn't scared even ONCE during this film, not even at its most 'inventive' moments. The premise itself was dull (how many times are we going to be subjected to the worn plot of a disgruntled little girl who was killed off and is now seeking revenge - "The Ring" anybody?) and the execution seemed to be focussed on the special effects rather than the real elements of horror.Radha Mitchell is a gorgeous woman and she does a fantastic job here (considering she mostly had to act scared in front of a blue screen - pretty darned impressive). But theres only so much that can take you. By the time you wind through mazes and labyrinths with her trying to find her daughter - you realize that this film is not a horror film, but a very, very stylish adventure-mystery. If you take it for what it is, it could work.The end was very convoluted. I mean, this whole 'parallel universe'/'existential angst' thing works well and much better in some of the darker Japanese horror films I've seen. In the last scene on the sofa, the lead actress actually looks relieved that the movie is over. This was one element I had a problem with. However, the moods of the two parallel universes were beautifully captured as one was smoky and gray and the other awash in technicolor just to make a point.Heres the thing - I would not call this a horror movie. Most of its horror moments are just very funny (and unintentionally so) - for example a scene where the lead actress is mauled by a dozen or so burnt baby corpses that come to life and suddenly they all turn into ash. The CG on this wasn't very good. Either way, its better than other films in the genre when it comes to special effects.This was definitely better than "Pulse" and "Sublime" that came out around the same time. However, its still a C-Grade horror film. Keep that in mind before you rent it, and go in with very low expectations, and you might have a good time.
summary: A Worthy Stylish Half-Sister of "The Cell"
