reviewText: I knew the video game existed, but when I watched the movie, I knew nothing of the context.  I wondered if someone such as myself, someone without a reference point for the story and scenes, would enjoy the film as much as a lover of the game.The story concerns a young girl, Sharon, who sleepwalks and, during her somnambulism, mentions the name of a town: Silent Hill.  Her adoptive mother, Rose, desperate for an answer that therapy and medication have not provided, takes her daughter to the town, which has since been closed down due to the unstoppable coal fires that burn beneath it, the result of an obscure accident that occurred years earlier.  This accident, it turns out, created deep spiritual scars that reveal themselves when the town is, periodically, drenched in an explicable darkness.  (Don't let the name fool you; there's a lot of screaming and moaning going on in this so-called "silent" town.)The town, of course, is a pit of misery, horror, and demons.  Shortly after arriving, Rose loses Sharon.  She goes on a desperate search for her daughter, and finds, instead, shape-shifting demons, a constant rain of ash, and a scattering of dangerously fundamental townsfolk.  It turns out that Sharon doesn't need help.  Rose does.Rose is aided in her quest by a policewoman (the story is almost entirely about the curative faith and destructive hatred capable in women; the men in this film are portrayed as completely impotent; there could, in fact, be no male characters at all and the film would probably work just as well).  The policewoman, Cybil, follows Rose into Silent Hill, intending to pull the mother over for some crime which is unclear (Cybil's motivation is later explained, but it still does little to justify Cybil's actions at the beginning of the film as she chases Rose into the town; for that matter, it is unclear why Rose doesn't simply stop and explain herself to the cop).  When they find themselves stuck in this hell together, they join forces to find Sharon and escape.This movie is one of the most visually compelling horror films I've ever seen.  Sure, there's gore, but in spite of its staggering volume, it hardly ever seems gratuitous.  There are a few exceptions to this.  Near the end, a character is killed (surprise!) in one of the single most disturbing and realistic depictions of someone being burned alive that I have ever scene.  Also, the final Scene of Vindication (for whom, I won't say) is necessary, given the nature of the story, but it goes on far too long, and is filled with the sort of unending and benumbing graphic violence that the movie had mostly, up to that point, only artfully hinted at.The key word there is "mostly."  This film is sure to offend and disturb more than a few viewers.  It's visceral cinematography is outstanding, but also truly gut-wrenching.  The squeamish should stay away.The acting and story, however, aren't bad at all.  And even if the story-line occasionally strays into Obviously-Based-On-A-Video-Game territory (Hello, Mazes!  Hello, Occasional Tricky Obstacles!  Hello, End Level Boss!  Power Up!), it is satisfying (in it's own right) for those viewers who aren't interested in role-playing games or first-person shooters.  Radha Mitchell is excellent as the desperate and horrified mother (although she does reprise a lot of the same facial expressions she employed in Pitch Black).  Laurie Holden (who appeared regularly on X-files) takes a little time to find her character, but once she does (taking off her sunglasses and that massive motorcycle helmet helps with this), she fills her niche nicely.I won't lie; although this film is mastefully done, its exquisite attention to detail sometimes comes across as over-the-top, and it can cause an emotional chasm.  I ended up being more intrigued by the film's limits and purposes than I was by the characters'.  This came flying back into my face in the movie's final moments, when character empathy becomes the most important element of the story.  Still, it's a balletic (and appropriately creepy) denoument, and, true to the title, it's pulled off without a word.
summary: Silence Is Golden ... or, er ... not

reviewText: I haven't played any of the Silent Hill games and probably won't but this film sure left me wishing I had more time on my hands so that I could.  This film works on a lot of different levels and you have to go back through it in your mind before you realize that the story does work and make sense.  ALL of the actors are very strong in their roles - solid acting all the way around.The feel of the town of Silent Hill reminded me of what I was feeling when I read HP Lovecraft's "The Shadow Out of Innsmouth".The costumes are so effective it becomes very hard to discern the line between live-action and CGI effects.One warning - much of the imagery is very nightmarish and disturbing - but it isn't really gore - can you get your head aound that?  It's like being dropped square in the middle of a Hieronymus Bosch painting that has come to life.Excellent, haunting and disturbing.Follow-up:  Just watched Silent Hill a second time.  In some respects it was even better because I could focus on the incredible imagery instead of trying to follow the story and plotline.  The acting, the sets, the effects, and the music score are pretty close to perfection.  Silent Hill definitely raises the bar for excellence in the horror film genre.  This is an intense work of art.  If I had any criticism it would be that the sound did not transfer well in a couple of places where Dahlia is speaking.  BUY NOW!

reviewText: Finally! A really good and really origional movie! This is one of the only horror movies to be released in the last couple of years that has not been a remake or a sequel - and it is very good!A woman named Rose's daughter has nightmares in which she sleepwalks and shouts of a place named Silent Hill. However, in a car accident shortly after having arrived on the outskirts of Silent Hill Roses' daughter, Sharon, disapppears and so Rose embarks, alone, upon her journey through the nightmareish hell that is Silent Hill...This movie is suspencefull, frightening and origional and I would reccomend it to all fans of the genre.

reviewText: First off, the movie doesn't make too much sense. Only at the end do things come together, and even then not much is explained.Second, it's incredibly long and boring. Much of the time it just shows Rose (the main character) wandering around in Silent Hill, which is pointless when all you can see is white and a few buildings. The movie is supposed to be scary, and not once did I get jumpy or anything. There's maybe two creepy parts, but it's more like a weird creepy than it is a serious "What the hell is that?" sort of creepy.Overall, one word: Boring. The story is weak, it's too long for it's own good, and it's not scary (which - for being based off of one of the most horrific of video games series - is pretty sad. Watched a friend play it for 5 minutes and I was creeped out.) The only few cool parts is with some of the creatures Rose encounters, and you only get to see them for a minute or two before she starts wandering off for 20 minutes again.If the makers of this game are trying to create the same terror the games did, they failed miserably. I actually felt like stopping the movie halfway through out of shere disappointment.
summary: Boring and not very well written.

reviewText: When creating a movie from a game like Silent Hill all the elements you need to make an outstanding movie are basicly given to you. If anyone involved in creation of this movie had played the games they would have understood much of a disgrace this movie is.Silent Hill the game itself plays out like movie. They could of taken the game and just played it out scene by scene and would of had a spectacular movie. Silent Hill should the movie should of been a cross between Stephen King's The Mist and M.Shyamalan's The 6th sense. Two films that that leave you with that spookie feeling of wonderment but provide plenty of "shock" gore when it's time to scare you. That myfriends is what Silent Hill is like. A Town covered in fog with strange creatures and running into people that you don't know are dead or not.After seeing Resident Evil and how that turned out in it's movie adaption I wasn't exactly thrilled about Silent Hill comming out on movie. I watched it and it was like pulling the wings off a butterfly. They actually managed to sample just about every other popular horror flick,throw in some elements from the game, and expect to pass it off as Silent Hill. I felt absolutely insulted by all this. Not only because I'm a Silent Hill fan, but because I'm also a die hard fan of horror movies.I couldn't really get into the movie already knowing what cheap knockoff spooks they were going to try because you've seen it 1million other times in just about every horror movie ever created from 1970-to whenever this junk came out.I mean I don't hate this movie, I just hate that it's named after something I love and enjoy so much. If this was just another horror flick I'd give it 2 or 3 stars for trying and move on, but this... this is supposed to be SILENT FREAKING HILL! Instead I get the Grudge/Ring/Shinning/Excorcist/Firestarter/Omen/Carrie/You name it it's here!A NOTE TO PRODUCERS! IF YOUR GOING TO MAKE A MOVIE OFF A GAME ATLEAST PLAY IT FIRST!
summary: It carried over none of the beauty the game offered.

reviewText: You know I knew this was based on a video game of the same name but never played it so I really wasn't sure what to expect. So I'll give you a quick summary of the plot. Rose(Radha Mitchell) takes her sleepwalking daughter sharon to the place she keeps mentioning; Silent Hill. On her way there(after running from the law) she gets into a minor car accident and wakes up and discovers Sharon is missing and goes to find her in the ash clouded town of Silent Hill.O.k. the town of Silent hill is like a roach motel for people, they check in but don't check out. Once entered in Silent Hill, I didn't get the feeling of Forbodding right away, it was more dreamscapey and mysterious. By day Silent hill is foggy with ash falling from the sky like snow, and at night(Heralded by air raid horns from the church) its transformed into Hell, and quick.  The transformation of Silent Hill happens right before your eyes, and the effect are pretty good. This Hellish realm looks like who ever created it(for the film and I'm sure the video game) took page from Clive Barkers Hellraiser. Or from his Tortured Souls action figure line. Hell in Silent hill is a twisted place filled with disfigured abominations galore, burnt mutants, creepy crawlies and one big Mutha of a Hell enforcer, walk tall and carry  big--no no scratch that a Huge Sword.This film had a lot of interesting camera angles.  Shot looking down at the characters. Wide pans on a tilt to show the vastness of some of the interiors, and some cool composites showing stuff in the foreground and in the distance. To me some of these scenes look as if they could have a comic book border around them. The only thing missing was the caption bubbles.  For those of you looking to be scared, you know, stuff jumping out at you, loud noises and such, forget it, its not that type of film. It is however a creepy film. Once things are revealed to you it starts to get under your skin.And for those of you looking to check out the Gore in this movie, yes there is some gore, its not gratuitous as some other films. However, some of the gore effects that take place near and around the end of the film are pretty twisted even if they are computer generated.Sean Bean is in this film as Chis De Silva Roses' husband, while she is looking for the Daughter Sharon, He is looking for Rose, and there is an interesting juxtaposition between the real world and the Purgatory that is the Ghost town of Silent hill, as they are both in the same place, but not together.  Alice Krige plays Claudia, leader of the Silent hill moral majority who is more like a witch hunter than anything else.  I thought she did a great job creepy religious fanatic, those of you who can't place what other horror movie she was in may remember her in "Sleepwalkers" as the creepy shapeshifting  Mother who hates cats.  Laurie Holden plays officer Cybil Bennet, cool character.You may remember her as Debbie, Ben Grimms Girl in the beginning of the Fantastic Four.(or not)I imagine that the time rose spent investigating the town had something to do with the Video game.  That, I thought was the only thing that was slow in this movie, not uninteresting, just a little slow. I would have like to seen some more of the horrors that the night time brought out, because those scenes were pretty damn cool.Bottom Line.....highly entertainig, Excellent visuals. This ones a keeper.
summary: Silent Hill.....Stylish surreal horror, a sick pleasure to watch.

reviewText: Given the trailers I'd seen and the creepy radio commercials I'd heard for this movie, I was expecting a fairly freaky viewing experience, yet I was also expecting to be let down, somewhat. Most times I'm expecting a movie to be disturbing, it turns out that the hype is highly overstated.Silent Hill starts out and it feels as though they are forcing the storyline a bit.. It has a deliberate and unexplained feeling to it, which isn't necessarily bad- so I gave it a chance, but I wasn't hopeful. The daughter, Sharon, talks about Silent Hill while sleepwalking and the husband doesn't think to research it until after the mother, Rose, has already taken Sharon to find the mysterious town. Along the way, Rose ditches a cop who is attempting to pull her over - another plot point that seems unnecessary.Ok, so Rose crashes the car and awakens to learn that Sharon is missing. It snows ashes in Silent Hill- and it appears to be uninhabited... or so it would seem... dun dun dunnnn.Rose seems to be a bit too calm and collected while underground, looking for Sharon beneath the streets of Silent Hill. Finally, a freaky scene... Rose stumbles upon a man that has been disemboweled, but remains alive, hanging on a fence. Then, we finally see the "ghouls" of the mysterious town, as they close in and swarm Rose. They seem to be people made of ashes, if that makes any sense. The CGI is very apparent for these characters and I didn't find them to be particularly creepy or disturbing. Pretty cheesy.The father follows, now a day behind Rose and Sharon, to Silent Hill. The movie gets stranger, but not too much more interesting. The pace is very slow. I realize that this was done deliberately, but it does drag along. The next good scene occurs outside of the church, as the townspeople who suddenly appear out of nowhere flee for refuge from the "darkness". The demon of darkness is a bad mofo, and this scene is gruesome, although brief.Here, inside the church, is where the ridiculous story begins to unfold. A story of religious fanatics and claims of witchery. The story is eventually fed to you (done in replay style, where you're shown grainy footage of what happened in the town's "dark" past). This feels like a copout, as I was hoping this revelation would be far more dramatic.The climax of the movie is gory and I would say it's pretty decent. The effects are also noteable, but I was honestly not impressed with the movie. I had a difficult time feeping my interest focused, even though this movie, I thought, would be right up my alley.
summary: "Honey, sometimes when you go to sleep you talk about a place"

reviewText: Based on the popular video game series which in most cases is a "destined to fail" situation, SILENT HILL does what seemingly no other video game adaptation has been able to perform and that is to make a feature film that stands alone outside of it's predecessors without leaving the uninitiated viewers without feeling like they arer missing part of the story due to lack of playing the games.Starring Radha Mitchell (Pitch Black, Man on Fire) and Sean Bean (Fellowship of the Rings, National Treasure) SILENT HILL takes one on a disturbing adventure through a town rotting in mysteries and plagued by it's own actions.  The film is a little slow at the start but culminates in one of the most intense and bloodiest endings in cinema in the past few years.SILENT HILL is definitely not a film for the timid or the easily scared...so enter at your own risk!!!
summary: You may enter, but you may never leave

reviewText: An excellent portrayal of how people can be terrorized into committing horrible crimes. Being an atheist I often wondered what it would be like to be branded as a heretic and burned alive at the stake by the church like what has happened throughout history. I wonder no more -- This movie did an excellent job of portraying just that. One might counter "we don't burn people at the stake anymore and beside this was only a movie -- this is the 21st century. WRONG. In 1952 a man was burned at the stake in Spain. Also a pacifist I again wonder how one could forgive a church who did things like this to their children. There seems to be no limit to the cruelty portrayed in this movie and its parallel to real life. It reminds me of the brazen bull; a device used during the beginning of the Christian era in which whole families including children were placed inside and roasted to death. I would like to believe these are isolated incidents and this sort of rare event could not happen to me or another person who disagrees with a church or religion. But then who wants to be part of a rare event that ends their life by being burned to death.

reviewText: Not being a fan of the video game that inspired this movie, I must admit I found it visually stunning but ultimately confusing and empty.  From reading other reviews, some of the enormous plot holes make sense, but if a movie isn't honest enough to let all viewers know what's going on, then has it achieved its goal as entertainment?The sets, atmosphere and effects are marvelous, but the performances are lacking, with the exception of Alice Krige as the nutty spiritual leader.  But once again, we have yet another movie in which a demonic little girl wants to possess another innocent little girl.  Been there, done that, and frankly I wish writers would come up with something a little more inventive.

reviewText: Somewhere in the early '90s, a Hollywood suit said to another, "Why don't we make a movie of this," while playing a round of Super Mario Bros. From there on out, moviegoers were 'fortunate' enough to have blockbuster video game adaptations every other year that usually fell under people's acclaim.Resident Evil or Doom, anyone?Roger Avary, one of Hollywood's braniacs and the one responsible for a little-known screenplay called Pulp Fiction, took on the job to adapt this year's video game film release, Silent Hill. The table was certainly sturdy, and all the right cards were laid out - especially when director Christophe Gans (Brotherhood of the Wolf) signed on to direct.However, the idea of a movie left an unsettling effect in my stomach. Silent Hill is by far the most terrifying video game to have ever graced a console. The game already borrows a handful of aspects from past films or literature (e.g. Jacob's Ladder and H.P Lovecraft, respectively) and in itself was a movie. The reason for a film fell under the jaw-dropping question, "Why?"Both Gans and Avary have taken the mood, feeling, and scenery of Silent Hill and literally culled it from the game's platform. There are angles, characters and even set designs that are down to the T. The only problem is there is too much, even coming from such a simple storyline.Once upon a time...Rose, played by the gorgeous Radha Mitchell, decides to bring an end to Sharon's (her foster child) horrible dreams by driving to the abandoned, ghost town of Silent Hill. Along the way, Rose and Sharon bump heads with a do-gooder cop named Cybil. After a near death car chase between the two parties, Rose awakens after the car accident in the infamous town to no daughter and a mysterious fog. What lies behind the fog is for Rose to find out and the audience to wonder.Silent Hill follows the premise of the original 1999 game. Over the past seven years there have been four games from the series, and the downfall of the film is combining each and every element from those games. Everything is there in the film, which happens to be the major predicament. In fact, characters from the original film are split into two or three separate characters all revolving around a plot that becomes misconstrued and highly interchangeable by the film's finale.It's almost like Mortal Kombat: Annihilation all over again.Only here, Gans directs phenomenally. The sound effects are revolting and the special effects are minimal, something any director today should take note of. Silent Hill is, in fact, the same Silent Hill any gamer will remember playing on that old console years ago. Avary is no doubt a fanatic of the game, as all the choices the characters make are nearly the same as the average gamer's. I found myself jokingly saying, "Maybe they should save soon." It's a simple point A to point B which can bring out point C, kind of like the regular jokes in Family Guy.One major setback is the total waste of Sean Bean's performance. His side story involves him looking for his wife, Rose, and the result is something interesting yet highly unnecessary. Instead, Avary should have stuck with the game's original design and kept the lead a male. Bean's the better of any actor attached to the film and is yet swept unnoticed. The film would have worked inordinately better with him in the starring role. Instead, the film borrows from any modern day horror film and features the distraught female lead with the creepy child that loves to draw fast (e.g. The Ring, The Ring 2, The Amityville Horror 2005, Dark Water, The Grudge, etc.).In areas where the film works, the storyline disrupts - so much so that you literally wonder when it will end. It starts out fresh and then somewhere around the middle, when dozens of Puritans ruin the isolated feeling of the picture, the film takes a nosedive. This is when I suggest that you walk out satisfied rather than confused and bored.Gans and Avary were close with this, so close that it's probably the best video game adaptation to date. Nevertheless, with plot holes and an abundance of unnecessary plot or character angles, the film fizzles flat. I suggest spending 10 bucks and buying the original game, turning off the lights, and playing it while you're sleepy.
summary: Try to sit still in "Silent Hill", then shut it off halfway through...

reviewText: Silent Hill, Sony Picture's adaptation of the popular videogame series, continues the entertainment industry's introspective exploration of disaffected and disempowered children, masquerading as dispossessed spirits, desperate to redress insidious abuses, sometimes at the expense of a parent's life.The film opens with Rose Da Silva's (Radha Mitchell) gambit to take her daughter, Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) to the enigmatically titled West Virginia town, against the wishes of her husband, Christopher (Sean Bean), in the hope of finding a spiritual cure for Sharon's mysterious illness. Its onslaught has conjured ominous bouts of sleepwalking, delirious repetition of ''Silent Hill,'' disconcerting memory lapses, and brutal artwork, all threatening to have Sharon institutionalized.En route, Rose and Sharon hazard upon an instinctively suspicious police officer, Cybil Bennett (Laurie Holden).  Keen on following the pair into Silent Hill, after a brief encounter in nearby Brahams, the parties are caught off guard by the apparition of a young girl that figures prominently in their separate roadside accidents. Rose ''awakens'' to find Sharon missing. Flustered, she ventures into Silent Hill, on foot, where she believes she has glimpsed her. What she encounters there defies rational explanation. After reuniting with an infuriated Cybil, they navigate a labyrinth of streets and buildings in a dimensionally fractured environment that is enshrouded by powerful metaphysical themes, worthy of some of the best-canvassed creations of the late surrealist, Salvador Dali. Quarantined thirty years ago by Toluca County officials, Silent Hill still smolders as a noxious, ashen hell made more menacing by the shadowy din that periodically transfigures it, heralded by a bellowing siren atop the town's Church. The original coal fire destroyed countless lives-some less innocent than others-and its victims seem to confront Rose and Cybil as badly burnt children, disfigured nurses, contorted corpses, rodent-like insects, and mythical demons--including "Pyramid Head"--a favorite of the videogamers. Most disturbing perhaps, is Silent Hill's cult of fanatical executioners, bloodthirsty witch hunters, led by beguiling Christabella/Valtiel (Alice Krige, in a role that exceeds the menace of her alter persona as Star Trek's Borg Queen).  More said would spoil the film. Notwithstanding, director Christophe Gans, and writers Nicolas Boukhrief and Robert Avery, execute a superbly crafted, and beautifully cinematographed, film with a brilliant flashback that satisfies nearly all questions about the unfolding mystery.Admittedly, I have never played the Silent Hill videogames. Despite witnessing grown adults shudder at its mention, I suspect the filmmakers' desire to gratify the gaming faithful with violent, if not familiar, imagery did the film more harm than good. The excellent ghost story and score that anchors Silent Hill deserves intellectual play in the disquieted minds of its filmgoers, not in excessively sadistic screen graphics. Gamers will likely disagree with this analysis, and it certainly is not my intention to begrudge them of their joy, but the film's over-reliance on visual mayhem eclipses the truly fine performances of the actors, and truncates constructive narrative and back-story that could have advanced the film's intriguing esoteric, social, psychological, and religious themes. The "monsters" and avatars that the protagonists defeat or heed in Silent Hill are metaphors for the less savory in society who impose, or taunt us through, corrosive cultural constraints, institutional obstacles, and personal dilemmas that can corrupt our sense of right and wrong, dissolve the lines between good and evil, and fail our better judgment. Those who are most malevolent threaten the collective good, which has taken the form of a lost and abused little girl in Silent Hill. Falsely accused of the "sins" of her mothers, she is to be sacrificed on the altar of heresy. The real fear in the film is the doubt we have in the protagonists' ability to save her, and keep other loved ones safe and alive, away from the fiery precipice.Inspired performances abound. Rahda Mitchell, as the emotionally distraught mother of a terminally ill child, connects with her on screen daughter and husband, and viewers alike. Sean Bean's frustration as an alienated husband, perniciously thwarted by a disingenuous detective, Thomas Gucci--whom actor, Kim Coates, seasons to perfection with small town mindedness--is genuinely believable. Laurie Holden indelibly impresses us as an abrasive, tough motorcycle officer, and Jodelle Ferland, like so many gifted child actors and actresses who have been featured, recently, in sinister tales of possession, raises the bar a notch with a truly mesmerizing interpretation that belies her beauty and innocence.

reviewText: I am a massive Silent Hill fan. In the past year, my brother and I have played through all of the games in the series and we love them. We've owned the Silent Hill film adaptation for a long time and I was excited to watch it after having finally immersed myself in the world of Silent Hill.One of my favorite things about the film, and something I think is so important to note, is that they use a LOT of tracks from the games in the soundtrack. You get that intense, paranoid feeling while watching the movie because you had those feelings while playing the games and hearing that heavy, industrial music. Akira is a genius and I'm thrilled that they included his scores in the film.I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. I'm surprised that so many people dislike it. The only qualm I have is that the lead character in this is a woman - the girl's mother - while, in the first game, it's a man - the girl's father. But really, the changes are so minor, I don't think it's worth letting it ruin the experience.While watching, we could point out things we remembered from the games, particular scenes that were wonderfully grotesque, just as the games were. I think, as far as video game adaptations go, this is rather stellar. It stays true to the series, includes many of the infamous creatures (The Nurses, Pyramid Head - who's massively overrated and barely even in the games, anyway, but is, for whatever reason, a fan favorite), and the ending is, I think, brilliant.I have my reservations about the sequel, as it deviates a LOT from the third game (which is what it's mostly based on, following the daughter from the first game), but I'm still looking forward to seeing it, especially after enjoying this movie so much. If you're not a fan of the games, you may not like the film, and I think that's understandable. But Silent Hill is an incredible place, and this movie portrays is exquisitely.

reviewText: Silent Hill achieved the 'Best Video game to movie' tag in my opinion...Which considering what it was up against with all due respect, wasn't that difficult!However, it is a good movie. It's just one of those movies which sadly could have been better. The hype, the anticipation, from Silent Hill fans like myself waiting for this movie was unbelievable. And once I got to see it, I did have mixed feelings.It starts wonderfully, and the imagery throughout is fantastic. Somewhere through the middle though it loses it a little and forgets it's a 'Silent Hill' movie/story, and tries too hard to tie loose ends.It's not bad-I wanted this movie to be fantastic and mess with my mind like the original PS1 game did...but expected it to be awful. In the end it landed somewhere in the middle with a movie I like but felt wasn't quite there. If you like the game, and you like the horror movie genre, go in with an open mind and you should find a movie you enjoy as a watchable but not a classic flick.

reviewText: This film meanders for a while in its attempts at spookiness and possibly also trying to satisfy video game fans--though I must admit that this movie convinced me that playing the game would be nothing more than playing _Resident Evil_ with another title.  The images at times are indeed spooky, though the mystery itself lingers for a while in appearing to be a typical movie of good vs. evil.What peaked my interest about this movie is that the mystery ISN'T typical, but takes an intriguing and well thought-out turn...but the film takes about an hour to get to that turn, and by that time I was already considering popping the DVD out of my player.  The film fortunately doesn't follow the bad horror-movie formula of taking forever to get to the creepy stuff, but it doesn't really present its most interesting aspects soon enough and could alienate viewers who might get a lot out of this by simmering too long in an appearance of plain-old horror.The movie starts out with a young mother (Rose) taking her adopted daughter (Sharon) to Silent Hill, West Virginia, because Sharon has been sleepwalking regularly and naming that town, though she has no memory of any of this.  At Silent Hill, Rose gets into an accident when a mysterious girl crosses her path.  When she wakes, Sharon is gone, but one of her drawings is left behind as a clue...and so Rose wanders into Silent Hill, a haunted town with a secret...It sounds as though the rest of the film would follow a typical horror-film plot: evil things prove to reside in Silent Hill and try to keep Rose from Sharon, but her devotion to her daughter triumphs in the end.The above is true in spirit, but exactly what is 'evil' in this movie becomes a pertinent question, as well as what proper justice is, as Silent Hill proves to have a more complex secret than most horror movies will care to explore.  Even Rose's devotion as a mother has its own price, but as I said before, its most interesting aspects don't present themselves until the second hour.  For what this film does by the end, I would give 4 stars, but its misguided beginning hour knocks the movie down a star in my estimation.Well worth a watch...just don't put too much stock in the first hour.A sad moment of this movie was to find out that Alice Krige does indeed age--Krige was the SCORCHING hot horror chick of the 80's with _Ghost Story_, and then to re-emerge as the Borg Queen in _Star Trek: First Contact_--that made ME want to be assimilated.  No doubt, she looked great for a woman in her early 50's, and she was by no means playing a sex symbol (which, let's face it, would have been creepy, since she was a puritanical religious leader), but still...to see her showing signs of age is just another reminder of my own mortality.
summary: 3-star review for what could have been a 4-star movie

reviewText: We awaited this movie with anticipation only to be VERY dissapointed.Hollywood......PAY ATTENTION..... $50 Million in special effects and $10 dollars of plot, screenplay and acting do NOT make a good memorable movie!This film is a textbook example of wasted potential..The set designs were great.. the atmosphere building was great.... the general premise was great........ after that it all falls apart.What we get is 2 hours of a woman running around in a maze of CGI and set designs trying to act scared and frantic.The actual images of what are supposed to be horrible are choppy, brief and incohesive.Never is a feeling of dread or actual horror created..... a simple scene of a blood-soaked (ex-family member) now-turned Zombie walking slowly towards a lone person trapped in the corner of a basement evokes infinitely more tension and suspense than anything in this film.MILD SPOILER ALERT......The plot here is basically a mish-mash of elements tossed together ranging from vengeful spirits, old West Virginia relegious fanatisicm, overgrown cockroachs, super powerful humanoids, etc....Basically it all become comical after awhile.If the plot had stayed focused along the line of a "ghost town" destroyed by fire and a "crossover" visit, then that would have been cool.But what we get here instead is "fiery ghost town meets videogame DOOM with some Deliverance tossed in".... it all erodes into forgetability.A real shame.... based on previews (which are misleading as to storyline).... we thought this was going to be a winner.

reviewText: Anyone familiar with the Silent Hill video games knows that Konami's horror franchise manages to pack in an awesomely eerie atmosphere with a somewhat lacking storyline.  While that isn't such a bad thing in the video game world, when it comes to film, well, that's not really a good combination.  Christophe Gans (Brotherhood of the Wolf) directs the film adaptation of Silent Hill with Roger Avary (Pulp Fiction, Rules of Attraction) screenwriting, and the film is a faithful interpretation of the game series, but that's not always a good thing as we soon learn.  Radha Mitchell (Man on Fire, Pitch Black) plays a desperate mother searching for her missing daughter in the ghost town of Silent Hill, and wouldn't you know it that all kinds of ultra creepy things start happening?  Sean Bean plays her clueless husband searching for her whereabouts outside the town, and Deborah Kara Unger and Alice Krige are along for the ride as well, but they are clearly having more fun relishing in just how laughable this film is.  That being said, though the film's storyline is practically incomprehensible, the look of the film under Gans' incredibly stylish direction really is a sight to behold.  The CGI effects and makeup work are very well done as well, which is a shame because had Avery maybe added a little more to the story, Silent Hill could have been something special besides being another lame video game to film adaptation (but at least this didn't get stuck with Uwe Boll).  That being said, Silent Hill is worth seeing for it's ultra stylistic look and feel, but that's pretty much it.
summary: Spectacular effects and visuals can't make up for weak storyline
Title: N/A

reviewText: _Silent Hill_ is an extremely bizarre film which features a woman and her daughter caught up in a nightmare world of demons, witches, and a fanatical cult.  The film begins with the mother, Rose, and her daughter, Sharon, at a time when Sharon is experiencing bizarre dreams and hallucinations.  Sharon repeatedly mentions a place called "Silent Hill" in her dream state, and her adoptive mother decides to take her there to cure her of her apparent psychic conflict.  As it turns out Silent Hill is an old ghost town, and as the two drive towards it leaving the girl's adoptive father behind, a series of bizarre occurrences take place.  The mother is pulled over by a police officer but drives away.  Later, they have an accident while nearing Silent Hill, and when the mother awakes her daughter has disappeared.  The mother becomes frantic and begins running through the town searching for her daughter, who appears to be running from her.  However, it is while in the town that the mother begins to encounter various strange and dark secrets.  Apparently there are evil forces loose in this town and mysterious dark creatures begin to besiege her.  Running from these creatures, the mother returns to her car only to find the police officer waiting for her.  The officer arrests her; however, soon it becomes apparent that the two of them must do battle with the forces of darkness.  The setting for this film is very dark and evil, and the influence of the demonic is felt at every turn.  While battling these wicked forces and searching for her daughter, the mother and the police officer encounter witches and crazed women.  Ultimately they are led to a cult of strange fanatics who hold a dark secret.  Apparently a great evil has been unleashed upon this town, stored up for many years in the body of a girl who was burned as a witch.  From there the movie becomes even more bizarre and ultimately the mother must encounter the demon by herself after fleeing from the fanatics.  The movie features dark deformed creatures, a knife wielding demon, witch burnings, a split self, and an all-around dark atmosphere and setting which is extremely well-done.  The ending includes a twist and an ultimate mystery that remains unsolved.  For more than anything else, this film is to be recommended for its dark atmosphere which is sure to provide a frightening experience of the dark side.  For those who bravely face head on the dark nature of things, this movie is sure to offer not only a source of entertainment but also a thoughtful look into both the dangers of fanaticism and the darkness of profound hatred.  Enjoy!
summary: Darkness, Demons, Fanatics, Witches, and the Source of All Evil.

reviewText: For a truly unique film experience check out "Silent Hill". As a fan of the games I expected to be impressed but anyone looking for innovative filmmaking and extraordinary (WOW) production design should find this film fascinating. I am firmly convinced that Gans and Avery have hit a home run here.For those who have never seen the game, "Silent Hill" is the best ever survival/ horror game series. It is difficult and confusing (a lot of mazes and D&D-like; details) so expect major disorientation at times during the film-which is a bit like actually playing the game.The acting was convincing, the editing extraordinary, and the atmosphere oppressive. Not 100% how I visualized it before viewing but even the differences tended to work in favor of the film.The town itself looked and actually felt familiar, unlike the mess they made of "House of Wax". This is definitely the sort of film best seen on the big screen with a theater sound system. Everyone should be totally creeped out.Enough said, more at this stage might spoil things so read on only if you have already seen the film or if you don't mind some spoilers.Dahlia Gillespie had a daughter (by an unknown father) named Alessa. Alessa became the town outcast until a bunch of religious nuts (led by Christabella) decided she was a witch and must be sacrificed to keep evil out of Silent Hill. Dahlia went along with this because she was afraid of her own damnation for having the child. But the ceremony went wrong and the nutcases were not just killed but sent to a netherworld between heaven and hell.The dark side of Alessa ended up in the same place but she was split into duel entities and the good part stayed in the normal world where she was adopted by Rose and Chris, and named Sharon. Sharon's sleepwalking is caused by her connection with Alessa who wants her to return to Silent Hill.On the way to Silent Hill, Rose and Sharon arouse the suspicions of a motorcycle policewoman (Cybil Bennett). This happens because Cybil has been extremely protective of children since she saved a little boy from a psychopath. Cybil follows them to Silent Hill (once a coal mining town that was abandoned because of a burning seam of coal under the town). At the town limits a mysterious girl appears and both vehicles crash. When Rose and Cybil regain consciousness Sharon is gone.As they explore the abandoned buildings they discover a church with a warning siren where the religious cult hides when Alessa (presumably) causes a darkness to take over the town; for some reason the darkness and Alessa cannot enter the church. It turns out that Alessa sent her Sharon identity back into the world of the living to bring back someone (Rose) who can take her into the church where she can finally exact her revenge.Everyone is dead in the netherworld of Silent Hill, even Rose and Cybil-they don't know it yet but they died in the accident-because you can only enter the town if you are dead. Alessa needs Rose which is why she died, it was just Cybil's bad luck to have been involved in the accident.The tip off to their being parallel towns comes when Rose's husband Chris enters the real Silent Hill and finds nothing supernatural in the place; although he senses a connection with his wife and adopted daughter, he finds no tangible sign of them. Rose passes right through him and the ending scene of Rose and Sharon in their home is blurred, but the scene with Chris in the parallel home is completely clear.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

reviewText: Silent Hill is a very good example that good games can be translated into a movie without losing its essence. I've played every Silent Hill game that has been released, so when I first heard rumors of a movie I had mixed feelings. Very few games can make acceptable movies. Besides Resident Evil 2: Apocalypse, I can't think of any other example. Don't let this fool you, Silent Hill manages to grasp the creepy atmosphere that was so characterstical of the games, especially the first one. The story is very similar to the original game, with certain adpatations that really work out for the big screen. The music, the surroundings, every step taken in the movie makes you remember every step taken while playing the game a few years ago. The foggy streets, the school, the strange characters. It's all there! I can say I'm really pleased to see one of my favorite games ever turned into a really good movie. Silent Hill will definitely scare you and confuse you. Things are never the same after being in Silent Hill.

reviewText: A little girl named Sharon has been sleepwalking and having nightmares of a place called Silent Hill.  Her mother, Rose, takes Sharon to see the ghost town to try to figure out the cause of these dreams.  When the arrive in Silent Hill, Sharon disappears and Rose must fight her way through gruesomely disfigured people to find her daughter.  But she uncovers much more about the abandoned town.Silent Hill is not a movie for everyone.  It basicly has the plot of a video game.  Very straight forward: The daughter gets lost and the mom has to find her while fighting her way through monsters.  The plot is fairly slow moving but worth it.  The special effects are very cool (although not necessarily the best) and there are some very gory scenes for horror buffs like myself.  The mutants are crazy looking.  They look like something straight out of the video game.  I'd certainly recommend this movie to anyone who has played the games or enjoys video game based movies.  This is one that I will probably eventually add to my library of DVDs.
summary: A thin plot, but good for horror movie buffs.

reviewText: Silent Hill is a movie based on a video game.Still reading? Good, because you will be pleasantly surprised to learn that, unlike every other video game-based movie ever made, this is a great film!  And it's a great film that fans of the game can enjoy as well as moviegoers who never heard of the game (or who have been offended by the drek that usually comes to the theaters in the guise of video game movies).Silent Hill is a ghost town that was abandoned in the seventies because of an underground coal fire and now haunts the nightmares of a little girl. In an attempt to help her adoptive daughter Sharon (Jodelle Ferland), Rose (Radha Mitchell) takes her to Silent Hill and enters a nightmare-like alternate reality. Going any further into the plot would spoil the surprises in this film and the surprises are part of the fun.The creatures that inhabit this alternate Silent Hill are very disturbing and nightmarish and they move in a very fluid way that is both familiar and strange at the same time. Seeing them in action (and, unlike most horror films, in full lighting) causes an almost immediate flight or fight reaction until the rational side of your brain remembers that it's only a movie.Also on the plus side is the music of Silent Hill. Very creepy, very fitting, and, very good; at least half of the reason this film works so well is because the music and sound effects do so well in conveying the sense that something is moving just beyond your vision.There is a downside to the film and it occurs almost dead center in the film. The beginning and ending of the movie is rife with psychological-based horror, and creatures dredged up from the depths of nightmares. But the middle is where we get an explanation for what's going on and it's a jarring change of pace that, thankfully, doesn't last too long.But the rest of the film makes up for that one pacing stutter and the entire film comes together in a great conclusion that may or may not hint at a sequel.Silent Hill also accomplished two very important things; it proves that a video game can be successfully translated into a great film, and it restored my faith in the horror genre' by giving me real chills without resorting to cheap tricks.A must see!
summary: My faith in the horror genre' was waning until...
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was an interesting experience for me as it's the first time I've ever been in the position of a videogame fanboy seeing a movie adaptation of something I've gotten really into.  Considering the overall history of videogame movie adaptations, I was worried, but considering how cinematic Silent Hill was, I figured it wouldn't be that difficult to pull off.  However, when I saw the trailer and noticed that there would be a side-story involving people outside Silent Hill, I was heavily disappointed because one of the key things that makes Silent Hill the game so great is the fact that it feels utterly futile to think of any world outside of it.Well, my disappointment was misfounded, they actually did that sidestory pretty well, and it didn't affect the overall grade of the movie at all.  All in all, this movie exceeded my expectations for it, though it still left me craving for a little more.A big dilemma in the creation of this film is the fact that it seems almost required to hold some of those coded horror-genre elements that tend to be a turn-off to even the average film-goer: horror-film style acting (sure they can scream, but can they pronounce emotion otherwise?), some very campy dialog at points (Cop: "They say this town is haunted."  protagonist: "I think they're right." Audience: "Ughhh..."), and the decision over what would be more scary, to actually show the terrifying elements or allow the audience's imagination to go wild.  Sometimes it was successful, sometimes it wasn't.I can say this about it: it could have used a bit less audio, both in terms of dialog and music.  Sometimes it just felt like the music was making it less scary, and some of the expository dialog was pretty much unnecessary: most of the dialog between the male cop and the husband, or that moment when the protagonist looks at the smudge on her finger and says "Ash..."  Yeah, we know it's ash.  Now on with the imagery and off with the sound!Also, Pyramidhead's appearance was glaringly gratuitous, for no other reason than the plot didn't fully develop his character and thus he was pretty much there for the Silent Hill gamer fan to say, "All right now on with the good stuff!"  It must be noted, however, that it was some very, VERY good stuff, so his appearance wasn't totally wasted.But all in all, it gets enough of the mood, enough of the setting, and enough of the imagery in that it's a pretty decent film.  Enough might not be enough in that I would really like some more...  *HEAVY DUTY SPOILERS HERE* For a film with skin-ripping and barbed-wire raping, it seems to be pretty needlessly reserved in other parts, like pretty much refusing to show the entire crucified janitor *YOU CAN OPEN YOUR EYES NOW*.  I did hear that a lot of the film had to be cut merely to give it an R rating.  Thus, for once in my life, I'm actually more interested to see the Extended and Unrated DVD that inevitably will come out.--PolarisDiB

reviewText: I'm paraphrasing here but Kurosawa once said that if you have a great director, great editor, great cinematographer and a great cast but have a bad script then you will have a bad movie. This film is a great example to back up this statement. This film has some of the best visual effects out there, good editing, good cinematography, occasionally good soundtrack but an absolutely horrible screenplay. What happened? I wish I knew but could only guess that what we saw was the end result of a rough draft. Somewhere hidden in there might have been a good idea and it seems that unless you played the games it might be difficult to pin point exactly what that good idea was.In order for a movie to be good it should not require an outside source (video game, comic book, novel or TV show) to hold it up. Some of the best films out there were based off of another medium, Spiderman 1 and 2, X-MEN 1 and 2, Batman Begins, Lord of the Rings (this list could actually go on forever), I even enjoyed the first Mortal Kombat. Obviously you don't have to agree with the titles I just mentioned, they're just opinions but the point is that these films don't require you to be familiar with the source material. The films actually stand on their own without that familiarity. There's nothing wrong with the director tipping his hat to memorable scenes that originate within the game as a wink towards the fan. What is wrong is when the director is not able to translate the games narrative into film for the non-fans. If he were successful in translating the game into film the non-fans would want to play the game! In this case Gans failed to do just that.Is the movie hard to understand? No, because the main point of the plot, that is, the motivating factor for the characters in the plot is spelled out for you in the last 10 or so minutes of the film in the form of a flash back with running commentary. I can't help but think that the logic behind this plot structure is to make you feel like you've painstakingly played a video game and now you will be rewarded with a reason as to why you have played the game in the first place or why you sat for almost two hours wondering why Rose (the mother character for those who have not seen it yet) didn't take the kid to a doctor instead of taking her to an allegedly haunted town that is to this day burning underneath. The point is that this type of exposition is just plain lazy writing. That kind of information is typically (not always but in this way it is more challenging for the writer and allows for interactivity from the audience) leaked throughout the film with the use of action, dialogue, metaphors so when the payoff happens there is no need for an explanation.Tension is caused by expectation, you expect something terrible to happen based off the clues that have been given to you throughout the course of the film. Sometimes the audience knows more than the main character raising the bar for tension. In other words you know what's coming before the character does causing the audience to scream the typical, "don't go into that room" or "Don't open that door" or just simply scream. Alfred Hitchcock has a better explanation as to how it works but the point is that tension is caused by expectation. Now putting aside the information that the fans are familiar with from the game, the movie itself does not clearly place any clues for the audience to create that tension. The clues that are presented are a mystery in of themselves. Although we eventually learn of the witch hunters origin and eventually, after the infamous flashback, we learn the story of Alessa, without some form of previous information placed earlier in the film it's difficult for most to see any of that coming. Therefore, the director literally has to hold our hands throughout the film for us to understand why anything is happening. But yes, by the end of the film you are TOLD everything and technically you should be able to walk out of the film "getting it". However, in this case, to "get it" was not fun.I'm not going to argue about this being one of the best VG adaptations out there because it probably is. But unfortunately that's not saying much.What I'm saying is I love video games and I really wanted to enjoy this film. Besides, I'm a huge fan of Brotherhood of the Wolf and based on that alone I thought this film was going to be great. I thought it was going to do for video games what X-MEN and Spiderman was doing for comics, people were finally going to look at it as a serious form of entertainment and not a mindless activity that most critics have labeled it as such. Unfortunately, in this case it did not do any of those things. Even worse, it seems, based on the number of the games fan responses in this forum, the film has isolated itself to the entertainment of only them, thereby alienating itself from the rest of the public and some are okay with this! That's not a good thing and you fans of the game should know that money ultimately rules this industry. If this film does not profit it will scare off the studios from not only making sequels of this movie but ultimately making future adaptations of other games. And there are a lot of games out there that deserve to be made into films.
summary: Another video game adaptation gone down the toilet and believe me I'm not happy about that

Being a fan of the series I was satisfied with the movie, It was a whole load better than the Resident Evil movie.

reviewText: SILENT HILLI'm going to forget that this was based on a series of videogames for a minute, and for one simple reason: I love the games; therefore, my expectations of this film would kill its chances ever before we get to looking at 'Silent Hill' as a movie in its own right. What I'm going to tell you about instead is 'Silent Hill', a standalone new horror movie.Rose and Christopher Da Silva's daughter Sharon is in trouble: prone to extreme bouts of sleepwalking and night terrors, she keeps crying out the name of a town near to the orphanage where she was adopted: Silent Hill. With her medications not working and her parents at their wits' end, desperate mom Rose decides a return trip to Silent Hill is in order. Going against Christopher's wishes, she meets and angers a cop named Cybil Bennett, shortly before crashing her car. Coming to, she notices that her daughter is nowhere to be found, and must plumb the depths of the abandoned town in order to find her child.Actors in 'Silent Hill' are a VERY mixed bunch: while Radha Mitchell does a good job in the role of Rose, Laurie Holden works very well as Cybil Bennett and Alice Krige is great as cult leader Christabella, the rest of the cast are either throwaway and forgettable (Sean Bean as Christopher, Tanya Allan as Anna and Kim Coates as Officer Gucci), or just plain bad (Joelle Ferland's performance is overstated and hammy, there are better child actors around; and all of the cult members just plain stink - they behave like stock players from a 1970s B-Movie).Things are not helped by an oftentimes unintentionally funny script: lines like "Look at me! I'm burning! ", or "Burn the Witch! " made me giggle to myself in the theatre - and in a movie that layers on the atmosphere as thickly as 'Silent Hill', this is a real problem. When the dialogue isn't pedestrian, as it almost always is, it's just plain outlandish. It's not a good script, it's not even always mediocre: sometimes, it's so bad that you have to laugh.This disparity continues with the storyline. What essentially begins as an isolated no-way-out plot is very quickly dampened by the introduction of more and more human characters. The cult members and their campy, Monty Python-style howlings (I kept expecting one or more of them to yell "Build a bridge out of her!!" when Christabella was denouncing Sharon as a Witch) remove all of the carefully-crafted sense of tension and isolation, instead turning the second half of 'Silent Hill' into a cheap 'Wicker Man' clone. Why bother having a deserted town, and building the plot and pacing on the back of a handful of central characters, when you're going to turn around towards the climax of the movie and remove these elements? The end of 'Silent Hill' loses its momentum badly, and, while the closing scenes are creepy, they can't rescue the overall impression of the movie as disjointed.The real star of 'Silent Hill' is the Production Design. Carol Spier has created a beautifully eerie background of deserted schools, churches and hotels against which the story is played out. But, as with the plot and the actors, the bad elements of this movie overpower the good, and sadly, Christophe Gans' extremely heavyhanded use of unnecessary special effects and cheap-shock camera shots does the gorgeous 'real' visuals a huge disservice. Case in point: the Janitor monster is a guy in a rubber suit, okay. It's unsettling to look at, moves in a very effective way and is generally a great visual element that adds to the fear of the scene he's in. Then along comes the computer-generated mess o' special effects and masks totally the creepy subtleties of the figure, until all we can see are obvious computer animations pumping away in the fore and middle grounds, and the fear is lost: put simply, we cannot see the scary wood for the humdrum trees.And it's a real shame. What could have been a great horror movie, a 'Wicker Man' for this generation - interesting premise, mostly solid central performances from the lead actors and a rare attention to set detail - is undone by its own frankly boring and unoriginal special effects, and many script and story problems that needed serious rethinking.For fans of the videogame: There's plenty in-jokes and references to the series, but Gans seems to have overlooked two vital elements that, at least for me, define the wonderful and original kind of fear you find in the games. One, you can see everything in all its gory detail: the sense of isolation and what-the-hell-is-that is totally lost to a too-big cast roster and flashy, cheap CGI. And two, the vibrant and distinct characterisation of the games is lost here to a boring script and generic stock players. Dahlia looks and acts like Tina Turner's Mad Max 3 character, had she been on smack. My favourite bubble-head nurses look like solar-power Michael Jackson's Thriller rejects, and Pyramid Head was not what he should have been. The cockroach storm and the skin-tearing scenes? Just another OTT example of the worst excesses of this movie.All in all, this is at best a mediocre horror movie with brief glimpses of interesting things, ruined by an over-the-top reliance on cgi effects, and a poor script. Not really worth your while; rental will be enough for most of you.

reviewText: As a little girl expieriences life like dreams, and periodically sleep walks and screams "Silent hill!" one might get either a small chill, or a slight giggle at the opening sequence... the rest is, well...Silent hill is an exelent game series, full of chilling and unrelenting fearful sights, sounds, and expieriences. The one thing most people dont realize however, is that Silent hill plays off of the fact that there will always be more quiestions than answers. Don't watch this movie and expect to get the plot the first time around. In fact, dont ever intend to watch and understand, it just sinmple wasnt meant to be, which is why there are 4 games to date [and with the movie, im sure its creator's are thinking up of another one].in contrast to the many "Horror" genre films out there, this movie is finally unique [much like the game]. It's not a slasher, suspense, or mindless scary movie, it's all three. Forget the Ring, Amittiville horror, the grudge, white noise, and any other movies that were supposed to be scary these past two or three years, this one is in a league all of its own... alone.The plot, as you can deciefer in the first few seconds of watching the trailor, is about the main character [a woman who seems incredabily determind to do things her way] frantically searching for her daughter in a place called... yes you guessed it, Silent Hill. Other than that, the plot doesnt really change, sure there are a few hints and clues and climaxs telling you just what the heck's going on, but the underlying "why" of Silent Hill will illude you throughout and even into the ending credits. All in all, original for the way it is shown, and the sights and sounds of it all. Even the music can get creepy at times, now if only they did that more...This is the best adaptation ive ever seen to a video game. Even the feel and sounds make you remember the game as you watch, and while a movie will never amount to a video game, this movie got really close, but...there are a few lacking points as a FILM. For one, while many viewers may find the constant running and gasping of the main character as she runs around trying to find her daughter a bit repedative, this comprises 50% of the game play in the game... however, there is a hightend sense in the game, as you never know when something's going to try and eat, mutilate, bite, suck, or decapitate you. The movie however didn't produce such a feeling of paranoia, more like a few scenes here and there.For those of you who think Sean Bean's name means something in this film, sadly it does not. His character is a bit wasted [oops, did i say that out loud?], however, the way the movie was shown and set up, it's almost like they were deliberate in this action, as if a sequal was being made next. If not, then... Sean Bean was basically an extra. Don't get me wrong he displays exelent acting, however, he just isnt part of the action.If you havn't played the game, you might not understand it, but you may come away either totally apalled that you paid to see it/rent it/buy it due to the fact it just wasn't scary at all and you found it quiet funny [as i did the grudge and the ring], or you may think it was genienly scary enough to invite a friend next time. beware, this is a sixth sense type of movie, once you've seen it once, it just isnt th same the second time around, unless you totally forget the plot, or lack thereof.If you've played the game, then lo and behold the first movie based on a vide game that actually makes one want to play the game right after watching it. This isnt the movie that will change how people look at video game based movies, but it is a great step in the right direction [finally]. Now if only producers would get over there imortal terror of producing epic films, with a little extra flare here and there, maybe there would be even better films out there based on video games. Until then, Silent hill should keep you entertained for a little while.In all the movie there was only one scene that i found scary, and it was only because the movie theatre wasnt exacally packed, so i could totally zoom in and watch like i was there. Other than that, it never did get any scarier than that, but i still left the movie theatre and constantly looked over my shoulder once i got home... alone.If you've never heard about Silent Hill and just stumbled upon it at the movie store and rented it, hold on to the buddy beside you, and keep an open mind... and then dive into the video game, it is so much better. This movie is a good door opener to an already popular gaming series, but unless they make another one, and that one is BETTER than the first one, this movie will just be another one on the shelf after a few months.As a little girl expieriences life like dreams, and periodically sleep walks and screams "Silent hill!" one might get either a small chill, or a slight giggle at the opening sequence... the rest is, well... I give it three stars, because Having played two of the games, I know in my heart that the creator's/director... ok, the "whole lot" of people who wrote this movie, could have done much better. All in all, not a lost cause, just sorta...eh...

reviewText: I was introduced to Silent Hill 3 by my roommate, who was a huge horror buff.  He had nearly every horror flick you could imagine, and the games to go with them.  Posters around the room foretold the end of the world.  Yet, all of this combined paled in comparison to the experience of playing Silent Hill 3, which made the grotesque look amicable, and made Jason or Freddy Krueger look like your after-school music teacher (which may be good or bad, depending on your music teacher).  I still remember how, while running through a subway corridor, the green/brown walls all of a sudden began to pulsate and drip with blood, only to return back to the sewage-filled, rusted facade three seconds later upon reaching the end of the cooridor.  We both looked at each other, and said "WTF"!I tell this to the readers who are either new to Silent Hill, or have played the game.  To both readers, the above description is basically the "allure" of this franchise - you will have never seen such displays of utter horror - and this movie will not disappoint.  After watching this movie, all I will say is that I will never think the same way about an air siren again.To the former, it ends there.  The plot is skeletal, enough to justify the amazing scenery, and enough to please gamers who have immersed themselves into Silent Hill lore.  You will not find Oscar-winning acting, nor much rhyme or reason.  You may even be slightly annoyed (as I was) when the screen turns white, and someone begins a narration with "Congratulations..." as if you had just beaten a game, and are watching the ending.  My advice to you is to basically sit back, and prepare for a visual nightmare which has, until now, yet to erupt onto the big screen.To the latter, I really think everything good about the game is in this movie.  The plot may make a little more sense, and the similarities of Sean Bean to the Silent Hill 2 protagonist, and Rosa to the Silent Hill 3 protagonist, are uncanny.  There's even a mention of Alessa and "rebirth", which were central to the plot in 3.  The characteristic "snow" pervades the street-level, and the sick and unforgiving nightmare of the hospital is prominantly displayed.I give this movie 4 stars, and I'll tell a story to justify it:I saw my roommate playing Silent Hill 3, and I still remember him going through the church.  The map, the MAP, out of all things, spooked me so much that when I played it myself, I never got past the hospital.  The map is an innocent child's drawing of the church, and the juxtaposition of that with the climax of the nightmare that is Silent Hill 3 was a bit too much for me.  This movie does not come close to drawing out that kind of response from me - I'm sure due to the mainstream appeal of this movie - and for that reason, I cannot justify giving it a higher rating.  I saw this with both eyes open throughout the entire movie, and outside of those damned air sirens, found myself more fascinated than spooked.  Of course, my opinion may change while watching this movie alone in the dark...

reviewText: I really don't know why a lot of the supposed professional movie reviewers gave this movie such a bad grade if your a fan of the games or not it still was a great horrific movie.  To those who have played Silent Hill 1 through 3 we all know the basics of the storyline and of course with Hollywood producers there are going to be some changes in the movie that differ from the game.  This movie storyline does seem to follow-up with the first except instead of the father you have the mother coming to Silent Hill to try and help her adopted daughter remember her past that she has about Silent Hill.  Again if your a fan and played the game I'm sure we all remembered the Pyramid Head guy from the game he to will also be in the movie as well as a few other recognizable creatures from Silent Hill.  The actors they got to play in the movie were great no complaints for any of them and the special effects were spectacular too.  There is a great deal of difference in the picture detail and audio between the standard dvd an the blu-ray dvdbut I feel it was mostly the audio a lot of background noises and other things you didn't hear before with the standard dvd you hear excellently with the blu-ray dvd.  So if your looking for a good horror movie or a good supernatural movie this one would be a good dvd for your library..

reviewText: The secrets of Silent Hill are buried deep, hidden for years...and if the raw fear it creates to protect them is any indicator, it does not want them to be found.In the world of horror-themed video games, the words 'Silent Hill' have attained special status. The name itself evokes powerful images of foggy, abandoned streets, decaying buildings, and surreal creatures.  No surprise, then, that the movie based on the games made sure to include all of these elements, and to do it well.  The film has its own failings and its own successes, to be sure, but it is most successful in establishing and maintaining the look, feel, and texture of the games.For the most part, the story also remains true to the spirit of the games. It is different in many details, but the themes and emotional resonance is the same. Pervading the film, just as in the games, is an overarching feeling of loss and hopelessness, confusion and panic. Right from the beginning the audience is offset and in unfamiliar territory, and that feeling is only built upon as the story is told.  The story of Silent Hill is always one of reality merging with the darkest of fantasies, and the viewer is left to sort out which is which even as the characters are assailed with discovery after shocking discovery.  Don't be surprised if you are left with more questions by the end of it than answers.While the movie is mostly consistent and delivers well on its potential, there are a few missteps.  Perhaps the most egregious among them is a drawn-out and overdone "big finish" ending, with lots of gory effects and violence geared towards satisfying an audience hungry for blood.  For those few minutes, the subtleties and nuances present until then are gone as a bloodbath ensues.  For those few minutes, what makes the games so great isn't there, and it works against the film too.The movie does recover itself, though, even after the awkward denouement of the action.  Returning once again to the spirit of loss and making an emotional connection that makes the games work so well, the final scenes of 'Silent Hill' are quiet and understated but undeniably creepy, effective, and tragic.  These last few minutes manage to redeem the film and end the story on just the right note -- a low, echoing, lonely note to be sure...but just the way it should end.As films based on video games go, 'Silent Hill' is quite probably the best of the bunch so far.  It maintains (for the most part) the spirit of the game while making a mostly-successful transition to a different medium.  The emotions, the look and feel, and most of all, the fear from the game are all there in the movie.  As scary movies go...well, to be honest, you've probably never seen anything quite like it.  And for that reason alone, it is worth watching.

reviewText: This is a movie that I had hesitated to see. The trailer looked shockingly good, but then again so does every trailer thanks to the highly advanced art of hollywood trickery these days. Additionally, I had never played the video game, and I wasn't sure if it was anything to get excited about. Luckily, my roommate was the one to splurge $20 on it and not me, and I got to see it.Despite the fact that they're churning out video games as fast as they can, most of which are helmed by the repugnant Uwe Boll, this is a solid horror movie. I have no idea how much it lifts either directly or loosely from the game, but it does provide some remarkable visuals and even better ideas. It's not reliant on pure atmosphere like The Ring or any of the J-Horror clones that have become so prominent lately, nor is it just one huge gorefest like the Nightmare on Elm Street series or Friday the 13th. Instead it walks somewhere in the middle while adding a nice adventure element that I'm guessing comes fairly faithfully from the game. It's refreshing that the movie isn't themed to the point that it's a one-trick pony, instead it brings out a new and exciting monster or revelation every so often to keep it fresh.All in all, this movie may not be 5 stars, but it does deserve the title of the best video game movie (or perhaps the only good one) to date.
summary: Not just good for a video game movie, but actually GOOD!
