reviewText: Silent Hill (Christophe Gans, 2006)I hope someone explains this to me, because I don't get it.There are three kinds of people who hated Silent Hill: the people who played the games and found the movie not enough like them; the people who have never played the games and couldn't follow the plot; and the critics, who, as a whole, haven't liked a single horror film in so long that by now it's a knee-jerk reaction. They, too, had a hard time following the plot.What I'm not getting-- how did anyone have a hard time following the relatively straightforward, actually quite simple, plot?Obviously, I can't explain it all to you without spoilers. But, really, folks, has your ability to connect the dots gotten that rusty? If so, I fear for the fate of modern society far more than I did on Friday before about 9:45PM, when I left the theater after seeing what I thought was quite the bang-up little film.I wrote recently, in my review of Slither, that it was one of the best horror films I'd seen in ages. And here we are getting Silent Hill in the same month. It's an embarrassment of riches. It leaves me with the hope, however infinitesimal, that someone in Hollywood has finally grown a brain. Two movies in one month that lead me to revise my position on the death of the American horror movie. Hollywood, I am weeping with joy, and for once, you are the cause. Thank you.Okay, here's what I can tell you. Now, if you saw the movie and couldn't follow along, pay attention. Rose (Visitors' wonderful, and criminally underutilized, Radha Mitchell) and Christopher (The Lord of the Rings Trilogy's Sean Bean) DaSilva have adopted a girl named Sharon (Kingdom Hospital's Jodelle Ferland). She comes from rural West Virginia. Sharon has nightmares, during which she sometimes (a) sleepwalks, and (b) talks about a place called Silent Hill. The condition is getting worse. Rose, in a desperate attempt to get to the bottom of Sharon's condition, decides to take her to Silent Hill, about which Sharon, when awakes, knows/remembers nothing. Christopher is not at all happy with this decision. On the way, Rose and Sharon attract the attention of Cybil (Fantastic Four's Laurie Holden), a local cop who thinks they seem suspicious (she explains why later, and if you found it out of character, folks, you've never lived in places that consider black swampy water potable) and follows them. While running from Cybil, Rose gets into a minor auto accident that knocks her unconscious. When she wakes up, the geography has changed slightly, and Sharon is gone. Rose, now on the outskirts of Silent Hill, must rescue Sharon, while, preferably, avoiding Cybil.If you missed any of that, I'm guessing you weren't paying attention, because all of it was actually explicitly mentioned in the film. In general, each facet of the above summary was mentioned only once, but none of the above summary was stuff I had to use any big leaps of logic for. There are things people have been asking that do require leaps of logic, but those, in general, are more gamer-geek questions than "I didn't get the story" questions. (The most common of these being "why is Pyramid Head in this movie?", one of the few questions being asked about the film that seems to be inspiring intelligent debate. My answer: because it's bloody cool, and Christophe Gans seems to think so, too. The movie doesn't have to be entirely faithful to the game; most film adaptations of books are, shall we say, not faithful. Like, they're cheating harlots.) If you weren't paying attention, don't criticize the film for being hard to follow. Your fault, not that of Gans and Avary.Whom I should mention, though their contributions were, in fact, somewhat mediocre. Director Christophe Gans (Pacte des Loups) and screenwriter Roger Avary (Killing Zoe) did a competent job with their roles. Avary's script was a bit heavy on the exposition, Gans' directing was just heavy. (Though, to be fair, I felt that way about Pacte... as well.) It's cinematographer Dan Laustsen (who also worked with Gans on Pacte...) and monster guy Patrick Tatopoulos (Pitch Black) who really give this film, once it gets going, something to sink one's teeth into.The acting is, well, standard. Which is kind of surprising, given the presences of folks like Mitchell, Bean, Alice Krige, and Deborah Unger. Mitchell takes the Naomi-Watts-in-The-Ring approach to acting (scream at anything that comes near you); Krige does the zealot relatively well, but lacks the air of menace that you know she's supposed to have before she gets to play the zealot. Unger turns in the best performance of the lot, perhaps her best since Crash ten years previous.But then, are you really seeing a movie like this for the acting? Or, for that matter, the directing or the script? Competence is good enough. As long as there's atmosphere, you've got yourself a movie, and what Silent Hill does have is atmosphere in spades. One of the few problems I had with Hostel was its rather abrupt shift in tone; softcore porn one moment, hardcore horror the next. Silent Hill is, on the other hand, a seamless blend of atmospheric horror flick and gore film, with more than a little mystery and psychodrama thrown in for good measure. This, of course, leads to lots of criticism; the atmospheric horror fans are blasting it for the amount of gore, the gorefeinds are saying there's not enough. I could've done with a tad more gore, myself, but I'm not counting points off for not having enough. Here, it seems to me, is the first really hard evidence that America is learning from Japanese New Horror, as opposed to simply remaking it or imitating it. (And while Eli Roth made a bang-up flick, Hostel really is more imitation than internalization.) All of the visuals, once Rose gets to Silent Hill, are aimed at throwing you off, if not always disturbing you. Nothing looks right, even those things that normally would. (Gans does kind of overplay this a tad in the scene with Christopher and Gucci wandering through the school, but since he's setting up a later shot, I have to at least partially forgive him; whether you will or not depends on whether you think that later shot is also overdone. It is, but only a touch, really.) You know something's not right, even before Rose does, and by the time she's figured it out, you're in full-on disturbance mode. Avary does a good job of spacing things out (e.g., showing us the miners, giving us a scene with the miners, showing us who the miners are) in the script so as to achieve the maximum disturbance effect, and again, as long as you're paying attention, you should be able to connect the dots just fine.Now, what I didn't tell you at the beginning of this review: I have never played the Silent Hill games. I was only marginally aware of their existence before I started hearing buzz for this movie, and as of now, all I know about them I know from the movie. So I am living proof that the "you have to have played the game to understand this movie" criticisms are wrong. I've barely even seen the boxes, and I thought it was loads of fun and easy to follow. The script was probably too subtle for a lot of people who saw it; I hope to all that's holy that doesn't lead Hollywood to start dumbing horror films down again. A lot of us did get it, and we're deeply appreciative that this script got through the way it did.I cannot recommend highly enough that you see this movie if you're a horror fan. See it on a double-bill with Slither, if you can; they're two aspects of what the Hollywood movie machine can do, if they either encourage or ignore folks who want to make movies that don't fit standard fare. Great stuff, both of them. ****
summary: If you don't get it, you're not trying.

reviewText: Hollywood seems to have gone belly-up when it comes to "horror movies",  as evidenced by this mish-mash of a teenage summer flick.  On the bright side,  the cinematography,  lighting,  and special effects are very good. The blood and guts scenes are inventive and ample,  for us gore-hounds out there.  And that's all, folks!  The writing sucks,  as does the acting.  The story is absurd and who gives a damn about the so-called characters.  Not ONE good scare in the entire movie,  and it's overlong to boot.Why do all of these dumb phony horror extravaganzas degenerate into a battle between God and the Devil?  Poe,  Lovecraft, Henry James,  and even the early stuff by Steven King did not fall into this obvious genre trap.  I'm afraid that Dracula was the last of the great horror concepts.If you want to see REAL horror movies,  try Rosemary's Baby,  The Innocents,  Black Sabbath (or anything else by Mario Bava),  Don't Look Now, Psycho,  or any of the old monster movies (not 50's atomic sci-fi--although that stuff is highly entertaining,  and sometimes classic).Glad I did not buy this nonsense.
summary: VERY WELL MADE,  BUT VERY STUPID

reviewText: I saw this film without knowing it was a video game adaptation.Truly atmospheric little cult gem here. What it lacks in plot, it makes up for in other departments.  It's more of a "Nightmare Drama" than a horror film.List of what works well, in order of success: (1) atmosphere/mood/tone, (2) imagery.  What's sufficient: acting, music. If you're looking for anything else, look elsewhere.You will find it useful to have no expectations, and a few minor suspensions-of-disbelief for the initial set-up to work.It's NOT a Romero-level masterpiece, not a landmark/zeitgeist-nailing/cultural-defining moment, but an enjoyable ride nonetheless.Compares on many levels to the 1962 version of "Carnival of Souls."  If that film is now considered a masterpiece by some, at least a masterpiece of atmosphere, then "Silent Hill" is another masterpiece in that same tradition.
summary: Atmospheric B-movie, Vivid Imagery, No Need For Plot

reviewText: Not really sure WHY someone decided to leave the making-of featurettes off this release.. why leave ANYTHING OFF a BD release? Like there's a danger of running out of room?  Doesn't make sense, unless they're planning an inevitable special edition.  Meh.I'm taking off a star for that.Otherwise, I love this movie, and it shines in BD format.Director Christophe Gans has done an expert job distilling the visual tone of the original game...  and those familiar with the games will recognize all of Akira Yamaoka's evocative music, used here perfectly. The entire production, unlike other videogame to screen versions, was done with the insight and blessings of Konami, and if fans of the games take issue with the details of the story, they hopefully might realize this film is more for those who are new to the series.This is more of a classic ghost story than a horror movie. Or like an especially dark episode of the Twilight Zone.  Silent Hill is a town with a secret so terrible, it literally fell into purgatory.. and it and it's inhabitants are hovering there, waiting...  twisting in their own personal hells.I really don't want to spoil the story, this film I don't think is really ABOUT story.. it's a mood piece about a mother going to the edge of sanity to rescue her daughter. And there is plenty of iconic imagery here to enjoy along the way.. even at it's most graphic, it has a surreal Hieronymus Bosch beauty to it.
summary: Visually Fantastic, but without the making-of featurettes

reviewText: It was OK after you've watched it and think about it, but during the first initial viewing I must admit I was a bit ancy in my seat. The problem was I had minimal sympathies for the leads, and the movie producers take it for granted that you care very much for anything that walks on two legs. Perhaps that's the way life should be to care for our fellow man, but in movies it's a whole different category.  You have to connect. Without that, you simply watching someone else's journey, and that's how it was during this entire movie. I feel for people who are in pain or distress in movies but there are certain levels of rooting for the good guy. The major point is putting yourself in his or her spot, that is where the real fun comes in. However, in this particular case, I felt like I was a watcher in someone else's nightmare, and as struggling as she was to find her lost daughter, I didn't feel it was monumentally that important. I felt more importance in Dorothy finding her way home from the wonderful land of Oz. That is the real clincher with horror movies, if you don't empathize with the main characters, the struggle is lost. For all the special effects, sound effects, fancy footwork to behold, the feeling was rather cold as the white ash almost deserted city she had visited.As for the villains, they ranged from a Katherine Hepburn African Queen wannabe to Michael Jackson's floating mummies. Nuf said.
summary: Mixed bag of trick or treats

reviewText: I first wanted to watch this film just to see how bad it would be, but to my surprise it actually wasn't terrible. This movie is one that I feel was just all right, that if it was on late night on cable I might watch it again, but I do not plan on owning it. For a horror movie it was good, but it's not the type I found altogether enjoyable.The plot was good, the actors okay, and the monsters were just creepy. I recommend seeing it but I can't promise you'll say 'wow'. The movie lacks but compared to other horror movies out there it was one of the better ones.3.5/5

reviewText: Let me start by saying I've never played the games, but I have watched my son play them.  The games are creepy to the extreme, and this movie manages to pull off the atmosphere perfectly.  Whether you are a game player or just a moviegoer, this film is a treat to the horror fan who loves an extra dollop of disturbing and sinister eeriness on their gore.Rose Da Silva (played expertly by Rahda Mitchell - Pitch Black, Man On Fire) knows there is something deeply wrong with her sleepwalking adopted daughter, Sharon.  Against the wishes of her husband Christopher (Sean Bean - Fellowship Of The Ring), Rose decides to take Sharon on a road trip back to Sharon's town of birth, Silent Hill.  Big mistake.After a run from police officer Cybil Bennett (Laurie Holden - Young Catherine, Fantastic Four), Rose crashes her car on the border of the cordoned off city of Silent Hill, evacuated because of an underground mine fire.  When Rose regains consciousness, Sharon is gone and Officer Bennett is intent on arresting her.  That is, until the two women discover that Silent Hill is now shut off from the rest of the world by a gaping chasm.Rose and Cybil return to the town to look for Sharon, but the town is really messed up.  Signals over the radio and cell phones announce the coming of squishy, disgusting horrors, and the fallout siren announces the arrival of a strange, alternate dimension.  Sharon is still here, somewhere, and Rose will stop at nothing to find her little girl.This movie is ALL atmosphere.  The sinister ambiance, the gut-wrenching mood, will make you forget everything else.  The FX is great, not just with the surroundings but also with Mr. Triangle Head (who appears in a particular skin-ripping scene that will leave you retching or reaching for popcorn).  Alice Krige (Star Trek TNG as the Borg Queen) plays a very over-the-top religious leader to perfection.  And the ending will leave you gasping for air, if you have any breath left after your ride through this spooked out town.Note:  I couldn't help but hear Simply Red's song "Night Nurse" during Rose's foray into the basement.  You will see what I mean, then look up the song.  I'm twisted, but it fits.  'Silent Hill' is a definite purchase.  Enjoy!

reviewText: All the reviews of this movie have either been positive or negative. People seem to either love this movie or hate this movie; I for one am in the middle but leaning more (much more) towards like. Of course going into the movie with the information I had on it is also influencing my review.Rose cannot accept the knowledge that her daughter Sharon is dying of a fatal disease. Over the protests of her husband, she flees with her child, intending to take the girl to a faith healer. On the way, she ends up driving through a portal in reality, which takes her to the eerie and deserted town of Silent Hill. Sharon disappears in Silent Hill, and Rose follows what she thinks is her daughter's silhouette all over town. It's soon clear the town is not like any place she's ever been. It's inhabited by a variety of creatures and a living darkness that descends and literally transforms everything it touches. The human inhabitants - the ones who are left - are trapped and fighting a losing battle against the Darkness. Joined by a cop named Cybil, who has been sent to bring her and Sharon back, Rose searches for her little girl while learning the history of Silent Hill and that Sharon is just a pawn in a larger game...That's the premise of Christophe Gans' game to movie adaptation. I went in to this movie knowing the premise. I've never played any of the games in this series but I really want to. Gans' did a terrific directing job. The sets look amazing. Everything is beautifully shot and he uses some camera angles which I am going to assume resemble the games' angles in some parts. All in all, his directing job is very well done; you can tell he loves this series.The script for this movie has been under a lot of scrutiny. Ok, it's not perfect and yes, it does have some corny, cheesy and out of place dialogue but I looked past that. I could have used without Rose yelling "Sharon!" over and over and over and over again. I was expecting Ozzy Osbourne to pop up and share in the yelling.The acting is what you'd expect in this kind of movie. Who's here is solid, not the best but they get the job done. Mitchell does a great job as Rose while Sean Bean is just there. Jodelle Ferland is good as the child as well. The score is just ho-hum. It's not bad but it's nothing memorable. They use the "Silent Hill Theme" too much (don't know if that's the games' theme they're using or the movie's theme).The effects in this are top notch. The monsters are inventive and creepy. They're unlike anything I've seen. It also helps they're not all CGI. They're people underneath there and there's very little CGI used.Ok, now to the information on why I rated this a little higher than I normally would have. This movie's run time is 125 minutes (approx.). Things seem missing at some places and not everything makes sense at the end. That's because the original cut was longer than King Kong, it was 3 and a half hours! So yeah, lots of things were cut, I guess that's why I'm being lenient to it and not bashing it. I went in expecting that and wasn't disappointed. This gets a higher grade because I understood things got cut out. The movie entertained me anyways. So I wasn't fully aware of what was going on in some places but I was so wrapped up in the world I was drawn into that I really didn't care. That's kind of like Doom, it's an empty empty movie but it's fun. Silent Hill is a movie with a simple plot and things were cut out but it was fun. Was Doom a "good" movie? No. Was it a "fun" movie? Yes and that's all that matters for a flick like this. I didn't go into this movie expecting gold in the first place and I wasn't let down. I guess the biggest thing that irked me was the ending. I heard about this huge amazing ending that left the movie wide open for a sequel. Sorry, it didn't. Sure, the ending was damn cool but wasn't what I was expecting, which is my fault and not the movie's. I enjoyed the very ending cause we don't get full closure. The ending is enigmatic but it doesn't hurt the film. My other large complaint is that the Sean Bean character really serves no purpose. His scenes only detract us from Rose's situation, a world that we've become a part of and entwined in.So no, this isn't a perfect movie, not many are. And yes, things were cut out and that will cause people to be lost. Is this the definitive videogame movie? Far from it. But I went in knowing this wasn't Gans' true vision, just his best effort to put out what he was allowed and for that I congratulate him. He created a pretty alright videogame movie. I'm hoping his cut is a great one. The dialogue will make you laugh and the acting isn't the greatest but it's supposed to be a fun ride and I for one am glad I took that ride.NOTE: I actually give this movie a 3.5 but seeing as how I can't give it that on the star line...you know.
summary: "To find your daughter, you must face the darkness of Hell"

reviewText: Eugh, video game to movie transitions. Haven't we had enough Mortal Kombats and Resident Evils? I did walk into the theater with low expectations, but kept my mind open. (About as smart as retrieving dropped soap in a prison shower, but I digress.) The movie is about a woman named Rose, whose adopted daughter sleepwalks near a waterfall piping out "SILENT HILL! SILENT HILL!" After about a minute's worth of online research, Rose heads to the ghost town with her daughter for some vague, subtext-explained reason. After Rose makes a brief stop, she notices the dubious foreshadowing of her daughter's once-adorable crayon colorings transformed into crude representations of blood and gore. The characters exhibit some obligatory shock, and continue towards Silent Hill. It would go against standard horror movie protagonist conduct to do otherwise, right? A cop who earlier wrote down Rose's license plate number follows her to Silent Hill, and disjointed scenes of mild intrigue follow. Silent Hill is an unapologetic exercise of style, intending to envelop the viewer in its dreary atmosphere to a level he/she doesn't notice the sterile script and generic "I'm shocked! Now let's move on." horror movie acting.Visually and aurally, Silent Hill is brilliant. The tainted ghost town drenched in fog is perfectly emulated, complimented by lucid camerawork and a melancholic soundtrack. The monsters themselves are somewhat creepy at first, (except the giant bug with the whimsical demon face) despite the fact that the CGI enhancement is too obvious. (CGI will always lack the depth and warmth necessary to be mistaken for flesh and blood.) I love the subtlety in how the creatures are presented, adding to the creep-out factor rather than the shock factor. On a superficial note, I was a bit let down by the lack of gore, or any real brutality, until the last quarter of the film. I understand Silent Hill is a mainstream movie with a regular R rating, but I expected a bit more considering the monsters were shambling lumps of pulsating flesh. Come on, give the audience a reason to be scared. Near the end of the movie, there's alot of blood and a certain Evil Dead-esque moment I don't think I can mention on Amazon, but the accentuating level of suspense in the amount of violence these creatures could inflict worked only to render the film somewhat visually unbalanced.This movie certainly evokes that bleak, gothic feeling of the namesake games, but utilizes the impeccable atmosphere to create a lopsided framework to rest a dark, but wholly forgettable Hollywood good vs. evil fairytale. Not recommended.- Thus says the Pellington
Title: N/A

reviewText: Silent Hill is one of the most visually stunning films I've seen. It is simply mesmerising to look at. The atmosphere is wonderfully dark, dingy, weird and creepy. A dreamlike (or more accurately a nightmare-like) serenity shrouds the deserted town, while just below the surface a terrible darkness lurks. The monsters encountered are truly disturbing, especially the Janitor, and the design of these creatures demonstrates the high level of creativity that has been lavished on the visuals. The effects are top-notch; you will never look at peeling paint in the same way again. Five stars so far, then, no question about it. So it's a real shame that the script lets the production design down. Up until the third act the mystery surrounding the disappearance of the little girl is deeply satisfying in its spookiness. Silent Hill is such a strange place you want the reason for all this suffering and evil to be equally unexpected and bizarre. Instead we learn, during a very long piece of exposition, that the town's terrible past is in fact a rather predictable, and disappointing one. Suddenly the eerie atmosphere is destroyed and the film becomes derivative. Even the spectacular finale can't recapture the mystery that the first two-thirds of the film so effectively created. Anyone who enjoys the work of David Lynch will know that weirdness can be used to great effect and doesn't always have to be completely explained away. If Silent Hill had left more to the imagination of the viewer it would have been a much better movie.
summary: The Janitor's out to bug you!

reviewText: Silent Hill is a movie that is fast paced and action packed from the very beginning. My only dissapointment with this movie is the director never shows the audience exactly how the mother, daughter, and policewoman died in the crash. Although the writing for this movie was really good, I did find the director's ommition of not showing their dead bodies to be very confusing.In this horror, a mother searches for her missing daughter in a creepy town that is quiet during the day, but is plagued by spirits and a "reaper" like figure during the night.The mother soon finds others hiding in the town.The ending is very good. Also, the actors are good.Because of the awesome special effects and good cast of actors, including the children (who were believable in their roles) I rate this movie with 4 stars.I left a star off due to the major loop hole of the director not showing the audience exactly how the mother and daughter died in the accident or what happened to their bodies, even when her husband came to search for her, he was never shown claiming or at least identifying his families' bodies.

reviewText: If you're ever in West Virginia.Be sure to make it a point to avoid a place called Silent Hill.Director Christophe Gans film version of the popular video game Silent Hill is very frightful and very scaring.With ghoulish sets and special effects.The trip into horror begins when Rose's(Radha Mitchell) daughter turns up missing after a car crash.And the tough minded and determined Rose will do anything to find her and get her back.Even if it means going up against deformed creatures,witch hunters and the leader of all the demons.For the town of Silent Hill is hiding a terrible thiry year old secret and is under a terrible curse.And the town owns a debt that must be paid and paid in full.As Rose looks for her daughter.She's put into a world of pure terror and nightmares.As she uncovers the truth about Silent Hill and it's people.All leading to a frightful climax.Where good,evil.justice and revenge meet.

reviewText: The nations "so-called" top critics have been bellyaching for years about the current crop of horror moves.  They have whined and complained about those films repetitiveness: [...] teenagers/young adults being tortured and killed by a sadistic psycho, the lack of intelligence in those films, and those movies focusing on entertaining an audience with nudity, bloodshed, or a combination of the two.  So finally a horror movie is released that doesn't adhere to this standard and yet again they're still bellyaching.  Perhaps because some people can't be satisfied or maybe their negative reviews of this film stem from their inability to use their brains when watching a horror movie so they go out and wrongfully label this film as plotless and confusing.Since those "so-called" top critics failed to grasp the plot and were confused, I'll enlighten them a bit.  I won't give away any major spoilers since that would ruin the movie for people who have yet to see it, but I will put out some useful information on some stuff that to me is elementary, but the "so called" top critics seemed to not have not been able to understand (honestly, what are they being paid for).  The basic plot of this movie is that Sharon DaSilva is in the mysterious town of Silent Hill looking for her missing adopted daughter named Sharon DaSilva.  In the process of looking for her she is lead from place to place by an entity that is intent on using her to seek revenge.  What's so confusing about that?Other important aspects of the film that went over the heads of those critics was having a basic understanding of the fact that there are 3 worlds that exist in Silent Hill.  Those 3 worlds are reality, the other world, and the nightmare world.  Reality in the film is the world where the husband and Officer Gucci are as they try to locate Rose, Sharon, and Cybil.  In this world the town is abandoned because of the ash, smoke and forever burning mines that requires them to have to wear protective facemasks.The other world in the film is a foggy place where ash falls like snow.  It is in this world that Rose, Cybil and Sharon are first transported to.  It is a vastly empty place that is completely closed off from the outside world by cliffs.  The religious zealots-miners who like Rose, Cybil, and Sharon have been pulled here inhabit it.  It also contains strange, mal-formed creatures.Then there`s the third and final world.  This is a nightmare world.  But who's nightmare world is it? My recommendation is watch the movie and find out.  This world is a dark, and burned placed filled with the hideous creatures.  In this world a child molester appears as an S& M styled beast, there's a monster wielding a giant blade with a pyramid shaped head, there are also lots of bugs (scary stuff to a child), and burned childlike creatures who scream and cry out as they harass Rose in a well-done scene.The other world's transformation to this nightmare world is indicated by the sound of sirens.  Here's a hint figuring out why sirens are heard will help you movie critics figure out who's nightmare it is.  It will also help you analysis an important aspect of the film's storyline.So would I recommend this movie?  You bet.  It's one of the best video game adaptations out there.  I should know because I've seen more than my fair share of terrible movie adapations based on popular video games, the Resident Evil movies and Super Mario Brothers are some of the bad ones that immediately come to mind.  I can only wonder what the studios were thinking when they released those extremely awful films.This movie is also a great stand alone horror film.  The visuals are beautiful and the story complex and tragic.  So forget the critics and their inability to think when watching a horror movie and enjoy this great film. Trust me, you'll be glad you did.

reviewText: First off, you people who haven't seen this movie yet and are reviewing it need to shut your holes! I hate people who review movies they haven't seen yet. All of you need your fingers broken off so you cant type up these ridiculous reviews!Anyway, on to the movie: First off, It is actually a little closer to being a 4 star movie. I just gave it a 5 to offset some of these other bogus reviews. It is the best video game movie sofar, but it is not without its problems. Here are my very MINOR complaints: At time it seems slow, but it does keep you interested. The concept of the mother looking for her child starts to ware thin on you after an hour of watching it. However, there is enough FX, nightmarish scenery, and gore to keep any horror movie fan satisfied. There were actually some pretty cool and unique sequences in this movie. Many of which the previews don't ruin for you. I was very impressed with the violence in this. Most of the other video game movies have been very toned down compared to their game format, but this one holds true to its name. As a matter of fact, toward the end of the movie there is a scene that I will not give away, but I will say I am surprised the movie board let it slip out. Let's just say mixing violence with children tends to really hit a nerve with your average movie goers. Finally, I must add one final complaint: like all other horror movies released in the last 10 years, bad ending! Well, maybe not bad, but it could have been way better!Verdict: It is definitely worth a movie ticket, go see it. Its like taking a journey through a nightmare. Great imagination was put into this one. I plan on purchasing it when it comes to DVD. P.S. See "The hills have eyes" too!
summary: Best video game to movie translation so far

I hate people who review movies they haven't seen yet. All of you need your fingers broken off so you cant type up these ridiculous  reviews!Anyway, on to the movie: First off,  It is actually a little closer to being a 4 star movie. I just gave it a 5 to offset some of these other bogus reviews. It is the best video game movie sofar, but it is not without its problems. Here are my very MINOR complaints: At time it seems slow, but it does keep you interested. The concept of the mother looking for her child starts to ware thin on you after an hour of watching it. However, there is enough FX, nightmarish scenery, and gore to keep any horror movie fan satisfied. There were actually some pretty cool and unique sequences in this movie. Many of which the previews don't ruin for you. I was very impressed with the violence in this. Most of the other video game movies have been very toned down compared to their game format, but this one holds true to its name. As a matter of fact, toward the end of the movie there is a scene that I will not give away, but I will say I am surprised the movie board let it slip out.  Let's just say mixing violence with children tends to really hit a nerve with your average movie goers. Finally, I must add one final complaint: like all other horror movies released in the last 10 years, bad ending! Well, maybe not bad, but it could have been way better!Verdict: It is definitely worth a movie ticket, go see it. Its like taking a journey through a nightmare. Great imagination was put into this one. I plan on purchasing it when it comes to DVD. P.S. See "The hills have eyes" too!
summary: Best video game to movie translation so far

reviewText: I don't much like horror movies that make you think about the plot or lack thereof, because they distract me from what I like about these kinds of movies, the thrill of getting scared. Silent Hill strayed from its genre, and not in a very subtle way.The overall atmosphere of the film was excellent. CGI effects created an almost believable haunted town with great lurking beasties of all shapes and sizes. I enjoyed the massacre and burning scenes near the end, although, it was more disturbing than scary, and some of you more faint-hearted viewers might disapprove.The story starts here. We have our heroine, young and beautiful, which I'm always partial to. She's trying to free her adopted daughter from the nightmares she keeps having, nightmares of a place called 'Silent Hill'. She decides to confront this place with her daughter, and somehow dispel the source of the nightmares. Things don't go smoothly though. She's hounded by a nosy cop, and on top of that, a mysterious apparition causes her to crash her car near the entrance of the haunted town. When she awakes, everything is covered in ash, and her daughter is missing.And so the real nightmare begins... or does it? That's just one of the many nagging questions you ask yourself by the end of the movie. At what point do the mom and daughter really lose themselves to silent hill? Perhaps at the very beginning in the crash, or at the end during the massacre. Well, that's never clear, even by the end of the movie, and if you watch it, you'll know what I mean.Throughout at least half of the movie, mom runs around town on wild goose-chases searching for something or someone that resembles her daughter. In the interim, the landscape of Silent Hill changes from light to dark and back again. As you might guess, dark is not a good time to be roaming Silent Hill, cause that's when the beasties emerge from the shadows, and stalk our cute heroine. Well, this cycle repeats a couple of times throughout the movie, until we start to get a clearer picture of what's going on.As the story fleshes out, things become increasingly less discernable so that by the end of the film, the plot gets more holes in it than the evil fanatic cult leader (probably the most graphic scene in the movie).Well not all is lost. If you can disregard the parts that don't make sense, and simply enjoy the attention-grabbing gore, and thrilling effects, then it does prove to be a somewhat enjoyable film. But if you're a straight-up horror enthusiast, then I would recommend Dawn of the Dead, or Resident Evil for your viewing pleasure.
summary: 3 Stars for Depravity and CGI effects.

reviewText: At the time of this writing the average rating on Silent Hill at Amazon was 4 stars. What a gip. If Silent Hill is a 4 star movie then something is broken. Either that or there are a lot of Horror movie fans with very low standards.Silent Hill isn't scary. There's no suspense. It's based on a cool video game, but it's about as believable as Donkey Kong (a stupid 80s video game about a gorilla that wears a tie).If you like good Horror [like Wolf Creek (2005) or the recent remake of Dawn of the Dead (2004)], or if you like good sci-fi [like Aliens (1986) or Terminator (1984, 1991, 2003)], you'll be bored silly by Silent Hill.Silent Hill is a dumb The Ring meets witches in the Twilight Zone kind of story that is not up to par with either of the media in my analogy.Paul S. Anderson [Resident Evil (2002, 2004), Alien vs. Predator (2004)] needs to write a book that aspiring video-game-to-film directors need to read that explains how to turn a good video game into a good movie. Because other than Anderson's films, I can't think of another movie that's been a good film adaptation of a video game.Pass on Silent Hill.

reviewText: In horror movies, there are several different rating factors.  Sadly, the only one this rated highly in is the one you don't want to: the cheese factor.  Mediocre acting, boring and unrealistic special effects, some hard-to-hear (perhaps mercifully) dialogue and over-the-top 'mood music' are enough to render this movie nearly unwatchable.  Plus the overall darkness of most of the scenes (a trend in horror movies these days, I suspect to cut back on special effects budgets) means that even if you watch the movie in the dark you're still squinting at the screen.I found it sadly lacking in plot (okay, it had one, but not a good one - it was trite and recycled) and with almost no suspense to speak of.  I didn't care what happened to the characters.  At one point I was willing to off the main character myself if it'd just stop her shouting.  Of course, this could be because the sound swung wildly from barely audible to bursting your eardrums.  It had a few moments that might have made you jump, were I not overwhelmed with apathy (for instance, the scene with the nurse corpses would have been jumpy, except I spent the time thinking how much it would have improved the movie if they'd busted out into the Thriller song and dance).  It had no lasting, nightmare-giving spook effect (though I admit to being a hard-core horror movie veteran, it would take a lot).I was even willing to give it credit in that it lacked the gratuitous gore that movie-makers now think is a good substitute for real horror, but then the end of the movie was showers of blood and unnecessary gore, which added nothing and took away any brownie points it may have earned in that arena.The only redeeming factor in the entire movie was the very end.  I'll give it a little credit there for not taking the easy route and leaving you with a little lingering air of mystery.  But that wasn't enough to even come close to tipping the scales against the mountain of badness that had accumulated.  Bottom line, on a scale of one to five popcorn bags this movie rates a fossilized chunk of popcorn you find under your couch.
summary: Zzzzzz... *snort* what, what, is it over yet?

reviewText: The first - but hopefully not the last - movie based on the groundbreaking series of video games, "Silent Hill" is an utterly riveting, horrific, eerie, and pyschologically and conceptually deep film, one that may take multiple watches to really 'get' all the facets within it, particularly if one isn't familiar with the games.An adopted little girl named Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) is plagued by violent night terrors and sleepwalking in which she seems to be frantically searching for something.  She's unaided by conventional medicine, and after one night's nightmare-driven excursions nearly prove fatal, the girl's mother Rose (Radha Mitchell from "Pitch Black" and "Man On Fire") decides to seek out what her daughter screams for in her sleep - 'Silent Hill!!' - and upon discovering that Silent Hill is the name of an old town, heads off with Sharon in search or relief for her daughter, in what form she doesn't even know.  Her husband (Sean Bean, of the criminally under-noticed "The Dark" as well as "Lord Of The Rings", "Equilibrium" and "Flightplan") fears this is just going to do more harm than good and takes off after them.Upon arriving in the abandoned town, Rose becomes separated from Sharon and with the help of a policewoman attempts to find her, and the true terror begins.  Silent Hill is a town like no other, of which multiple versions exist concurrently, and which sometimes shifts between them.  It's a place of nightmares and monsters - brought to life with amazingly disturbing imagery and visuals - and the ancestral home of a Very twisted, corrupted version of religion.  And many of its old secrets focus right on the little girl.To touch briefly on the psychological and conceptual depth of the movie, I'm going to have to give away more than I normally do, so I'll preface the rest of this with*WARNING: SEMI-SPOILERS AHEAD**Okay, there's a lot here open to interpretation, so the way I see some of the things toward the end of the film isn't neceasrily how everybody else is going to see it (and a lot of it is just hinted at, hopefully for possible expansion should they do a sequel), but there seem to be an awful lot of strange and fascinating undercurrents here. Basically - it never states this outright, but this is my take - there are places on Earth where if enough human cruelty and hatred comes out, it can open the door for those things to draw 'entities' or states-of-existance to come into contact with our world.  But this is a really interesting part - the demon Pyramid Head, from a certain point of view, seems to have come to empathize with the innocent more than with the cruel, and to be acting as an avenger of certain victims in the town's history.  That's not to say Pyramid Head is a 'good guy' rather than the 'bad guy' of the game, but it raises questions.  Can a demon come to feel compassion?, for example.  This goes with the whole flow of the video games, which has brought in questions of basically 'what horrors can twist the good into the abominable?', and has also played with the flip side of the equation.If there is a sequel, I don't know whether this angle will be followed up on, or whether it'll be left stand as an 'even the most evil can have some occasional virtue in there' thing without taking Pyramid Head from his 'terrifying villain' role, but either way has its merits.  "Silent Hill" is chock-full of revenge, evil characters, blood-ripping/bone-crushing horror, and the most ghastly visual imagery, and it's also loaded up under the surface with themes of love, compassion, and justice.  There's a strong interplay between characters, as with the games - you're never playing just a character out to save their own skin in the video games, there's always something of a group dynamic where there's someone your character is out to protect, and simultaneously where your character needs to take a chance on trusting other, possibly duplicitous, characters as well.It all combines brilliantly, and in this case gives us one of the best movies of the year.  A true great.
summary: Epic, Multi-Layered, Mesmerising Tale Of Horror And Retribution, Darkness And Salvation

reviewText: I have to say that Silent hill so far is the only game to film adaption that truly followed the feel, look, and even sound of the game it's based on. As we are to expect, the movie does'nt follow any story line from the games, although it is very similar to that of the first; in which our lead "Rose" whom replaces "Harry" of the first game, is in search of her missing daughter. As the movie progresses we see familiar characters, like Dhalia Gillespie and the nurse Lisa, whom has a small role in the film. We're also witness to various creatures we've encountered in the game, more notably Pyramid Head  and the Nurses.We also seeother memorable creatures, like the little ghosts and a freaky new one called "the Janitor". The film combines elements from all four games. Like the monsters from the second, and various little enviroment and characters details from the others. The movie keeps the games music which adds to the excellent atmosphere the film presents.I think the look and atmosphere are one of the strongest elements in the movie.They spared no expense in the blood and gore department, especially towards the end. Another aspect I thoroughly enjoyed was the transition between the real world and the dark. It's very reminiscent of the game, especially when we hear that dreadful siren, warning our character of what to come. I felt that the explanantion and ending itself seemed a bit rushed.Other than a couplefairly slow paced sequences, the first half was brilliantly plyed out, with a mix of moody atmosphere and freaky characters.Then as we reach our climax we seemingly get rushed explanation and ending, which did not really fit the feel of the first part of the movie. Regardless, I still enjoyed the film the film from start to finish. Overall fans of the game may be dissapointed by the thin story line, but in ways it makes it up.with excellent use of the games music, along with the right atmosphere and a fair amount of blood and gore. Look out for some of the more notable creatures in the movie, as they look very much like they do in the games.In the modern age of remakes amd games to film adaptation, Silent Hill sucessfully pulls off a creepy movie  that stays true to the games it's based on. If only it did'nt seem so rushed towards the end could have been better. Still though I say bring on part TWO!! An go see this one for sure.
summary: One of Best  Game to Movie Ever Made!

reviewText: I loved this stylish horror film that manages to both entertain and disturb.  If there is ever a way to capture a nightmare on film, then this film has found a way to do it.I think most of Amazon's review is dead on accurate except for the ending comment that the film feels hollow.  I don't get that, in fact, I was quite moved by the end of the story.I have always enjoyed horror films that focus more on atmosphere, plot and character development over gore, porn, and special effects; however, this film knocked me over with its gore and special effects that only enhance the plot elements of the film.  It's rare when a film can do that appropriately (such as in the originalNight of the Living Dead).  This film's washed out blue-filtered photography, generally disturbing images, outstanding make-up, and deliberate pacing make this a standout in this genre.  The film is both boldly original and oddly familiar in its nightmarish presentation.In addition, the film has great plot twists (which I won't spoil for you) and characters that we sincerely care about; hence, my disagreement with Amazon's comment that the film feels "hollow."  We are attached to the characters in this film because of the great performances of the very familiar faces.  Raha Mitchell ofPitch Blackis quickly becoming a very recognized actress even though her name often escapes most.  Sean Bean's presence is welcomed in this horror flick and lends it credibility.  He's a classy actor that we have come to feel comfortable with whether he's the heavy like inNational Treasureor the good guy inFlightplan.  Finally, the appearance of the great, but largely under appreciated actress, Alice Krige, who is probably best remembered forGhost Story,Sleepwalkers, and as the Borg Queen inStar Trek - First Contact.  She is not only still beautiful, but also still quite chilling in her portrayal of evil characters.This film is your worst nightmare come to life.  It's totally surreal, atmospheric, graphic, and frightening.  Simply put, this is why we go see horror flicks.
summary: This is a visionary and haunting film destined to be a classic.

reviewText: First off, I have to admit that I never finished Silent Hill or Silent Hill 2 on the PS2 simply because it freaked me out too much.  I had decent hopes for the movie, no matter what the critics said.  Unfortunately, the critics were right.  The movie has its good and bad but sometimes the bad isn't so bad that the movie is ok.  This is different than going in w/ low expectations and being content with it.  This movie just doesn't do it for me.Scary and horror movies have many different ways of being effective.  Graphics can be scary, sure, but if they aren't backed up properly, it can be viewed as a joke or weird.  The concepts behind the horror has to be sound. If they can mess with your mind, even better.  Sometimes the action can be horrific.  Shock value doesn't go that far.Alien for example, was a good horror movie.  It wasn't necessarily the concept, but the atmosphere.Event Horizon had a creepy concept.  The concept of an evil, horrific force that can span across the galaxy had me creeped out more than the movie itself.Halloween, Nightmare on Elm Street, Texas Chainsaw, etc.  It was all about the concepts.  Silent Hill doesn't do it conceptually or storywise.  Confusing, cryptic storylines work (Ju-On) but not in Silent Hill.  The basic story that Rose's daughter, Sharon, is a bit of a nutcase.  Rose believes that the only way to get her `fixed' is to visit the town of Silent Hill which Sharon tends to babble about in her sleep.  She also sleepwalks which really doesn't help matters much.  Sound enough premise, right?Nope.  By the time they get into a town that nobody wants to remember and strange things start happening, it SHOULD be time to pack up and go.  There wasn't really a sense of Rose being trapped (even though there were 2 scenes of the road being cut off) and all the viewer can think is, "Just leave.  The kid's a psycho."  I don't agree with the director and writers showing the monsters off so early in the game.  The suspense disappeared very quickly in that regard.Due to the rather lame story, it's hard to feel for these characters.  I have no problem with using a female cast; I think it's great.  The connection between mother and daughter are there but it's not strong enough for us to want the mother to really find the daughter.  Because of both the early showing of monsters and the story, the REST of the monsters that are shown aren't scary.  Triangle head, creeping roach dude and the nurses, it just doesn't work.  Even the funky motions of the creatures can't save it.  House on Haunted Hill was creepier, y'know?The rest of the story, the whole witch hunt thing, was really lame.  Come on...  Survival horror is far more interesting than a contrived Hollywood-like story.  Demons?  ACTUAL demons???  Evil taking the form of a little girl that looks like a female Ju-On???The effects were ok.  The motion of the monsters sucked (probably because we've seen it too much now), but I loved the fog and falling ash effects.  The changing of Silent Hill world to HELL world was very cool.  The siren was ultra creepy.  All I can say in the end is that this movie would have done just fine w/o the Silent Hill name.  Sure, it's remotely based off the 1st game but the suspense and action just don't last long enough.  A casual viewer might be remotely entertained but any real fan of the games won't like it.  As a movie, I'd give it a C-.  There are so many more things that could have been done with this property.  And who knows, maybe there's a Silent Hill 2 on the horizon.
summary: Silent Hill or Hill of Demonic Monsters?

reviewText: For those of you who have played the game, the visual images in the movie will remind you of your gameplay as if you were immersed in the world of Silent Hill.  For those of you who have never played a Silent Hill game, the images are still quite disturbing but may not have the same resonance as those who have played.  Bottom line, this movie is well worth seeing.Silent Hill (The movie) doesn't suffer from the usual video game to movie translation issues... if you want to see a bad example just rent DOOM or Street Fighter.  Although there are some dialogue issues ("Everything will be alright"), the movie moves along at a brisk a visceral pace.  The action, the visual effects, keep you glue to the pace of the movie and the mystery deepens and grabs you as you peel off each mystery behind Silent Hill.Overall, a great cinematic experience that is made even better because of its reflection of the original games' concepts.

reviewText: This movie looks great on DVD. It's crisp and clear, which was one of the problems I had seeing this in the theatre. The images were often muddy and the action hard to see clearly. These problems have been resolved on disc, and I have to say this movie makes for some really nice eye candy. Yes, there are script/plot/pacing problems, but I found myself totally engrossed in all the visuals this time around; Fans of the games(like me...)will get way more milage out this than just horror fans, but there is enough disturbing stuff here to satisfy most. Also, I fast forwarded by every scene with Sean Bean(Nothing personal...he is just totally wasted here...)except for the ones where he is searching in the town and the end. It shortened the movie by about 20 minutes and actually made it flow alot easier. Lots of nice game nods; An ending out of some Hellraiser movie on acid; But it is hard to deny Christophe Gans is a visual genius; I'm sure he'll only continue to get better...

reviewText: I knew going into this film that Silent Hill would be deeply polarizing to different people.  There will be fans of the game that love it, fans of the game that hate it.  However, there will also be the casual audience member that will love it and the poor sap who will go "WTF?  What am I watching?"Such is the huge task dropped into the laps of gamer Christophe Gans (the director) and Roger Avary (the writer).  Neither of which are slouches when it comes to making films.  Add to that a cast that includes Sean Bean and Rahda Mitchell, among others, and you have the makings of a video game movie worth watching.  So, is it?  Well, that depends on the kind of individual you are.The Silent Hill games are a very mysterious beast.  There is a semblance of a plot in the traditional sense holding them together.  However, much of the time is spent disecting the backstory of both the town and the people trapped therein.  The basic story of this movie is that Rose is a mother of a child named Sharon who is having dreams of Silent Hill.  Rose thinks its a good idea to take Sharon to Silent Hill to help her remember.  Fans of the horror genre know this can't turn well and it doesn't.  Rose crashes, Sharon vanishes and all hell breaks loose.The rest of the movie is stylishly shot with filters, fog and darkness to create a living nightmare, both literally and metaphorically.  Here is where Christophe Gans shines.  He is in full control of what the town should look like, how the camera angles should show the action and how to propel Rose toward the inevitable gory conclusion.  The biggest problem he had to face was to bring a story that is hidden behind notebooks, letters and cryptic dialogue to a 2 hour film that doesn't leave the audience not knowing what happened.  It's easier to piece together a cryptic plot in a 10 hour game or 500 page novel than it is in a 2 hour movie.I'll admit, there are some egregious dialogue problems.  But, I hate to say it, video games aren't exactly the birthing place of dialogue greatness.  Think Resident Evil: "Blood.  I hope it's not...Chris's blood."  Think Silent Hill 3: "Remember me, and your true self as well, also that which you must become. The one who will lead us to Paradise with blood stained hands!" It's a bit over the top.  So when lines are spouted in the movie that seem to be head-shakingly bad, I guess if we can't fault video games why fault a movie?As such, the film as a medium is forced to be a bit more obvious.  Here is where a lot of fans will turn up their noses.  I'll admit, there are times where the mystery is spoiled because Christophe wants the audience to understand more.  But overall, I think it works.  And works well if compared to other video game adaptations like Tomb Raider, Resident Evil, Mario Brothers or *insert the Uwe Boll movie of the week here*.  Is it perfect?  No.  But what is here is an enjoyable representation of images, tone and feeling of the game series.

reviewText: First of all, let me get on the record as never having heard of the Silent Hill videogame franchise before viewing this film.  I went into the film expecting a dark, but potentially formulaic and predictable horror film like many others that studios have released lately.  What I saw was captivating and utterly disturbing...and I mean that as a sincere compliment to the filmmakers.The story line and exposition are a bit thin in spots, but once the viewer is immersed in the utterly nightmarish world of Silent Hill, the visual imagery is so compelling, the viewer is compelled to forgive these minor complaints.  I do not recall having seen a film before that so deeply resonated with my subconscious boogeymen.  Although the film certainly has its share of gory moments, the true horror is in the awful, hellish creatures that the protagonist experiences in the deserted town of Silent Hill.  From the misshapen, twisted humanoids to the miners to the ever-gruesome Red Pyramid, the creature work is fantastic.Another component of the film that makes it so utterly disturbing is that there is actually a town in my home state of Pennsylvania that has been largely abandoned for the same reasons as the fictional Silent Hill.  Centralia, PA is also on fire from beneath, and only a handful of residents remain.  Like Silent Hill, Centralia has been essentially decommissioned as a town (the post office even took away its zip code), and the knowledge that such a place actually exists (and that a few residents still live there) lends an air of authenticity to the film that only makes it that much more disturbing.This is not your average videogame-to-film adaptation (e.g., Mortal Kombat, Resident Evil, Doom) that relies more on the systematic execution of stylized violence between familiar characters than on any real filmmaking prowess.  Gans and his art directors create an alternate universe that is literally the stuff of nightmares.  Frightening, graphic, and disturbing material, but GREAT if you like to be scared senseless every once and awhile.

reviewText: I was surprised at how much I liked this movie. Normally, movies based on video games end up being pretty bad, but that is not the case with Silent Hill. From my limited knowledge of the game, this movie follows the plot fairly well, there are some obvious differences (like the main lead being a woman instead of a man), but overall it's decently faithful, and that's a good thing! It succeeded in creating a suspensful, chilling atmosphere, and some of it was genuinely creepy and unnerving. The acting was not nearly as bad as I thought it would be, in fact I'd say the acting was pretty good! I won't spoil what happens in the end, but I will say that I didn't care for it too much, it didn't seem like it offered enough closure, and it was a little confusing, but luckily this is not one of those cases where the ending makes or breaks the whole movie. I'd recommend this movie. -Trent Foreman, Author of Nightmare

reviewText: I saw this movie on cable and I'm a big fan of the games.  The atmosphere was great, the story was a little disjoined.  It's one of those movies that you have to read into it in order to explain what's going on.  Couple of times I got confused.  But, didn't dwell on it too much so that I can continue the movie.  I liked Pyramid Head.  Wow, what he did to one of the people was right out of a Hellraiser film!!!  In fact, this movie did remind me a bit of Hellraiser, not as vulgar and sexually explicit, which I felt was the problems of the Hellraiser movies.  My wife left the room to tend to our daughter and didn't come back, so either the images disturbed her, or she wasn't that interested in the movie.  She's kinda funny when it comes to movies anyway.  She likes more of the killing, Goodfellas, Carlito's Way, gangster type movies anyway.  Horror, just isn't her genre.  Me I like all kinds of movies.  As long as it doesn't have a whole lot of unnecessary sex, which this one doesn't, then I'll check it out.Silent Hill had many, many parts of the game thrown in, but done in a good way.  Very interestingly done.  As a fan of the game, this is a good movie.  If you're not, well, it maybe confusing.  The siren that goes off just before the world changes can be confusing to the non-gamer.  That was one of my questions.  Did the siren originate from the church?  Is it something that just happens before the darkness comes?What's even more interesting is that there is a place in Pennsylvania where there is a town that exists over underground fires that burn to this day.  Many of the people have fled and relocated, but others chose to remain.  Creepy huh?Going back to the movie, I would have to see it once again to fully understand the idea.  The ending is kinda sad.  Disappointing, but so are some of the endings of the games.  See it for yourself, BEFORE you buy.  If you like it when you see it and want to watch all the extras, well then, buy it.

reviewText: OK, this review is written by a man who has not played the original Konami video games - actually any games for many years, so please read it as such. Not that I hate playing the games. I like it. I just don't have enough time for doing that now. But I liked director Christophe Ganz's previous film `Brotherhood of the Wolf' and the presence of Jodelle Ferland (`Tideland') is attractive enough.Jodelle Ferland plays a little girl Sharon DeSilva, who keeps dreaming about a ghost town named Silent Hill, a town that was completely burnt down 30 years ago. Sharon's protective mom Rose (Radha Mitchell, `Pitch Black'), in order to cure her daughter of the habit of bad daydreaming, takes her to the now deserted town, without telling her husband (Sean Bean) anything about her hasty decision. And soon it really turns out hasty because Rose is lost in Silent Hill after a car accident. Moreover, Rose finds her daughter is missing.The introduction is lengthy, but it is worth waiting. The spooky photography by Dan Laustsen (`Mimic') that captures the lost town of Silent Hill is fantastic with the perfect production designs of the ruined buildings and deserted streets while white ashes constantly falling from the sky add some surreal beauty to the scene. And when a siren wails over the town, lots of the undead, these creepy creatures (designed by Patrick Tatopoulos, `ID4') resurrect out of nowhere and start to attack Rose.[LOOK WHO WROTE THE SCRIPT] I mean no disrespect, but for all its terrific production designs, superb sound and visual effects, and very spooky and scary zombies, Christophe Ganz did one big mistake in making this film. It's the script that seems to observe all the rules of the original games, but ignore the basic rules of storytelling. You may remember the name of Roger Avery, once co-credited with Quentin Tarantino as writer of `Pulp Fiction.' It is Avery who is responsible for the messy story that makes no sense in the second half of the film.I confess that I don't understand the meaning of the ending except that it refuses to follow the conventional patterns of horror films. For all the inclusion of a missing little girl, the film in the middle part suddenly seems to forget all about her, concentrating its energy on the bloody battle against the undead. I admit these fierce battles are impressive, but Avery (who is responsible for Bruce Willis and Ving Rhames' torture scene in `Pulp Fiction') is so intent on surprising and annoying us with unnecessary sadistic themes like suggested child molesting. This film should be pure entertainment, and it is in some of the set-pieces, but even the fans of the games find it incoherent. Why didn't Christophe Ganz add the puzzle element to the story, which would be much helpful in drawing attention to the film's alternate world?The supporting cast including Sean Bean, Deborah Kara Unger, Laurie Holden, Kim Coates, and Alice Krige have virtually nothing to do except looking like minor characters in the video games. They all look great, but without them the film will do, so why not just drop them?Among many films adapted from the games, `Silent Hill' should be called a success. It is surprisingly emotional and is unique in that most of the main characters are played by women. Therefore, it is regrettable that the overwritten script does not live up to its wonderful cinematography.

reviewText: Rose (Radha Mitchell) and Christopher Da Silva (Sean Bean) have an adopted daughter named Sharon (Jodelle Ferland) who begins suffering from severe night terrors and dangerous sleepwalking episodes.  The doctors tell the couple that their daughter is going insane, but Rose will not accept that diagnosis.  She decides to take Sharon to the one place that she keeps mentioning in her sleep, Silent Hill.  Supposedly Silent Hill was abandoned years ago because of an ever-burning mine beneath the city, but Rose decides to take Sharon there anyway.  After getting in an accident with a woman police officer (Laurie Holden), Rose awakens to find that Rose has disappeared and wondered into Silent Hill.  The place is eerie and disturbing.  Rose searches high and low to find Sharon, but when the sun goes down she discovers that there are monsters everywhere.  In the times of light Rose and the police officer, Cybil, learn that the people still living in the city take refuge in the town church when the Darkness and monsters come.  As Rose learns, though, things aren't exactly black and white and that in Silent Hill your best bet is taking a path down a road of grey.SILENT HILL is slightly better than the average horror-suspense movie, with two elements in particular that allow it to stand out.  The first is the music.  SILENT HILL has some of the creepiest music I have ever heard in a film.  Listening to just a few strains early in the movie was enough to give me the willies.  The other element that stood out for me in the movie were the monsters.  The structure of the movie is set up so you know exactly when the creatures are going to come out:  sirens blare, crows fly, and the sky turns dark.  Despite those warnings, the monsters of Silent Hill are still horrifying enough to frighten just about anyone.  They move at a regular pace, but with almost unnatural movements that seem like some grotesque ritual.  I later learned that the reason for this is that dancers were mostly hired for those roles.Even though I found SILENT HILL to be a better than average horror-suspense movie, I didn't enjoy it all that much.  It suppose it worked the way it was intended to, because I was left with some disturbing feelings and images after seeing it; the movie truly frightened me.  However, there was just too much unnecessary gore and violence for my tastes, especially during the last twenty-minutes of the movie.SILENT HILL is a movie that fans of the horror genre will probably appreciate most. I've also been told by people who have played the video games that the film is an excellent adaptation of the overall spirit of the games, so people who are fans of the games might enjoy the movie, too.

Silent Hill had enough for me to get past the totally misogynistic barbed wire in the ** scene.  It at least has cool CGI creatures, intelligent plot, decent acting, very creepy atmosphere and a fitting musical score.And that's why I'm keeping this one!..;-)

reviewText: I agree with the reviewers who say this transfer is no better than a standard DVD.  I purchased this disc because the 1080p trailer available on the PS3 online store looked interesting and was very sharp.  The transfer on this disc is inferior to the downloadable PS3 trailer.  I disagree with the other reviewer who stated that the transfer was sharp and who disparages the negative reviewers for having inferior tv's.I have a 67" DLP 1080p television that is ISF calibrated.  The other blu-rays discs I've watched (Underworld Evolution, Devil Wears Prada; even the single-layer Talledega Nights freebie that came with the PS3 - which has a worse transfer than the retail double-layer unrated version) exhibited much better sharpness and clarity.  The transfer on this disc is closer to a good upscaled standard DVD than a good Blu-ray or HD-DVD (which I also own).I give this movie a one-star because its the transfer is not worth the premium paid over the standard DVD version of the movie.

reviewText: Well...I watched it a couple of days ago. I have to give the movie just an "ok" rating. It really wasn't as good as many made it out to be. I thought that it was pretty predictable. When I saw the woman run by the hop scotch game that was labeled "Heaven and hell," I pretty much knew what was going on.The movie,at least in my opinion, was a bit too long to have had the ending that it did. reviewText: (2 & 1/2 stars) In the past I've enjoyed some of the movies made from video games - the 1st Resident Evil flick comes to mind - but this Silent Hill was just a little too lifeless for me.  The LOOK of the picture is intriguing, with some relatively strong horror effects.  However, there are too many scenes of people just walking around, not really doing anything.  To put it another way, when the lead character sees the monsters, she usually just screams and runs away.  She rarely does anything to combat them.  And there were too many things in the plot that made no sense.  The Silent Hill movie just never really grabbed me.

reviewText: It's hard for me to explain my thoughts on this movie. I have never been so divided by opinions. On the one hand the movie has the darkest most ghoulish touch I've ever seen. It's as if man's mind was split open and evil were permitted to drip across the screen. The visuals are too striking to do them justice with mere words.On the other hand, the plot and acting were so poorly thrown together you'd think it was a dress rehearsal and they were making it up as they went.The soundtrack is a bonus as it encompasses a lot of what makes the series shine. Sadly, it is used around THIS cast of characters who aren't fit to be in Silent Hill to begin with.My advice; if you are a Silent Hill fan, it's a must see for the sheer backdrops of creation. If you aren't a fan, this movie will likely make sure you never become one.

reviewText: The visual creativity of this movie is terrific. There are scenes that are almost inspired in their eery feel and imaginitive creepiness. But you can't make a movie with just this. You need a story and this movie just doesn't have one.  Compare this movie to the Alien Movies where the special effects were also inspired and something to talk about but the special effects were the supporting cast to a great story. In this movie the special effects are the main star and it just doesn't make for a good movie. A good video game yes, but movie no.
summary: No matter how good the special effects you still need a script.

reviewerName: Wilmar Luna "Author of The Silver Ninja"
reviewText: Although I've read that this movie was supposed to be much longer, I don't think having additional scenes would have saved how cringe-worthy this movie could be. Though it absolutely felt like a hell on earth kind of a movie with a satisfying ending scene, the main character, the dialogue, and the pacing really make this movie a chore to watch.Rose, the main character is absolutely terrible. She's annoying, not very well acted, and acts a little too crazy and desperate that it was on the verge of unbelievable. It didn't make sense for this woman to speed away from the cop Cybil, nor did it make sense why Cybil even pulled her over. Nothing that Cybil saw at the gas station should have raised any alarms.Cybil on the other hand was a great character, that was hampered by bad dialogue. She made sense and kicked ass when she needed to, but at the same time, uttered some of the silliest phrases that I just had to shake my head.The rest of the main supporting cast, you know, the men not in Silent Hill. Awful, boring, and the least interesting to watch on screen. It felt like the movie could have done without them and that the scenes were added in without much enthusiasm.However, the crazy church woman that is the leader of a little cult in Silent Hill. That chick was awesome and delivered her lines perfectly. You loved to hate her and man did she conjure up all the negative things you think of when faced with a religious zealot. Just a wonderful character to watch, well-acted, and overall well-thought out.Another great thing was the creature design. The creatures were disgusting, moved horribly, and would absolutely fuel your nightmares if you unlucky enough to watch this movie as a child. They were based off Silent Hill monsters of course, but seeing them come to life in the movie made them all the more frightening. Absolutely horrific stuff, really great.But at the same time, the over reliance on CG for certain elements made the film a little too "clean" for a horror movie. You never really feel scared when you're watching this movie. Everything feels very fake and glossy, when really the movie should have looked a little bit more grainy and amateur. You get this feeling that you're in a nicely made haunted house that has creepy and disgusting stuff, but nothing that will really scare you.Which also brings up the editing. The movie was really slow and boring at times and I shudder to think what the uncut version of this movie would have looked like. There's just too many moments where there's pointless running screaming "Sharon" and then cut back to what the male character is doing. Unfortunately, the male character doesn't offer or add anything to the movie, at all.However, the climactic scene in the movie is absolutely spectacular and horrifying to watch. The creature they created for this film was just perfectly created and executed. The way the resolution for this film hits is ultra satisfying and absolutely does not disappoint.I didn't care much for the ending, but considering how great it was to see justice served, it more than made up for the lackluster ending.Overall, give the movie a watch if it's free. Could it be worth a rental? Mmm... hard to say. If you like to see disgusting creature designs and evil people get their just desserts, then yeah, sure give it a rental But if you can't stand bad acting, bad writing, and sometimes questionable pacing. Definitely skip it.
summary: Captures the spirit of Silent Hill, but is hurt by terrible acting and writing.

reviewText: -- but with nothing earthly underneath.When I was a child, snow at night always felt safe to me. The big, puffy flakes would scatter any light back into my little pool of night, and would absorb all the sound in the world. Everything else would be far, far away, deadened by distance behind my gentle wall of snow.This whole movie makes a nightmare of that childhood dream. Instead of cloud-distilled water, this snow is burning poison. Even while it hides the evil outside, the snow itself erodes eyes, lungs and skin. But it's the evil that counts.After a moment's thought, it's easy to see that this is a game adaptation, like Tomb Raider or Super Mario Brothers. There's no plot to speak of, in the sense that one scene has to come before or after another. Instead, it's dozens of scenes and vignettes, flying in close formation. What matters instead is the mood, the visuals, and the characters. Rose (Radha Mitchell) stands out, as a very womanly character, and very strong because of it. In fact, all of the female characters are good. According to the IMDB blurb, that makes sense - male characters were an afterthought, and it shows.I've never played the SH game, and am not likely to. I've read part of the comic series, though, and loved it. It's nothing like the movie, except in all the ways that count - in those, it's great.Different viewers will rate this movie differently. General movie-goers may be underwhelmed. Game fan-boys/-girls will either love it or hate it, as usual. Anyone looking for an eerie visual experience or for a distinctive photographic scene-setting has a lot to enjoy. And anyone who gets black chills from creepy little girl-things will have a lot to work with.//wiredweird
