reviewText: I confess, I played the game, actually all SHs. Parts 1 to 3 took place in the town of silent hill. The movie is a bit of a mess/mix from the first and second entry. In the first SH, part of the big thrill was not to know anything. The game began with a really confusing introduction, actual events and such that will happen during the game: actual events involving a couple finding a baby (think Moses), a skinburnt girl in pain, a cop getting a call, a man with his daughter in a car, meeting up with the cop from before, then they have an accident...SPOILERS AHEAD:the game began right after the guy awakens in the broken car, realizing the daughter's gone. From then on, the quest for finding her became secondary when he finds that the accident brought him to a deserted town, with snow falling in the middle of summer, raising questions like "what's this place? Where's everyone?". During about half of the game there was this eerie feeling only due to lack of knowing what's going on. That doesn't mean the player was just doing one puzzle/fight after the other, the story evolved around the idea, that the guy might have been killed during the accident as the town has two faces: one being in thick fog, the other in darkness. Just as in the movie, the darkness transformed the environment and brought up different kind of enemies. The cinematic aspect of it was the brilliantly told story and the feeling of total isolation it caused as the few people who meet are just as confused as the main character. Slowly, there was story being built around the situation: that of a town in which the police once was looking for drug dealings, that of tourists once buying them, that of a hospital with a secret strange place in the cellar, that of a doctor drifting around town with a strange bag, that of children books with monsters you actually met (=fears becoming reality), that of the abusing of a girl by her own mother... slowly we got the picture and the idea that the own daughter might play a specific role in all this.In SH2 it was obvious that the town of silent hill was a ghost town that existed for real. It was left alone and deserted as many american ghost towns. From there the main character gets a letter from his dead wife, inviting him to the place they once loved. So he's not caught in another dimension, he was walking throught a real life town, but as in part one, it changed its face every now and then.The movie is mixing up both ideas: that of a person searching for her daughter in a strange town and that of a person actually looking for a really existing ghost town named silent hill (in the games you were always asking yourself if this place exists or not). I didn't like this fusion that much as it takes away the individual basic feeling of both games. It's a bit hard to explain unless you've experienced the games.The monsters are a bit too digital, the pyramid head and the nurses (!) looked like from a music video clip to me and were placed in a ridicoulus situation, like a table dancing group they stand there. I had to giggle there.Not my movie, but I liked the atmosphere and the pictures. The way Gans is trying to explain it all is ways ways ways overdone. I think especially this material would have done for a great rewatch-movie, only to understand more of it, but never fully.

reviewText: First off, the downsides: Some parts of the movie seemed a little drawn out, the film was two hours, and at certain times, you could feel that. It's far-fetched, and I can imagine some people rolling their eyes at the storyline, and there WILL be some people walking out saying "that was a stupid movie". (As many people responded to Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within.) Of course, some of them will be saying that in response to the sheer amount of gore and violence, which brings me into the 'upsides': This movie certainly had it's 'wow' moments with shock, anticipation, and gore, especially near the climax. Scenes and even alleyways and monsters from the games were almost identical. If you've played the games you will get a lot of deja vu. (For example, the camera goes crooked at exactly the same time and place it does in one of the scenes in the game.) Also, a lot of the sounds and music tracks from the games are used, and so are the monsters. The entire feel of the games is preserved in the film, and you will have trouble keeping your feet on the floor the entire movie. The creepy presentation works, and if you haven't played any of the games, this movie will scare you in new ways.

reviewText: I would say I liked this movie more than I disliked it. The acting was pretty good, effects were awesome, the plot was strong and I liked the ending. I was a little scared but I found the movie more creepy than scary. It's certainly better than a lot of horror/thriller stuff that has come out lately. It contained some fairly grusome stuff but was surprisingly low on actual blood and gore, I think it could have used more in this area. Also, I persoanlly think the whole 'gates of hell' concept is overdone in movies but I never played the game so maybe I am missing something here. The ambiance of the movie overall was wonderfully dark and it was well paced with good action. I did like it and I would watch it again and would suggest it to anyone who likes a good scary movie.
